PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Education: Government Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decision of the Honourable The Minister for Education Senator Ryan not to provide Commonwealth Recurrent Funding for the proposed extension to Secondary School in 1987 by the Illawarra Christian School be reversed.

Your petitioners request the Senate to protect the freedom of choice of parents wishing to educate their children in a Christian Secondary School by providing Commonwealth Recurrent Funding for the extension to Secondary School by the Illawarra Christian School.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that your petitioners:-
Request that the Hawke Government:
Remove the mining veto from the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we oppose the deregulation of housing interest rates without adequate safeguards to protect homebuyers.
2. That we condemn the Government for breaking its unequivocal promise not to deregulate these interest rates.
3. We express our concern that the Government's decision will cause undue hardship to many Australian families.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should: urge the Government to reverse its decision and re-impose the interest rate ceiling.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights because:
This Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as:-
The right to own your own home and other property and not to be deprived of it without just compensation.
The right to insulate our children from radical forms of education and the right to choice of schools.
The right to a referendum for constitutional amendments.
The right to True freedom of speech.
The Bill gives dangerous, unlimited powers to an unelected Human Rights Commission with no appeal, no legal representation and closed hearings.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote to reject the Bill, believing that such a Bill should only be determined by the people at a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lidija Lasmane-Doronina
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in January 1983 the Latvian born nursing sister Lidija Lasmane-Doronina was arrested by the Soviet authorities and subsequently sentenced to sixteen years in a strict regime enforced labour camp with an additional three years in exile. She had been charged with maintaining contact with Baptists abroad and for being in possession of a copy of the 1975 Helsinki Accords and of having a list of the Soviet Union's transgressions of them.

Since Lidija Lasmane-Doronina was only exercising her rights as guaranteed by the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights to which the Soviet Union is a cosignator, your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the Senate will intercede with the Soviet authorities on her behalf and so secure her early release.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal System in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Brownhill (from 16 citizens) and Robertson (from 14 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. In this aging Australian society children are our most precious resource.
2. We request that any changes to the Child Care Act should ensure the protection of these children by providing for quality care by mothercraft nurses or other trained child care professionals.
3. We urge that funding provided under the Child Care Act should ensure the maintenance of the present standards of 75 percent of award wages and conditions for approved child care professionals.
4. We also ask that available child care places be provided according to the needs of the children rather than through restricting access according to the work-related needs of parents.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
that the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill
1. offer nothing more than is already available under law,
2. deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should: completely reject the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Brownhill (from 11 citizens) and Robertson (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: Honourable the President, and members of Senate in Parliament assembled Parliament House Canberra, ACT
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia express our concern at the proposed Australian Bill of Rights legislation and therefore call on the Senate to reject that legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore pray: That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Knowles (from 13 citizens) and Robertson (from 68 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we are concerned at the likely adverse impact of the Australian Bill of Rights on the fundamental rights we Australians have already won.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled reject the Australian Bill of Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the so-called ``Australian Bill of Rights'' which is now before the Senate, is an inherently dangerous piece of legislation. Furthermore, it takes away many of the basic and important rights Australians now have. It is a blatant attempt to engineer social change according to a given ideology without the people having any say in the matter. It should be settled by a referendum.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled reject the Australian Bill of Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Retail Outlets
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled.

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, humbly pray that the parliament act to outlaw the practice of the large petrol companies also controlling petrol retail outlets in competition with independent petrol distributors and retailers who they supply, thus acting in a position of unfair competition, and leading to the large companies exerting unconscionable pressure on those independent distributors and retailers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support `The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of widespread serious ill health caused by smo-king tobacco.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petitioning letters from 47 and eight citizens respectively and a petition from 12 citizens, which are not in conformity with Standing Orders as they are not in the correct form and do not contain a prayer at the end thereof, reques-ting that the Australian Bill of Rights 1985 be rejected:

SPEECH.PARA: P.O. Box 85
Cardiff 2285
9th February 1986
Senator Michael Baume,
C/ Parliament House,
CANBERRA
Dear Sir,
During the next session of Parliament I understand that the proposed Bill of Rights will come before the Senate to be debated.
We the undersigned would like to voice our protest at the proposed Bill for the following reasons:
1. Due to the haste with which this legislation was passed through the House of Representatives in view of the fact that it affects adversely areas of immense importance to liberty and freedom.

2. Because it is based upon the United Nations International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights which has been rejected by the United States of America and Great Britain but was accepted by the Warsaw Pact countries.

3. Because our Australian Constitution states that ``whereas we the people'' give you the government these rights. The Constitution limits the rights and power of the government. The proposed Bill of Rights reverses this totally and states that ``we the government, give you the people these rights''. This totally reverses the nature of government in this country. Our rights are now protected by current legislation, Common law and the present Constitution.
4. Because it transfers the power of interpretation of legislation from the Parliament of Australia (the democratically elected institution) to the Courts (an un-elected body of people).

5. Because the Bill of Rights will be administered by the Human Rights Commission which is an unelected body of people with powers which are outside and not subject to the normal processes of law-no appeal, closed hearings, no legal representation.
We therefore request that you vote to reject this proposed Bill of Rights.
9 Exhibition Pde
Mt. Pritchard 2170
24th March 1986
Senator Baume
Parliament House
Canberra
Dear Senator,
We wish to express to you our alarm at the proposed Human Rights Bill, now before Parliament.

Rather than preserve the legal and human rights of Australians, now in operation, this Bill lays the way right open for tyranny and abuse of these rights. It is a Bill which has received no public debate, insufficient Parliamentary debate, and bears all the hallmarks of being hastily put together.

The far reaching effects of this Bill could be devasta-ting to the time-tested and highly-valued system of justice in this country. It is most worthy of note that the Bill is being received gladly by the leaders of totalitarian governments, but has been rejected by the democratic parliaments of Great Britain and United States of America. This nation should, in fact, MUST, also reject the Bill.
We urgently request that you vote against this Bill, in its entirety, when it comes before the Senate.
PETITION AGAINST THE PROPOSED
BILL OF RIGHTS

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY HEALTH AUTHORITY ORDINANCE 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to notice of intention which I gave on 16 April 1986, I withdraw Business of the Senate, notice of motion No. 3, standing in my name, for the disallowance of sections 54 and 59 of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority Ordinance 1985. I seek leave to make a brief statement explaining the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I first looked at the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority Ordinance I found quite a few oddities amongst the provisions. Consultation with the various unions confirmed my suspicion that some of the sections were completely out of date. Unfortunately the first time that virtually all the union officials had heard of the ordinance was when my office contacted them. They expressed varying degrees of incredulity and suspicion about several sections, which were largely the ones that I had noted. They certainly had misgivings about the manner in which the ordinance had been put together, particularly the lack of consultation, which is not conducive to a good industrial relations atmosphere.

SPEECH.PARA: I moved to disallow sections 54 and 59, which deal with employees on probation and the setting of qualifications for staff vacancies. There were problems with staff possibly not knowing that their period of probation had been extended and with inappropriate qualifications being set for vacancies. After discussions, the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) wrote to me about these and other matters connected with the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority Ordinance. I am prepared to accept the Minister's assurances that proper procedures must always be carried out in relation to probation and staff recruitment, and I therefore withdraw my notice of motion for disallowance of these sections. In order to save time I seek leave to incorporate the Minister's letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator D. Vigor
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
My Dear Senator
HEALTH AUTHORITY ORDINANCE 1985

My purpose in writing to you is firstly to give you an assurance that the prime objective of the above Ordinance was to give effect to the new broadly based ACT Health Authority as modelled by my colleague the Minister for Health, Dr Neal Blewett, and secondly to clarify for you the position in regard to those provisions of the Ordinance about which you have expressed some concern.

I am also aware that the ACT Trades and Labour Council has expressed similar concerns about those provisions of the Ordinance which deal with staff conditions of employment. Contact was made with Mr Charles MacDonald (Secretary of the ACT Trades and Labour Council) earlier this week and arrangements made for him and other union delegates to meet with Authority officers to discuss those concerns. I understand that the outcome was quite positive and that agreement was reached to establish a working group comprising TLC delegates and Authority officers to advise on the final form of those parts of an updated ordinance, which refer to staff conditions of employment. Consultations will also be held with the Hospital Employees Federation which, as you know, is not affiliated with the TLC.

I do wish to emphasise that the Ordinance was prepared primarily as enabling legislation to allow the new Authority structure to be put in place. The former Ordinance was used as its basis, and it was recognised that some clauses, particularly those that related to staff and conditions, needed review. The former Authority specifically declined to update these provisions during the transition stage so that the new Authority and its boards with wider membership as well as staff associations and other community based organisations could have the opportunity for input.

To assist you in considering your position in relation to specific sections of the Ordinance, I have set out below my comments about those sections and the advice I received from the General Manager of the Authority. My comments also cover those sections subject to disallowance motions by Senator Reid.
Section 11

You indicated a desire to amend Section 11 so as to provide for local political representation on the Authority. The government made a conscious decision to avoid overt politicisation of the Authority or the Boards which had caused some conflict in the past. The objectives and membership of the Authority and its boards emphasise broad ranging community participation in health services. My colleague the Minister for Health discussed this issue with Senator Haines and it was agreed that the absence of local political representatives would not be reason to move disallowance.
Section 45 (g)

Our colleague Senator Reid has lodged a notice of motion for disallowance of this paragraph. It provides that the Authority shall not appoint a person as a Visiting Medical Officer or a Visiting Dental Officer if that person has, in the opinion of the Authority, been guilty of unprofessional conduct. As it is the role of either the Medical Board or the Dental Board to find a doctor or dentist guilty of unprofessional conduct I am advising Senator Reid that I will raise no objection to the disallowance of this paragraph. I might add that I am advised that the disallowance of Section 45 (g) in no way diminishes the excellent professional standards which the public is entitled to expect of visiting Medical Officers in public hospitals.
Section 52-Appointment of Officers

You indicated that para 52 (2) (c) was of concern. This paragraph deals with the capacity of the Authority to satisfy itself that a potential appointee is a fit and proper person for appointment. It is unchanged from the superseded Ordinance and is identical to the standard set by the Public Service Act. In these circumstances I do not consider that it requires amendment.
Section 54-Appointment on Probation

You mentioned para 54 (4) (c) as needing alteration. This provision is unaltered from the superseded Ordinance. The Authority's administrative procedures ensure that a probationary period could never be extended or annulled without advice to the probationer. In the case of annulment, paragraph 54 (b) provides that reasons for such action must be given. There is provision for appeal against any adverse decision under Section 54 via Section 69. I attach, for your information, a copy of the form used by the Authority, and indeed by the whole Australian Public Service, for Probation Reports. You will see that Section 11 of that form provides specifically for the probationer to comment on the assessment if he or she so desires. Accordingly, I consider Section 54 of the Ordinance to be satisfactory in its present form.
Section 59-Filling of vacant positions

Your concern related to the power of the Authority to interpret sub-section 59 (2) so as to prescribe matters other than educational qualifications as necessary to fill vacant positions. This could not occur. The Section merely provides a capacity for the Authority to prescribe educational qualifications as necessary in a Health Authority which employs large numbers of technical and professional staff. It could not be used for any other purpose and in fact is used to ensure that the qualifications required by the Authority are similar to those required in the Public Service. This Section is unchanged from the previous Ordinance.
Sections 61, 62 and 65 to 69

I understand that you are particularly concerned about the lack of reference to the Merit Protection Review Agency in the provisions relating to promotion appeal and disciplinary matters. The relevant provisions are Sections 61 and 62 and 65 to 69 inclusive.

The General Manager of the Authority has advised me that several months ago the Authority decided that staff employed under the Health Authority Ordinance should be covered by the Merit Protection Review Agency procedures. Following this decision the Authority wrote to the Director of the Merit Protection Review Agency seeking his agreement to this arrangement.

Discussions were held with the Director of the Merit Protection Review Agency, Mr P. Gifford, last night and he has expressed the view that in extending services to Statutory Authorities it is his Agency's policy to deal first with those organisations who have expressed a wish to be so covered.

In respect to the ACT Health Authority Mr Gifford has agreed to have discussions with the Authority and the relevant unions before the end of April 1986 with a view to effecting the transfer of responsibility to the Merit Protection Review Agency by 1 July 1986.

In the meantime, to enable the Authority to continue to handle promotion appeals and disciplinary matters it is essential that Sections 61 and 62 and 65 to 69 are retained. You have my assurance, however, that the necessary amendments to enable the Merit Protection Review Agency to handle promotion and disciplinary appeal matters will be in place within the next six months.
Sections 63 and 64

As you point out these provisions dealing with tenure of office and excess officers are out of date and have been overtaken by the provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. The Australian Capital Territory Health Authority is a prescribed organisation under that act. I would therefore raise no objection to the disallowance of both these sections if a disallowance motion was put forward in respect of Section 63. You have already lodged a motion of disallowance in respect of Section 64.
Section 76

Senator Reid also gave notice of motion to disallow this section. It provides the Authority for a hospital patient to elect to be treated as the private patient of the doctor of choice. Now that the Department of Health is to issue a revised Medicare Directive to the effect that privately insured patients entering public hospitals will be automatically classified as private patients, unless they opt to be treated as Medicare patients, the provisions of Section 76 are unnecessary. I therefore have advised Senator Reid that I will raise no objection to the disallowance of this section.
Section 81-Secrecy

The intention of this Section is to impose the same standards on non-medical staff of the Authority as are imposed on medical staff by their own professional ethics. The provisions relate to disclosure of information concerning the affairs of any other person, or the provision of documents to other persons, except in the performance of a duty under the Ordinance. The provision is not intended as a measure to prohibit all discussion on Authority affairs, although normal public service standards on public comment would apply through other legislation, guidelines and codes.
Yours sincerely
GORDON SCHOLES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I add that the Minister has set 1 July as the goal for the Merit Protection Review Agency to take over the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority's promotions, appeal and disciplinary processes. In the light of the Minister's written assurance that the necessary amendments will be in place within six months, I shall withdraw my objection to sections 61, 62 and 65 and 69 by writing to the Clerk of the Senate. The Minister has indicated that he will not mourn the loss of section 63, which proposed quite unreasonable powers for dismissal of employees between the ages of 60 and 65 years. We will proceed with that disallowance.

DEBATE.TITLE: REVIEW OF THE REPATRIATION HOSPITAL SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government has endorsed the major recommendations of the report of the Review of the Repatriation Hospital System, chaired by Dr Ian Brand, which was tabled in Parliament on 11 September 1985. I commissioned this review in March 1984 seeking recommendations to correct deficiencies in resources, buildings, equipment and staff and to identify the requirements for the further development of the hospitals and related services to an ageing veteran and war widow population.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has confirmed that the repatriation hospital system will continue operating as a separate and independent unit for veterans and war widows for the foreseeable future but has agreed to the review's recommendations that planning should commence now with the States on rationalisation of services and for the eventual integration of repatriation hospitals with State health systems when they are no longer needed for Commonwealth purposes.

The Government has agreed to the recommendation that standing committees of senior State and Federal officials be established to advise on total departmental-State relationships in the health and hospital arena. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will be seeking the co-operation of State Premiers to implement this initiative. Several States are commencing major structural reviews in the nursing area. The need for a nursing career structure review to be undertaken in the Commonwealth area is accepted. The Public Service Board, in close co-operation with my Department and the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority and, as necessary, other departments and authorities and involving relevant staff associations, will be undertaking this review immediately.

The Brand review considered that there was sufficient evidence to suggest an interim increase of 6 per cent in overall staffing numbers in the repatriation general hospitals but admitted that it had neither the resources nor the time to determine specific numbers of additional staff, their classifications and locations. The Government has acknowledged that there is a need for an increase in staffing for the repatriation hospital system and the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Finance will be undertaking an immediate review of human resources, with the involvement of staff associations, to determine the numbers, classifications and locations of extra staff. This review will be separate from the review of Australian Public Service nursing career structures but will take into account any changes flowing from that review.

These immediate reviews will provide the Government with the basis for provision of resources to improve the treatment standards in repatriation hospitals and assist in reducing the numbers of referrals to non-departmental hospitals. I am concerned that these reviews be not delayed and that conclusions are reached as soon as possible. To this end and to put in train the Government's decisions in relation to the Brand report, a task force of senior officers is being established in my Department. Mr R. Somes, a principal adviser with the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, will be transferring to the Department of Veterans' Affairs to head this group under the senior executive service temporary assignment program.

These decisions, together with the increased funding in the 1985-86 Budget for repatriation hospitals, particularly in the areas of specialised equipment and capital works, confirm the Government's commitment to upgrade repatriation hospitals to meet the needs of our veterans and war widows. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite frankly, the Opposition considers that the response of the Government and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), as expressed in his statement on the report of the Review of the Repatriation Hospital System, is thoroughly unsatisfactory. This report, made to the Minister in June of last year is 246 pages long and has 236 recommendations. The Minister's response is written in little over two pages of foolscap and, in fact, seems to address, so far as I can ascertain, only six issues. It begins by saying that the Government `has endorsed the major recommendatons of the report'. However, the truth of the matter is that when one reads on through the statement to see in what way the Government has endorsed the major recommendations one sees that the Minister has ducked most of the major recommendations. As I said, he has in fact referred to only about six issues.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that without further elaboration from the Minister the veterans' organisations will need to give this report very close scrutiny, in view of the Minister's misleading statements about the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. The statement, as far as we are concerned, is couched in language that is unclear, and I think the veterans' organisations also will find it unclear. I suggest that one thing which is clear from the statement is that the Minister has no influence within the Cabinet. He has had to resort to generalities and rhetoric in order to cover the fact that he has been unable to get through the Cabinet many of the recommendations made in the Brand report.

Let me refer to one area in particular, the area of nursing, which the Minister appears to address in his statement. He refers to the need for a nursing career structure review to be undertaken in the Commonwealth area and says that the Government accepts that. He also says in regard to financing:

The Government has acknowledged that there is a need for an increase in staffing for the repatriation hospital system and the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Finance will be undertaking an immediate review of human resources . . .

Let us look at what the report says. It says that the disparity in wages between nursing staff employed by the repatriation general hospitals and those employed in the State systems should be urgently addressed. In other words, we really have to look at the problem of nursing wages for the reason that the Federal nursing award is about 10 to 20 per cent below the Victorian State award. We know that the Government is talking about a British nursing recruitment program, but the truth of the matter is that until such time as the Government fixes up the Federal nursing award nurses will be leaving the veterans hospitals en masse. That was established when my colleague the Liberal-National Party shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Tim Fischer, visited Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital in Melbourne on 17 March this year. He ascertained that of the 504 beds in that institution 133 were closed due to the severe shortage of registered nursing staff employed under the Commonwealth award. Notwithstanding the fact that 371 beds were open, he was officially advised that up to 50 veterans a week, of whom 20 would fall into the category of requiring essential rather than elective surgery, were being turned away from the Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital. This had been going on for some time at that stage. Indeed, the Minister was asked a question about that matter on 20 March and did not give a satisfactory response.

It is clear that one of the great problems here is the prices and incomes accord. The infamous accord of which this Government is so proud is creating a major problem for nurses employed under the Federal award in Australia. The Heidelberg and Concord hospitals are suffering greatly because of this Government's inability to do anything about the wages of nurses, thanks to the accord. As honourable senators will know from what I have read, the Minister has totally failed to address his mind to the problem and has not been able to persuade the Cabinet to apply its mind to the disparity in wages between the nursing staff employed in these institutions and those employed under State systems. That is but a simple example of one of the problems that arise from the 236 recommendations contained in this report and the thoroughly inadequate response by the Minister. I note that the Minister has arranged for Mr Somes, a senior officer, to be transferred to his Department under the senior executive service temporary assignment program to head up a task force. I wish Mr Somes well. I hope that Mr Somes will be more sympathetic to our veterans than the Department has been in the past. One would hope that the adversary role adopted by the Department to its client veterans will now cease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome the statement made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) with regard to the repatriation hospital system. I raised this issue in the last debate we had on the veterans' entitlements legislation and urged the Minister to declare as soon as possible what the Government intended to do with the report of the Review of the Repatriation Hospital System, which was chaired by Dr Brand, in terms of the additional resources that are required for that system. I think most people who have any dealings with veterans' affairs understand that Australia is now entering a period where the vast bulk of veterans-that is, roughly 320,000 veterans from the Second World War-are in their early sixties or slightly older. Medical statistics lead us to believe that the increasing greying of the veterans' community will place enormous pressure on hospitals which will treat the war related disorders and disabilities from which veterans suffer. Our repatriation hospital system will be required to pick up and assist in this respect.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's statement is a short one. I feel that many people in the veteran community will be looking for details which are missing from this very short statement. I would like to point to two items in particular that are mentioned in the statement. The Minister talks about the continued operation of the repatriation hospital system as a separate and independent unit for veterans and war widows. He then uses the phrase `for the foreseeable future'. The Minister then says:

. . . the planning should commence now with the States on rationalisation of services and for the eventual integration of Repatriation hospitals with State health systems when they are no longer needed for Commonwealth purposes.

I suppose forward planning is always desirable. However, I would have thought that any changeover from the repatriation system to a general hospital system is such a long way down the track as not to warrant inclusion in a brief, two-page note of what the Government intends to do in this area. Surely it is important to give an unequivocal guarantee that the repatriation hospital system will remain as a separate and independent unit for as long as it is required for veterans' purposes rather than-to use the phrase that is used in the statement-for Commonwealth purposes.

The veteran community is very concerned that the State systems would be unable to deal with particular areas of medicine, such as geriatric medicine, that are essential in repatriation hospitals. Many hospitals in the State systems would be unable to meet the requirements of such a specialised area and this would lead to a lessening in care for veterans. So the Australian Democrats certainly welcome the statement, as far as it goes, that the Government, as a matter of policy, now says that the repatriation hospital system will remain for the foreseeable future as a separate unit available to veterans and that specialised care will be provided for veterans.

The other item I raise, which takes up the bulk of this statement, refers to the staffing resources which are needed to meet the increased demands now facing repatriation hospitals, demands which will increase in the very near future. However, in reading the statement I am unable to find what decision the Government has made. On page 2 the Minister states:

The Brand Review considered there was sufficient evidence to suggest an interim increase of 6 per cent in overall staffing numbers . . . but admitted that it had neither the resources nor the time to determine specific numbers of additional staff . . .

The Government then goes on to say that it will undertake a review to determine that provision, but no commitment is made in this document to the essential element of the Brand report with regard to staffing; that is, that there is now sufficient evidence that there should be an interim increase of 6 per cent. The Government has not committed itself in this statement to picking up the initial increase of 6 per cent. It says it will look at what needs to be done, but I would have thought that the veteran community in particular was looking for a commitment from the Government to the initial interim measure of a 6 per cent increase. Where that actual staff would then go obviously has to be decided on the result of the review that the Government has announced in this statement. But why undertake a review when in fact we are not told whether or not there is any commitment to increase staff?

When I first read this statement it seemed to me that the Government had agreed with the Brand suggestion of a 6 per cent increase, but when I read it again I saw that there was no commitment, merely a suggestion that these decisions, together with increased funding in the area, confirm the Government's commitment. But when one goes back to look at what these decisions are, they amount to no more than that a review will be undertaken. I hope that that might have been an oversight in the way this statement is written because, after all, I would have thought that is the whole point of the Minister making a statement with regard to the review of the repatriation system insofar as it bears on the staffing problem. I cannot see in the statement where the other matters of the Brand report have been rehearsed in any detailed way, so I assume that this report is only about the staffing problem. When we limit it to that we do not see any decision taken by the Government to increase staff, merely one to look at where there are possibilities of increased staff. Yet as the Brand report very clearly points out, there is already sufficient evidence to suggest at least a 6 per cent increase.

I hope that the Government will respond immediately to the query I raise because I know that the veteran community has been pressing the Government on that item since the Brand report was delivered to the Government late last year. I hope that the veteran community will not have to wait any longer to see whether the Government is actually committed to that particular increase.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.
