Clause 38 (Warranties in relation to the supply of services).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated yesterday, when we were discussing a number of other matters with relation to the Trade Practices Revision Bill 1986, that we would be moving an amendment with regard to clause 38, which is the clause which amends section 74. This is the clause that has probably excited most interest in this chamber, and it has attracted attitudes lined up much more on ideological bases than those on probably any other clause. Essentially, our amendment is to exempt qualified architects and engineers from the ambit of the new legislation, and we do that for a specific reason.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Durack commented yesterday that more and more professionals are incorporating, and that this is particularly true of architects and engineers. This is not our main reason for moving this amendment. In amending the Trade Practices Act through clause 38, the Government is attempting to bring to bear, I suppose, a greater responsibility on the part of professionals in their dealings with their clients. This measure will not do what a number of people have suggested it will do-place an excessive burden on most of those professionals so that if they do not achieve some whimsical desire which may or may not have been made known to them by the client, they will somehow be in dereliction of their duty and will be hauled before the nearest court, and as a consequence, of course, their personal liability insurance is going to skyrocket, costs to the consumer are going to increase, and all sorts of nasty things, including the end of the Western world as we know it, will occur. In fact, that is a nonsense, and I think that most people who are alleging it realise that it is a nonsense. Doctors will not be expected to cure patients in every case, nor will lawyers be expected to get all their clients off. Nothing of this sort has happened even in the United States, where people are far more prone to litigation on vexatious and frivolous issues than we are here.

The issue with regard to architects and engineers is we believe that they fall into a special category as far as their relationship to their client is concerned; that is that, while they come up with designs, specifications and so on in accordance with whatever a particular client wishes, in the implementation of those specifications, designs, contracts and so on a fairly significant third party intervenes.

As I said, we do not subscribe to the general argument that has been put in this place over the last few months of debate-that professionals generally should be exempt in the manner in which they have been in the past; that there is somehow a God-given difference between trades people and professional people that allows the professional to have oversight of his or her actions while the tradesperson has to be covered by the law in a more specific way. In the case of architects and engineers, we believe that the complicating factor of that third party that I mentioned is a reason for amending the legislation as far as the provision of services by those two categories of professionals is concerned.

The particular cause of concern to us is, as I said, the intervention of a third party. A builder, for example, can ignore or deviate from specifications in such a way that the end result is not what was contracted for or expected by the client, and can do so in a manner which is not always readily apparent to the people who may have cause for complaint at the end. Unravelling who caused what problem is a big enough difficulty when one is dealing even with such things as an ordinary suburban home, let alone with multi-storey buildings, bridges and what-have-you that are dealt with on a regular basis by architects and engineers. To imply that the architects or engineers are absolutely responsible and that if a building or whatever turns out to be unfit in some way for the purpose they are wholly responsible is to place a far more onerous provision on them, I would have thought, than is placed in any other dealings between another group of professionals and their clients or patients, or whatever they want to call them.

The effect of this amendment being accepted would simply be that architects and engineers would be covered by the common law, as they are at the moment, and that they could then battle their way through the sorts of problems that occur if windows pop out of multi-storey buildings or bridges fall down, as they have in the past. I just hope that the Committee sees fit to support the amendment, for the reasons that I have put. I move:
Page 35, lines 1 to 10, leave out the clause, insert the following new clause:
Warranties in relation to the supply of services
``38. Section 74 of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by inserting in sub-section (2) `(other than services of a professional nature provided by a qualified architect or engineer)' after `services' (first occurring); and
(b) by omitting sub-section (3) and substituting the following sub-section:
`(3) A reference in this section to services does not include a reference to services that are, or are to be, provided, granted or conferred under-

(a) a contract for on in relation to the transportation or storage of goods for the purposes of a business, trade, profession or occupation carried on or engaged in by the person for whom the goods are transported or stored; or
(b) a contract of insurance.'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government is not disposed to accept this amendment. To the extent that there is any justification for it, it would certainly not appear to be the grounds just advanced by Senator Haines, which are based on the practical reality that there is very often the interposition of a third party between architects and engineers and their clients. The existence of that third party in the case of an architect-for example, a builder-does not in any way affect the character of the legal relationship between the architect and the client.

SPEECH.PARA: There may be practical difficulties in untangling the respective responsibilities and determining whether something is a design fault or a fault that is attributable rather to execution, but that, of course, is a recurring problem in real life and it does not in any way undermine the character of the legal obligation which at the moment, as a matter of common law, the architect has directly to the client. It should not affect the course of this particular debate, which is about whether that common law obligation should be given statutory expression and perhaps slightly rewritten to include in sub-section 74 (2) the concept of fitness for purpose.

A better reason for considering that architects and engineers perhaps do not need to be covered by this statutory provision is an argument based on a United Kingdom Court of Appeal case in 1975 which indicated, if it is indeed good law, that the scope of the duty or obligation of professionals such as architects and engineers at common law does extend to this wider criterion of warranties of fitness as to purpose. In that sense, they might be more exposed to liability at common law than other categories of profes- sionals. The case in question is Greaves and Co. v. Baynham Meikle and Partners, 1975, 3 All England Reports at page 99, where the United Kingdom Court of Appeal held that there was an implied term that a warehouse designed by a structural engineer would be fit for the storage and transportation by fork-lift truck of oil drums on its first floor, where that purpose had been known to the structural engineer and it was clear that the building was needed for that purpose. The argument would be that section 74 (2) of the Act imposes no more liability than does the law of contract as articulated by the Court of Appeal in the Greaves case.

So far, perhaps, so good, from the point of Senator Haines's argument, and the Government did have some willingness to accede to Senator Haines's representations on the basis of that consideration. However, a further consideration that must be resolutely borne in mind in these matters is the one I advanced yesterday in debate on an earlier amendment, and that is that the common law is not in itself an absolute guarantee, even where applicable, as perhaps here, that the obligations will in fact exist, because it is possible to contract out of a common law obligation. That is the problem about relying wholly on common law grounds of liability when one is talking about professional and other categories of responsibility.

It is the case that, except perhaps for some limited residual operation of the concept of fundamental breach, about which, again, I will not burden the Senate with a lecture, apart from some potential residual operation of that particular doctrine in this area, but necessarily of very limited scope, the reality is that professionals, like anyone else, can contract out of liability for negligence, and some of them do, whereas they cannot contract out of liabilities under the Trade Practices Act by virtue of the existence of section 68, as I said yesterday. I have established that while it is certainly claimed by both the architectural and engineering professions that they do not as a matter of practice contract out of liability, that as professionals they accept a proper liability, and while I do not contest that as a matter of practice that does generally occur, nonetheless the opportunity is there for them to do so. I am also advised by the Trade Practices Commission that there is nothing in the architects' code of ethics to prevent them contracting out, and in the engineers' code of ethics there is also nothing directly to prevent them contracting out, although some of the more generalised expressions of principle that appear in that engineering profession document might be construed as at least inhibiting them from so acting.

The bottom line in all of this remains that at the end of the day there is simply no reason for treating any particular group, either the professions as a whole or some particular sub-category of professions within that larger group, any differently from anyone else. As I said yesterday, if a concreter who is employed to pour foundations for a coastal house but does not render services fit for that purpose can be subject to liability under section 74 (2), there is no reason why an architect employed to design a house fit to stand the pressures of coastal winds and so on should not also be liable if that house does not meet that purpose. There is no reason for that kind of exemption.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that they should be.

—No, but the honourable senator is saying that they should not be liable by virtue of anything in the Trade Practices Act. What I am saying is that the liability which presently exists as a matter of common law is a liability that can be avoided. There is no reason why any group of professionals should have the capacity to avoid liability, if one is being serious about implementing nationally codes of conduct, as it were, for the protection of consumers relating to services as well as goods. There is no justification for singling out any particular group as appropriately the recipient of a higher vote of confidence than someone else. It is invidious to distinguish doctors and lawyers as less worthy of confidence than are architects and engineers. I am not making any particular assault on the architectural or engineering professions in what I am saying, but simply making the point that the case has not been made for treating them differently from anybody else. It is for those reasons that the Government resists this amendment.

—The example that Senator Gareth Evans has raised about concrete contractors and architects pouring foundations and designing houses respectively for coastal areas is not appropriate to the cases I was raising. Clearly, should something happen to a house in the way he has raised, it would be fairly easy, I would have thought, to find out whether it was the concrete pour or the design that was at fault. It is not always so easy and that was the point I was raising, notwithstanding frantic wind-up signals from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) at the time in order that we could get through this with some expedition. Certainly there will be areas where one can pinpoint clearly which of the people involved-the designer or the people putting the design into effect-were at fault. It is far more likely that there will be far more areas where it is not so clear. It seems to me, I repeat, that there is an unnecessarily onerous burden on those professionals where there are interposing events and people-tradesmen and other professionals-which make it worth while putting in this sort of exemption, notwithstanding anything they may or may not have in their codes of ethics, which is another matter entirely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have moved a further amendment to the Government's amendments to the Trade Practices Act dealing with the delivery of professional services. As we debated this matter at some length last evening, the issue that emerged from the Government's amendments was the very wide increase in the responsibility or liability which will be imposed on professional persons. They will expand the liability which professional people have had for centuries under our law, namely, to exercise reasonable skill and care, having regard to their professional expertise and the skills which they have been trained to use and which their experience requires them to be able to use. A very high duty of care is imposed on professional people because of the reliance on their skills by their clients. The law has recognised that and has enforced it for a very long time. Indeed, professional people are now subject more and more to claims for damages. These days professional people are careful to cover themselves with professional indemnity insurance because of the effectiveness of the existing law.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is now saying that it can improve on these responsibilities and liabilities of professionals and will amend the Trade Practices Act to widen that liability to cover a situation where a person makes known, either expressly or by implication, the purpose for which the professional service is required. In that event, as Senator Evans has pointed out, an implied liability may be imposed by this Act. Any such implication cannot be excluded by agreement; it will be implied that the services will be reasonably fit for the purpose that has been made known to the professional. The particular obligation that is thereby imposed by the client on the professional cannot be excluded by agreement. A fantastic requirement might be imposed, in which case virtually the only thing the professional could do is refuse to act at all in the circumstances, because if that requirement is imposed by legislation there will be another objective test as to whether or not the services are reasonably fit for that purpose, or are of such a quality as might reasonably be expected to achieve that result.

The Opposition is totally opposed to the imposition on professional people of this additional very wide and uncertain obligation. The debate we had was to endeavour to exclude professional services from this amendment to the Trade Practices Act. Last night the Democrats voted with the Government to defeat the Opposition's amendment because the reality is that they do not understand the effect of this provision. Indeed, they seem to think, from what I can gather from what Senator Haines has said in previous debates and said again last night, that the obligation will be not much different from the existing obligation. I sometimes think that the Democrats believe that this liability which will be imposed on professionals is the same as the existing liability. That is not the case. The Government is not arguing that; it is arguing that the obligation on professionals should be extended in this way and should impose these further uncertainties and liabilities on professional people generally, preventing them from being able to contract out of such great responsibilities.

If this amendment is passed-the Opposition attempts have been effectively defeated by the Democrats' support for the Government's amendments-there will be enormous problems in getting adequate insurance cover in many cases. If that cover is obtained it will be at very much greater premiums which obviously will be passed on to the clients of professional people. We want to make it perfectly clear that the Democrats are supporting this great expansion of liability of professionals and the increase in the cost of professional services which will result. Many professionals will refuse to accept these sorts of burdens at all by simply refusing to act or, as Senator Sheil pointed out last night, with his medical knowledge will refuse to carry out innovative procedures which may be desired or required by a patient with a full knowledge of the risks involved. The Medical Defence Union Ltd in New South Wales, which was referred to by Senator Michael Baume, has also pointed out that there will be this restriction on the type of medical services that doctors will provide as a result of this ridiculous and totally unnecessary expansion of the liability of professional people.

The Australian Democrats have supported the Government on that issue and have refused to vote for the Opposition's amendment, and the result is on their heads. Because of the usual intellectual bankruptcy of the Democrats, which is constantly revealed in this chamber, and because they want to be nice to somebody-they are always anxious to be nice to somebody-they have accepted the argument that has been advanced by architects and engineers. They have tried to single out these people as being in a different capacity from all other professional people. I do not understand why the Democrats have singled out architects and engineers and suggested that they should be exempt from these rigorous additional burdens that will be imposed upon all other professional people. The argument that Senator Haines advanced this morning is absolute nonsense. To say that only architects and engineers have third parties interposed between them and the ultimate delivery of the service to the client is rubbish. Doctors particularly are subjected even more so to the intervention of third parties in very delicate situations. This occurs with hospital treatment for which they cannot be responsible from minute to minute. It all depends on nurses, nursing aides and other paramedical staff. The argument that has been put forward is intellectually bankrupt and is a classic example of the Democrats' attitudes.

Certainly architects and engineers may be placed under a greater threat than other professionals by this amendment to the Trade Practices Act for two reasons, both of which I mentioned when I spoke last night. In the first place, architects and engineers very often operate under a corporate structure these days. The engineers particularly have been in the vanguard of the movement for professionals to practise under a corporate veil rather than on personal liability which has been the traditional role for professional people's operations. That movement is now widening in the professional community. There may be more architects and engineers practising under the corporate veil; but that is not a sound argument for singling them out, because other professions are moving in that direction. That has also been pointed out in the letter to which I referred from the Medical Defence Union in New South Wales, which stresses that doctors are operating increasingly in that way.

The second and perhaps a better reason for singling out architects and engineers is that they are more likely to feel the effects of this extended provision of the Government's amendment. That amendment is probably more applicable to them in that they are constantly being subjected to their clients' saying `We want a building for a particular purpose'. That situation arises more commonly in these two professions than it does in others. The danger for other professionals is that this legislation will not be applied only where there is an express statement of purpose, but also where there is an implied statement of purpose for a service. Therefore, it is very dangerous for all professionals. There may well be an argument in regard to architects and engineers. They were the first people to perceive the problem of this amendment and to make representations. Certainly that was so in my case. Perhaps there is more real concern that this poses a greater threat to architects and engineers than to other professionals. However, from the Opposition's point of view there is clearly no justification for simply singling out architects and engineers above other professional people, all of whom are under some threat or other, all of whom will have some additional liability-to a greater or lesser extent-imposed upon them.

However, the Opposition's view on this matter is, as I said on another intellectually bankrupt amendment put forward by the Democrats to this legislation, that we are thankful for small mercies. If some people can benefit from the Democrats' intellectual bankruptcy by achieving some amelioration of this draconian and unnecessary burdensome legislation placed on the business and professional community of this country, the Opposition will support it, even though we think that there is no intellectual justification for it. We believe the Democrats should be condemned for not seeing the significance of this legislation and for not supporting the Opposition in its efforts to achieve a rational and intellectually sound basis for opposing the Government's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Faced with this formidable coalition of the intellectually bankrupt and the opportunistic, the Government has no alternative but to capitulate. I make it clear that we do not do so with any enthusiasm and we believe that this is an amendment which should not be carried.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 39 to 45-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 45a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: 11.03)-I move the amendment circulated in my name:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 38, after clause 45, insert the following new clause:
``45A (1) After section 74G of the Principal Act, the following section is inserted:
Liability of manufacturer or importer in respect of certain defective motor vehicles
`74GA (1) In this section-

``authorized service agent'', in relation to the manufacture of a motor vehicle, means a person authorized by the manufacturer to effect repairs to the motor vehicle for the purposes of the express warranty given by the manufacturer in respect of the motor vehicle;
``motor vehicle'' includes a motor cycle.

`(2) This section applies in relation to a motor vehicle where a consumer has acquired the motor vehicle in circumstances in which an express warranty given, in or in relation to trade or commerce, by a corporation that is the manufacturer of the motor vehicle is applicable in respect of the acquisition.

`(3) Where this section applies in relation to a motor vehicle, a consumer becomes entitled to a remedy under this section in respect of that motor vehicle where, while the relevant warranty is still in force and within one year from the date on which the motor vehicle was first supplied to a consumer-

(a) on not less than 4 occasions, an authorized service agent has been given an opportunity of remedying a particular defect to which the warranty is applicable (whether or not the authorized service agent is the same person on each occasion) and the defect has not been satisfactorily remedied; or

(b) the motor vehicle has been out of service for more than 30 days (whether in a continuous period or not) by reason of any defect or defects to which the warranty is applicable notwithstanding that reasonable and prompt steps have been taken to enable an authorized service agent to attend to the defect or defects.

`(4) Where a consumer who is entitled to a remedy under this section informs the manufacturer, or an authorized service agent, in writing, that he wishes to avail himself of that remedy and arranges for the surrender of the motor vehicle to the manufacturer or an authorized service agent, the manufacturer shall, at the option of the manufacturer, either-

(a) supply to the consumer, without charge, a new motor vehicle substantially the same (except as regards defects) as the motor vehicle concerned and covered by a warranty corresponding to the original warranty on the surrendered vehicle; or

(b) make a payment, in accordance with this section, of an amount equal to the amount that was, in the transaction by which a consumer first acquired the motor vehicle, treated as the cash price of the motor vehicle, less a fair deduction for depreciation having regard to the distance over which the motor vehicle has been driven and any damage to the motor vehicle not attributable to defects covered by the warranty.

`(5) A payment by the manufacturer in accordance with paragraph (4) (b) shall be made to, or divided among, the person or persons who have a legal interest (including a security interest in the motor vehicle concerned at the time of its surrender and, if there is more than one such person, in such shares as are agreed among them or determined by the Court in accordance with this section.
`(6) If the manufacturer is uncertain as to the person to whom a payment should be made or as to the proper shares of persons in such a payment, the manufacturer may pay the amount into the Court.
`(7) The Court may, on the application of any person interested, make such orders (including mandatory injunctions) as it thinks necessary and just for giving effect to this section, including orders
(a) for the just disbursement of moneys paid into the Court; and

(b) for declaring, or adjusting in such a manner as is just, the rights and liabilities of persons arising out of transactions in relation to a motor vehicle surrendered in accordance with this section or in relation to moneys paid by a manufacturer under this section.

`(8) Where a new motor vehicle is supplied by a manufacturer to a consumer in accordance with paragraph (4) (a), the same rights and liabilities exist in and in relation to the new motor vehicle as existed in relation to the surrendered motor vehicle.

`(9) Where a manufacturer supplies a new motor vehicle or makes a payment in accordance with this section, all rights and title in the motor vehicle originally supplied vest in the manufacturer, free from all securities.'.
``(2) The amendment made by sub-section (1) applies in respect of motor vehicles first acquired by consumers on or after the day fixed for the coming into operation of this section.''.

This amendment inserts new clause 45a to deal with what are affectionately-or perhaps not so affectionately-known in this country as `lemon cars'. I will certainly be interested in hearing the Minister's enthusiastic rebuttal of this proposed amendment because when the issue was first raised some years ago Senator Gareth Evans told me that the Australian Labor Party would not embrace it with any enthusiasm at that point, although it was very sympathetic to the problem, because the entire Trade Practices Act was under review. The entire Trade Practices Act has now been reviewed. That review has brought forth the amending Bill that we have been debating for some months, and still there is not protection inherent in it for people who, having bought a car, discover that it is so full of faults that it is basically a dud or a lemon and that they are getting no joy from either the dealer or the manufacturer when they take it back for servicing or fixing .

I first raised this issue in 1982 because I was receiving an increasing number of complaints in my office about the rather cavalier way in which some dealers and manufacturers were treating consumers who had purchased a new car in good faith and who seemed to be spending more time at the dealer's workshop than they were spending enjoying the use of that new car. I said at that point that this was not an attack on all the importers, manufacturers, distributors or dealers of cars, most of whom are conscious of the need to maintain the integrity of the brand name of the car they are importing, manufacturing or dealing in by giving prompt, efficient and effective service on a car which is proved to have some fault or another.

The various State consumer affairs departments have noted over the years that manufacturers are increasingly offering genuine assistance towards the rectification of mechanical or paint faults or other problems that have originated from manufacture. Most dealers, I am pleased to say, also take that responsible attitude. However my files, and I am sure files of other people, indicate that there are still some who are not prepared to take their responsibility seriously, notwithstanding that there are a large number who do take their responsibility beyond the warranty period. Those files are not full of frivolous or vexatious claims by people who have bought faulty cars. In the main they are from people complaining that some authorised service agents are simply not prepared to accept fully their responsibilities-in some cases even during the warranty period, but in many cases outside it-using the warranty period expiration as justification for not performing the sort of service or replacement and so on that they should have done in the first place. The people who are complaining to me are getting tired of being blamed, in effect, for the problem, of being fobbed off with excuses such as `all cars of that make and model make that noise', or `it does not make the noise when we drive it', which implies that there is something the matter with the driving skill of the person concerned. They are being told that they ought to ignore it because it will gradually wear itself in and it will all go away. The sorts of irrational excuses that people are being met with are simply not good enough. It should not be almost impossible in modern day society to get compensation in circumstances where a genuine complaint exists, and to get that compensation either by way of reasonable, prompt and adequate service from the dealer, or in some other form.

The Americans have certainly confronted this issue in a number of cases and it has not been the end of the car industry there. America has come up with some reasonably restrictive and not unreasonable circumstances under which compensation needs to be made to the consumer. I will not go into the sorts of dreadful things that happen to people, unless I am pushed in a little while to do so, because I realise that we are running short of time.

This legislation, in effect, will mean that a motor vehicle purchaser would be entitled to redress-if the warranty on that vehicle is still in force and within one year from the date on which the vehicle was first supplied to the consumer-in the form of a new motor vehicle or financial reimbursement after depreciation had been taken into account. The consumer would be entitled to redress if, on not fewer than four occasions, a particular defect to which the warranty is applicable has not been remedied, or if the motor vehicle has been out of service for more than 30 days, whether in a continuous period or not, by reason of any defect to which the warranty applies. I do not think that is unreasonable given that there are still a number of dealers who are irresponsible enough to hope that they will gradually wear down the resistance of the consumer so that they do not keep coming back to have it fixed, so that they give up and simply drive the car-assuming it is driveable-in whatever state it is in.

Let me repeat that the amendment I am moving today is not an attack on the manufacturers, the importers, or the majority of dealers, but I argue that it will compel those who do not already do so to act in a socially responsible manner. In other words, it will force them to do what the majority already do.

Sub-section 74GA (4) gives manufacturers and not the consumer the option of choosing between the supply of a new vehicle and the making of a refund. This appears to be the position under similar State laws in the United States of America, and I find it a reasonable one to give to the manufacturer. Although I note that the United States Federal law relating to consumer products generally provides that the warrantor must permit the consumer to elect either a refund for or a replacement without charge of such product or part, in this instance I think it is reasonable that the manufacturer should have the option, especially when we take into account that a comparable car may not be available where a new model has come out. Furthermore, the depreciation or damage may be such as to make it unreasonable that the manufacturer should be required to provide a new car.

Sub-section 74GA (7) has been included because it is difficult, if not impossible, to foresee and provide for all the problems that can arise out of the making of a refund or the supply of a new motor vehicle. It therefore seems to be appropriate and wise to vest in the Federal Court wide powers to declare or adjust rights and liabilities.

By imposing legal obligations on manufacturers and importers, I believe the amendments before the Senate today will basically reduce the element of risk currently entailed when a consumer purchases a new motor vehicle. The amendments will protect consumers by imposing a real social responsibility on manufacturers and importers. I believe we can no longer sit back and allow some people to be taken for a ride by a few unscrupulous dealers and perhaps irresponsible or negligent importers and manufacturers in this country. While many voluntarily behave as they should, a number do not, and I believe that in this instance it is time the law protected the consumer of new motor vehicles. My amendments will, I hope, achieve that aim and I commend them to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government recognises that with motor vehicle purchases that most consumers make or will become involved in at some time, which do usually represent a significant cost, the consumer should be given a reasonable protection from unfair conduct and be provided with statutory warranties in relation to defective products. There is no difference at all in that fundamental outlook between the Australian Democrats and ourselves. However, we do not believe, as presently advised, that this product-specific amendment that the Democrats are proposing is really necessary. The very basis of Divisions 2 and 2A of the Trade Practices Act as it now exists is the protection of consumers against unfair treatment by manufacturers or importers and sellers of goods which arise from that unequal bargaining power. The Government's commitment to restoring and enhancing the previously understood operation of the consumer protection provisions of the Act, and to improving the Act's ability to protect consumers and reputable business interests, is clear from the amendments that are contained in the Trade Practices Revision Bill we are now debating.

SPEECH.PARA: We are prepared to go on looking at alternative means by which the problem, if it is shown to be of sufficient magnitude, can be tackled. Before one looks at an amendment conferring rights in relation to a particular product-in this case, lemons, or defective motor vehicles-there should be a critical examination of the incidence of the problem, of the need for remedial action, given the other provisions in the legislation which are now being beefed up by the other amendments we have been debating, and of alternative forms, not just legislative, of remedial action it could take.

Let me spell out a couple of those points in a little more detail. The Trade Practices Act at present implies conditions and warranties as to, for example, fitness of purpose of goods, including goods such as motor vehicles, their merchantable quality, and availability of service facilities, repairs and parts. If a supplier breaches a condition or warranty under the Act under section 75A, the consumer may seek a recision of the contract; that is to say, in effect he or she may return the vehicle and receive the purchase price back without any loss or damage sustained. In addition, the consumer has the right to take action up to three years after his or her problems arise, not within a year of the date of supply, as in fact is proposed by Senator Haines's amendment.

The present Act also imposes civil and penal sanctions on suppliers who, for example, make false or misleading statements as to the exclusion or effect of any condition of warranty or the price of or the need for goods and services. The present Act does not in general extend to commercial vehicles, reflecting its character here as a consumer protection measure rather than a business regulation measure at large. However, the amendments which are contained in clause 5 of this Bill will ensure that the Act covers all motor vehicles, commercial or otherwise. The Government recognises that consumers may not be as aware of these rights as they could be, or should be. I guess this is one of the central points in Senator Haines's contribution to this debate. We are currently considering proposals to increase consumer information and education to rectify this situation.

It should also be said that there is some legislation in the States and Territories specifically regulating motor car traders. The possible effects of this amendment on that legislation need to be carefully considered together with the question of whether the Commonwealth should intervene in this area, given that existing State and Territory legislation. It is not a question of being absolutely inhibited from such intervention but it is a question of practical necessity. That is a matter that needs to be addressed.

What I am saying on behalf of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is simply this: The Government is prepared to consider additional measures to deal with defective motor vehicles, including possibly further amendments in time to the Trade Practices Act. However, we would need to be satisfied that a problem exists which the existing law is not adequate to handle and which is appropriately dealt with by legislation rather than other means. I should further say that the Government's disposition in all these matters is to look not at product specific legislation but rather legislation that would apply to all products. The framework of the Act, which is cast in those terms at the moment, is, we believe, basically sound, and much of this soundness does come from its general application. We will not lend our support to this amendment but we will further examine the matter of defective motor vehicles to gauge whether there is a problem and, if so, the extent of the problem. If a problem is revealed which requires attention the Government will look at solutions to it through a combination of measures which certainly may include other amendments to the Trade Practices Act but also include encouraging industry to take remedial measures and increasing consumer information and education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) for the limited words of comfort he gave about the manner in which the current Government amendments are likely to assist people who have bought new motor vehicles that do not do what they want them to do or go where they want them to go in the manner that they would like them to do it. However, I take some umbrage at the comment that the Government will continue to see whether there is a problem and whether it is of sufficient magnitude to do anything about it. The fact of the matter is that there is a problem here. However small the number of dealers and manufacturers involved may be it is nevertheless a massive problem for the people who are caught by owning one of these cars that simply turn out to be a Monday car, a dud or a lemon, or whatever anybody else wants to call them.

SPEECH.PARA: Purchasing a car is one of the major costs that any consumer faces. Consumers deserve much better than the cavalier treatment they sometimes receive. It is not enough for the Government simply to promise to go on looking at the matter and to take whatever steps may be necessary if a problem appears to exist, and appears to exist in sufficient magnitude. We are dealing with an item which on average costs people between $10,000 and $20,000. For most people, that is not an insignificant purchase. I think they have a right to assume that, with minor details aside, they are going to be able to drive that car in comfort and safety and to have whatever faults come up in it dealt with adequately, quickly, responsibly and efficiently.

When I first raised this matter in 1982 I gave as an example an American situation which was, at least in part, responsible for producing changes in the American Act. I want to repeat that example here partly because I think it is a very good one and partly because I do not want to be put in a position of actually specifying an occurrence relating to a particular dealer, manufacturer or importer in Australia. I want to keep it as general as I can. This particular American example is not dissimilar to some which have occurred here in Australia and, indeed, which have prompted one New South Wales driver actually to purchase a number plate that has `LEMON' for its first five letters. He drives around in his imported car with his number plate for all to see. He had problems that were at least as serious as the one I am about to cite. He got caught up in a dealer change of hands problem that left him and his family quite severely affected.

The particular man in America fought for 18 months a vain battle to have his car repaired satisfactorily. The faults he complained of included the car collecting seven inches of water after a rain storm, the electrical system failing repeatedly, the paint peeling, the parking brake pedal coming off, the manual transmission repeatedly popping out of second gear and going into neutral, and an assortment of lesser faults.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was this a new car?
—Yes, it was a new car.
—Was it under warranty?

—Yes. Despite the seriousness of his complaints the car sat in the dealer's car yard for transmission repairs for 135 days over a period of 18 months. As I said, it was his case which led to one State in America passing its own specific legislation to ensure that manufacturers, distributors and authorised agents accepted the fact that their responsibility to a customer went beyond merely selling a person a car.

SPEECH.PARA: While, for a variety of reasons, I do not want to take up any more of the Committee's time in dragging out the sorts of concerns that I have on file, this example is by no means something so extraordinary or so exaggerated that it has not happened or could not happen again in Australia. Since the Government is not going to indicate its immediate concern in this matter I can only hope either that the Opposition will do something or that the Government, in the event of the Opposition not supporting the amendment, will be a little more enthusiastic and do something more to help people who purchase a car that turns out to be a lemon than simply say that it is going to continue investigations to see whether there is a problem and whether it is of sufficient magnitude to warrant attention. After all, the reason that the Minister fobbed me off on behalf of the Labor Party some years ago was that it would be investigating this issue, among others. I would say that the current trade practices amending legislation does not go as far as it should in protecting the hundreds of people in this country who are suffering frustration, anger and economic loss as a consequence of their irresponsible treatment at the hands of some dealers, some agents and some manufacturers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats dealing with the so-called lemon, namely the car that just does not seem to be able to be made to work as it is supposed to, is a very good example, on the one hand, of how hard cases, as it is said, make bad law and, on the other hand, of the desperate desire of the Democrats to be nice to somebody and to please anybody who comes along and pitches them a hard luck story. Again, we have an example of a Democrat proposal with little principle or consistency. Sure enough, it is very irritating and very upsetting for people when they buy a pro-duct-one which they may have saved hard for and which they may cherish very much-to find that it really does not operate in any sort of a satisfactory way and that they cannot get satisfactory redress for that, in some cases, no matter how hard a dealer may try to improve it.

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to be no reason at all in principle why the legislation should specifically apply to a car. The problem could relate to a whole range of products. There is no reason why we should have special legislation that deals only with cars. Certainly, hard luck stories seem to arise in respect of motor cars. However, the problem must be very rare when one considers the large number of motor cars, to say nothing of the large number of consumer products generally, that are dealt in. Sure enough, such problems are very upsetting for the person who suffers. They also make good headlines when a journalist gets hold of them. We know that headlines really set the Democrats aflame; they encourage them to introduce legislation to fix up a problem. This is another pathetic example of parliamentarians, particularly the Australian Democrats, waving a wand and putting forward legislation so as to make them feel good.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pass laws for the good of the people.

—The Democrats' amendment enables Senator Sanders to rant and rave as he does on every subject that makes him feel good. It is a classic example of the misuse of Parliament and legislation. We are talking about a problem which is comparatively rare. We cannot use legislation to fix up every rare problem that arises. In fact, this legislation is extremely badly drafted.
—If that is the best you can do, sit down.

—The honourable senator can get up and make one of his ranting speeches when I have finished. We will all have to suffer it. However, I do not propose to compete with my noisy colleague. The fact of the matter is that the amendment is so badly drafted that it does not simply deal with the lemon situation at all. It applies to used cars as well as new cars. It simply refers to a particular defect, which might be of a most minor kind, that is not rectified by the dealer after the vehicle has been returned on four occasions. That does not satisfy the description of a lemon at all. For a variety of reasons-I have outlined the main ones-the Opposition will not support this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clause proposed to be added (Senator Haines's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.
