TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Newman, I draw attention to the fact that this is the honourable senator's first speech in this chamber. I ask that the normal courtesies be extended to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can have been few senators standing as I am today who have not done so with great pride coupled with humility. I am grateful that my Party chose me to replace Senator Peter Rae and I look forward to the challenge eagerly and with great enthusiasm. The Senate generally does not receive great publicity, but from the few short weeks I have spent here I have already seen first-hand how valuable it is in its constitutional roles of representing the States and as a House of review. I have already taken my place on an Estimates Committee and on the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I believe that the useful work that can be done in both these places is not widely enough understood outside the Senate. I must pay tribute to the work of my predecessor, who has now become a Minister in the Tasmanian Government. His time in the Senate was distinguished by his work to ensure the preservation of the rights of the States, his work regarding quangos, and his committee work which helped to bring about the National Companies and Securities Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe it is customary in this place to pay tribute to one's spouse. But in fact my selection for the Senate places me in a very select group. Only two other women have followed their husbands into the Federal Parliament, Doris Blackburn and Dame Enid Lyons. Dame Enid Lyons, in following her husband into the Federal Parliament, made history by being the first Australian woman in the House of Representatives and the first woman to be a member of the Executive Council. She, too, was a Tasmanian and followed a husband who had served his country well. My husband has served his country with honour, first as an Army officer, including active service in battalions in Malaya and Vietnam, and then for eight years as a Federal Minister. As I look across the chamber at the Ministers opposite, I can already see the toll which high office takes in this country. It took its toll on my husband's health and forced his retirement. I am proud to have been selected as a senator for Tasmania and the example which my husband set of service to his electorate, his State and his country will be always before me. I hope I can one day claim the love and respect which his constituents came to hold for him.

Predominantly my Tasmanian constituents are miners, fishermen, tourism and forestry workers, farmers and farm labourers, and people who work in small businesses and factories. They are not necessarily the people one would expect to send five Liberal members and five Liberal senators to Canberra. But they have been doing that now for ten years. And why are they doing it? It is well known that Tasmanians are very politically aware. They would need to be! They have more politicians per head than any other State in Australia. But they expect a lot of their politicians and they keep a close eye on them. They expect to have ready access to them and they expect to see and hear from them regularly. They are also extremely sophisticated as voters. They enjoy a State system of multi-member electorates, and a system of voting which encourages the representation of various views at the same time as allowing a wholesale change of membership of both major parties while returning the Government to office, as happened recently. These sophisticated voters, after years of voting Labor in both State and Federal elections, have changed to my Party and stayed there for over a decade.

Tasmanians sometimes feel themselves to be `the Irishmen' of the nation-the butt of the nation's jokes. Tasmanians are frequently thought of as different from the rest of Australia. But as an adopted daughter of Tasmania and very proud to be so, having lived throughout Australia and overseas, I can assure the Senate that in many respects they are very representative of the men and women of our nation. In the provincial cities, the country towns and country areas, there are citizens whose attitudes and aspirations very closely resemble those of my Tasmanian constituents. They may be regarded as conservative. They have a strong belief in the family, in their right to work and reap the reward, and in helping their neighbour. They are concerned about defence and in the education of their children. They are concerned about the conservation of their State in a balanced manner. They largely work in small businesses and on the farms, and they are worried at the direction we are headed.

My Party stands for the free citizen-his initiative, understanding and acceptance of responsibility. My Party rejects the doctrine of the all-powerful state. My Party believes that improved living standards depend on high productivity which can only be achieved by free and competitive enterprise. We believe in the citizen's freedom to worship, to think, to speak, to choose, to be ambitious and independent, to acquire skills, to seek and earn rewards. When we consider the movement throughout the country towns and rural areas of Australia for a new Australia based on these aspirations, one thing is clear. These are the aspirations of my constituents. This is why Tasmanians continue to support my Party. Contrary to the belief that Tasmanians are `different', it is very evident that they are typical of `non-metropolitan' Australia. In many ways they have shown the way to the rest of Australia in rejecting the socialist alternative.

The welfare state does not know best. Australia was settled and established by people who had to battle to make their way and who expected to enjoy the fruits of their labour. They expected to take responsibility for themselves and their families, and we here are probably all old enough to remember old-timers who were too proud to accept assistance either from their friends or from the Government-even when they should have done so. But where is that attitude now? In some parts of Australia we have a generation or more of people who have grown up expecting the world to provide them with a living. What sort of pioneers would they have made? What sort of nation would they have produced? We have fathers who will not provide for their own children, legitimate or illegitimate. We have community groups who once would have raised the money for their project but who now automatically go to government for funds without making any attempt to help themselves. We have industries which automatically look to government for subsidies to keep them from the cold wind of competition.

The nation has been gradually encouraged to live beyond its means. As taxpayers we all complain about the burden of taxation. An industry has grown up to feed on the nation's desire to pay as little tax as possible. It's not just the wealthy who avoid taxation. Avoidance embraces a wide span of our community. Measures had to be introduced to try to deal with small contractors, especially in the building industry, who were operating in the cash economy. The weekend builder continues to thrive. The farm labourer prefers `cash behind the barn' to award rates and taxation.

The heavy involvement of government in all our lives inevitably leads to heavy taxation, which in turn leads to dishonesty, avoidance and evasion. We have come to accept as normal that government should be involved in so many areas. For too many years we have believed that if the end was justifiable it was desirable that government was involved. I ask: Why? Why must it always be government? Are we not an educated and civilised people? If a desirable end is attainable, can it not be attained by community groups, industry groups or individuals without the expensive hand of government being introduced? Should we not have been saying two things loudly and clearly for years: Is this legislation really necessary? Is this expenditure really justifiable?

Government interference and the burden of taxation, which inevitably go hand in hand, must surely have been less if the legislators and the nation had been automatically asking these questions, instead of automatically assuming that government knows best. It would also have been less if politicians had not been encouraged to buy their votes at an ever-increasing price. Pork-barrelling has become too expensive for us to afford any more, especially when it appears that nothing which is handed out can ever be taken back.

What are the unavoidable duties of government? The primary duty of any government must be to see that its citizens are protected from external aggression and internal violence. In times of peace no nation ever wants to spend on defence, but the lessons of history teach us that to prevent aggression a nation must be seen by any potential aggressor to be strong. As any housewife knows, a small budget, if well spent, can be more productive than a bigger budget wasted. I am convinced that the money now being spent on defence, with good housekeeping, could see us better protected than we currently find ourselves. Throughout our history we have believed that we must have powerful friends to supplement our own efforts to protect ourselves. It disturbs many Australians today to see members of the Government take actions which would diminish our friendship with our allies. With the ANZUS Treaty in jeopardy at the hands of our New Zealand neighbours and sympathetic members of the Australian Labor Party, with recurring difficulties with our most powerful Asian neighbour, Indonesia, I await with concern the publication of the Dibb report.

The reliance we place on our allies and our ability to go it alone will all be matters which I expect will be addressed in the Dibb report and I therefore do not intend to enter into speculation on those areas here. But fundamental to our defence capability will be the use we make of the money allocated to defence. The big ticket items will be heavily dependent upon the future direction after Dibb. The training of the men and women needed to operate these `big ticket' items is a continuing matter and also a large cost item in any defence budget. The part which must frighten all who know the implications is the alarming wastage rate we are suffering of middle-ranking officers and non-commissioned officers who have had up to eight years training and who are being lost to the services after only a few years service. The cost of continually retraining their replacements is a terrible waste of scarce resources. For operational reasons, serious and urgent attention must be given to deal with the causes of this wastage.

`Conditions of service' is a phrase which is bandied about but given very little attention. It does not seem as worthy of headlines as battleships and bombs. However, as one young man told me the other day: `I left the Army when my six years were up because it's not a job for a married man.' That young man was a driver who had been trained to drive everything one can drive. The Army must then start again with another youngster and lose him once he acquires a wife. Why is it not a job for a married man? Of course, separations are an integral part of service life; and because they are integral, no effort should be spared to minimise and compensate for the problems caused to domestic life by defence service.

There are still over 90 Australian servicemen living in houses without a hot water system or sharing a communal laundry without a hot water system. The Department of Defence has assessed 13,147 married quarters as being sub-standard; this in fact is over half of the total married quarters. Barracks for single men which were temporary in the 1950s and should be condemned and torn down are still in use. The funds which were allocated earlier this year are too low to help today's service families and will never be sufficient to catch up with the need. Housing areas are frequently located in areas which are unattractive to locals. Little effort is made to improve the locale or to provide and maintain attractive housing areas. With the heavy involvement of the Department of Housing and Construction in the provision of service homes, there is little hope of providing attractive and adequate housing for our service families at a price the nation can afford. The average cost of a service home taken over the whole of Australia is $97,500. I realise that this includes high cost housing in inaccessible areas. A private company has offered to build project homes in groups of five or more at a price of less than $20,000. This, perhaps, is a graphic example of the need to avoid wastage of what funds are available. Is it any wonder that our married quarters are inadequate in number and sub-standard in quality?

With frequent removals, every Army family stands to lose. They lose because any allowance payable is always lagging behind actual costs and because the need for new curtains, new carpets, new school uniforms and books just is not co-vered by the allowances. The heartbreak of damage and theft during removals and the problems of children adjusting into new schools are simply not being compensated for. Where they can be assessed in financial terms, allowances at least should keep abreast of costs. These are only a few of the matters of concern in the area of conditions of service which support the young man's claim that it is not a job for a married man.

We have just had a big splash with a $2.5m advertising campaign for reserve recruiting. That campaign has been stopped. The target was 26,500 men and women in the Army Reserve by 30 June 1986. The Army Reserve currently stands at 23,722 personnel. After nine months and $2.5m we have had a net loss of 547 personnel. Those figures are the raw or gross figures. The effective strength of reserve units is considerably less. It would be very instructive for the Government to tell us what are the effective figures, what is the figure which each unit regards as being its effective strength of members on the books who actually turn up for training. We have a very worrying morale problem throughout the Services in both the regular and reserve forces. A re-allocation of the defence budget to place more emphasis on retaining the men and women we train is urgently needed.

I turn now to another area of true government responsibility-the protection of the rule of law and the preservation of the Constitution of the Australian Commonwealth. Despite the conventions concerning maiden speeches, I have to say that this Government seems to have a fine contempt for the rule of law. It is a matter of great concern to me, and obviously to many people in Australia, that an attempt to limit the rights of the citizen before the law is now being pushed through the Parliament as a Bill of Rights. It is a mockery and a tragedy. A citizen's rights are being limited by this Bill. Under this legislation the citizen will also be prevented from having legal representation, from knowing the nature of the complaint against him, and from appeal to the courts. This Bill is, of course, yet to be debated by the Senate. I think perhaps the Government has underestimated the opposition to this Bill which is to be found throughout the nation. People everywhere are angry that the citizen's right to the rule of law is being eroded by government, whose duty it is to protect it.

As a senator, I cannot fail to express my deep concern at the increasing trend of the Government to manipulate the Constitution to its centralist advantage. The progress of this nation to nationhood was long and rocky, and bought at great price by the colonies, which saw the need to go into the 20th century as one nation. In order to get the agreement of all the States compromises were reached and the Constitution as finally agreed gave protection to the role of the constituent bodies who formed the Federation. I remind the Senate that Australia is a federation and that, no matter how inefficient a federal system can be, it is the system that governments have to work with. Only last week the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, was visiting Tasmania and telling Tasmanians that if the stance of the State Governments did not change the Commonwealth would consider overriding the State.

It is not just the governments of Tasmania and Queensland which have spoken out over their concern on the directions being taken by the centralist government in Canberra. The Premier of Western Australia, Mr Burke, told the Perth Press Club after his election recently that `decisions were being taken in Canberra without consultation and without proper appreciation of the problems faced by individual States'. He said:

Federalism will become the dominant issue before the turn of the century in political circles and it will cause great trauma unless people of goodwill at all levels are able to address problems with a little less self-interest.

The Commonwealth Government's recent tendency to misuse its foreign affairs power to overcome the rights of State governments is a matter of great concern. It may not be widely known outside Tasmania, because the dams debate received such one-sided reporting on the mainland, that many Tasmanians who were against the dam closed ranks with the Tasmanian Government when the issue became one of whether the decision should be taken in Canberra or in Hobart.

From the beginning of Federation this country has required government involvement in education. Fierce have been the battles over whether that means education for all. I fear that they are not yet behind us. The increasing involvement by Federal governments in education-an area which has largely been a State responsibility-presents us with problems. Formerly, the States received their funds and distributed them as they saw fit and were answerable to their electorates. Increasingly, Federal governments decided, often for laudable reasons, that funds should be tied for specific purposes. We have now nearly reached the stage where Federal mother knows best and the States are irrelevant.

It is desirable that certain basic standards of achievement should be set by the States for all Australian children, and such matters as a uniform starting age for the children in a mobile society would be valuable. But I question the need for the Commonwealth to be reaching down into each school in the land and to tie up valuable resources into constant evaluations and accountability procedures. It is not the proper role for the Commonwealth. Let the States monitor their schools, government and non-government. It is they who are best able to judge the needs of their own States and who are most directly accountable to their constituents. It is the Commonwealth's role to see that the taxpayers' education dollar is spent equally on every child, regardless of race, sex, religion or preference for non-government education.

I turn now to an area of government responsibility which has become such a large part of the Federal Budget and which is arousing such a concerned and continuous debate-social security. Government must look after those who cannot look after themselves. But I quote from Dame Enid Lyons's maiden speech made in the House of Representatives in September 1943:

In the matter of social security one thing stands out clearly in my mind. Such things are necessary in order that the weak shall not go to the wall, that the strong may be supported, that all may have justice. But we must never so blanket ourselves that those fine national qualities of which I have spoken shall no longer have play. I know so well that fear, want and idleness can kill the spirit of any people. But I know too that security can be bought at too great a cost-the cost of spiritual freedom. How, then, may we strike a balance?

That question faces us today with even greater force. In 1943 the tax paid by the citizen was 19 per cent of an average wage and that was in wartime, with all its expenses. Today it is 24 per cent. In 1943 the social security vote was 16 per cent of the Budget. Today it is 26 per cent. We must support the aged, the invalids, the unemployed and the children whose fathers fail to support them. As a founder of two women's shelters and a former practitioner in the family law area, I well understand the problems of disintegrating families. But is it right that in the Family Law Act we actively encourage the courts to allow for the eligibility for benefits to be taken into account in determining maintenance payments? Should we not support families in another way? Should not spouses support their own families? Should not the government see to it that they do? Children, whether legitimate or illegitimate, must be raised above the poverty line. But the cost of doing so should primarily be that of the parents, and only in the last resort, not the first resort, should it be paid for by the taxpayer.

This is only one area of the social security system which is giving concern. It is a constant topic of conversation outside the political world. People realise the need to protect the weak, but there is an increasing sense of alarm at the growing burden. Already, 23.1 per cent of the population are eligible for concessional medical fees, and that does not include all pensioners and all unemployed people. In 1970 that figure was 9.4 per cent. Only 10 years ago it was still approximately half of today's percentage. On the other hand, people throughout the nation are aware of cases of fraud and cases of double-dipping. While figures are bandied about as to the total amount of fraud, and they all vary, the fact remains that there are people ripping off the system.

My own experience would not be unusual when as a farmer I often had great difficulty in recruiting casual labour. I paid award rates, deducted tax and kept proper records. People on government pensions or benefits, as well as the people who wanted to evade taxation, were not prepared to accept work on those conditions. Other industries employing casual employees have similar experiences. Whether we have the Australia Card or whether we have an improvement in the taxation file system, some method must be found to reduce the misuse of the system.

We on our side of the chamber may be painted as hard-hearted reactionaries, but I remind the Senate that it was Liberal-Country Party governments that introduced many of the benefits which are in place today. My concern is that it seems to have become unfashionable to suggest that elimination of waste, reduction of misuse and careful welfare housekeeping are desirable and attainable. It is the taxpayers of Australia who foot the bill, and we cannot afford what we do not earn.

The Tasmanian miners, fishermen, forestry workers, farm labourers and people who work in small businesses and factories recognise that there are some jobs which government does for which they must pay. They must pay for defence, the enforcement of the law, the education of their children and the protection of the weak. But increasingly they are getting angry. They are rebelling against governments which know best, which spend their money as if it belonged to government, not the people. There is a vast surge of people outside who want to be left alone to run their lives, their families, their small businesses and farms without government interference which distorts everything and without having to pay for a massive bureaucracy which inevitably goes hand in hand with big government. Our big government is dominated by an overstrong union movement and together they have taken this country into the largest deficit and the highest interest rates in this country's history-factors which will send our farmers and small businesses broke and remove all chance of our young families owning their own houses and our needy and our aged citizens living in dignity. If ever there were reasons for doubting that `Big Brother knows best', there are good reasons now.

Mr President, I have tried to make my maiden speech a review of the areas which I believe are crucial to the good government and the future of our country. There are, of course, other areas which also are important to us all but which I have not touched upon today. We have certain areas of government, however, which are absolutely vital for the survival of our way of life. Our defence, our federal system of justice, the education of our children and the protection of our needy are surely considered basic by us all. In my future service in the Senate they are areas to which I will give particular attention. They are areas which I know concern my constituents in Tasmania. We must never forget that whatever we do in this chamber affects the lives of our fellow Australians. It is with humility that I pledge myself to their service. I thank honour- able senators for their courtesy.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Clauses 46 to 47-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 38, clause 46, before paragraph (a), insert the following paragraph:
`(aa) by omitting from sub-section (1) `3 years' and substituting `7 years';'.
(5) Page 39, clause 47, paragraph (b), proposed new sub-section 79 (6), leave out ``3 years'', insert ``7 years''.

The amendments to clauses 46 and 47 of the Trade Practices Revision Bill are directed at extending the time which can elapse between some person recognising that he or she has in some way been wronged by somebody under the trade practices legislation and the commencing of an action. The main reason for moving the two amendments together is that they are both basically similar. The first amendment proposes that the time allowed for bringing civil action in the case of a wrong under the Trade Practices Act shall be seven years instead of three years, as is the case with the Act as it stands. The second amendment allows for the penalties associated with the wrong also to be brought into force for a period of up to seven years after the wrong has been discovered, rather than just the three-year period which is proposed by the Government.

One might well ask why one should want to extend that period. Basically, all of our normal statute of limitation requirements are in fact for seven years. In this case, to allow only three years puts a distinct limitation on people wishing to bring any type of action under the Trade Practices Act. That is why I have moved my amendments. No real administrative burden is put upon anybody by this requirement. Under other legislation, medical and tax records have to be maintained for a period of seven years. This means that material available at the end of three years would still be available at the end of seven years for handling any defence that may be raised by a company that may have been thought to have defaulted.

To date, in most States where there is legislation covering litigation under their trade practices or consumer injury legislation, the statute of limitations is, in fact, six years. In New South Wales and Victoria there is also the provision that if material facts arise after that period people will have one year from the date at which those facts became available or became reasonably knowable to them in which to start litigation. It may not be possible to demonstrate a scientific link in three years. That is one of the reasons why I have taken up this issue.

This is particularly so with pesticides. It has taken up to four or five years to establish the relation between the withdrawn morning sickness preparation Debendox and birth defect cases in the United States of America. Injuries may be latent and persons may not be aware of them, as in the case of asbestosis. I know that the Government may respond that under this Act people in fact will have three years only from the time at which an injury becomes known. The fact is that that person may not be able, at the time of crisis when the injury becomes known, to connect it with a particular product. Indeed, this is the main point for my believing that in this area we should follow what I believe is normal practice in the rest of Australian law and we should have at least a seven-year period. A person may not be able to identify who was responsible for any loss through injury. The commercial transactions and arrangements which happen in the case of certain products may make it very difficult to know that.

Particularly relevant today is the case of the Dalkon shield. The Dalkon shield is an intra-uterine birth control device, or an IUD, made of plastic. It is oval in shape, with small fins extending from the right and left sides, and a tail string to facilitate its proper placement and removal. In fact, the Dalkon shield was developed in the 1960s and initially was marketed by the Dalkon Corporation, which sold about 27,000 of these devices before it sold the rights to A. H. Robins. Some years afterwards, between 1971 and 1974, a number of injuries were noted that were associated with the Dalkon shield, particularly because of various changes that had been made to the product such as the addition of copper and copper sulphate to the plastic material.

Because of various processes that the A. H. Robins company followed, it was not until 1974 that certain injuries were sheeted home to that product. The facts about the wicking properties of the multi-filament string which was used to put the IUD in place and to remove it really emerged only some years after the event. A. H. Robins had collected all of its internal documents on bacteria conduction matters in 1974 and had withheld them from the courts. This meant that a period of at least four years went by before anything could be done.

Liability for importers under the Trade Practices Act arose only in 1978. Hence, very few Dalkon shield actions can be brought in Australia under the Trade Practices Act. However, if they could have been people would not have had the fact base that had been built up in the United States. Hence they could not have carried on their cases and under this area of the Act the statute of limitations would have protected the company from prosecution. Aboriginal women in South Australia have been injected with depo-provera. They may not realise the link if they suffer various problems as a result of those injections-a link that has been recognised overseas. This situation exists now. What is the Government doing about it?

While laboratory tests may lead to the removal of products from the market-place, it may take quite a while for their effect upon humans to be established. Some laboratory tests in the United States have been shown to be fraudulent. Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories had some real difficulties in saying that its chemicals were safe when tests pointed in the opposite direction; and this came out in the courts after a period longer than three years. The facts showed that there was a link between exposure to those chemicals and injury. Such evidence was not available within three years. Under the Act such an injury would be recognised, but the fact that one needs to tie it to a product has not been recognised. That is a real deficiency. The medical profession might tend not to believe the victims in these cases, and it would be very difficult for the consumer or the sufferer in those cases to bring court cases to effective fruition. I suggest to both the Opposition and the Government that it is only natural justice that we should allow a reasonable amount of time for actions to be brought in each of these cases. The seven year period which has been recognised in other areas of the law should be the recognised and reasonable delay allowed for people seeking redress under these provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — As Senator Vigor has said, this amendment would extend the period for a consumer taking action against a manufacturer or importer under the Trade Practices Act from three years to seven years and would also extend the period for prosecutions to be brought in relation to a contravention of Part V. The three-year limit in section 74j conforms with the time limit under section 82 for bringing an action for damages in respect of a contravention of Division 1 of Part V and the proposed limit under section 79 for commencing prosecutions in respect of such contraventions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government believes that that three-year limit in section 74j is adequate, especially as the three years does not begin to run until the consumer first becomes aware or, as Senator Vigor acknowledged, ought reasonably to have become aware that the goods did not comply with the relevant warranty. There is an outside limit of 10 years, so that the action has to be brought within 10 years of the original supply of goods to the consumer. We believe that is basically a fairly generous time frame so far as the affected consumer is concerned. We believe that the three-year time limit is adequate not only in relation to section 74j but also in relation to the prosecution provision in proposed section 79. There the current limit, as has been said, will be increased from one year. That time limit was proposed in the Green Paper and widely accepted. The Trade Practices Commission certainly supports the Government amendment.

The particular reason why a seven-year time limit is not considered appropriate in relation to prosecutions is the hardship that would be caused to a defendant in formulating a defence to such a criminal prosecution after such a long period. As to the justification for extending it to seven years in respect of civil litigation and civil liability, it ultimately comes down to a matter of judgment as to how long is a reasonable period, bearing in mind not only the interests of the consumers but also the reasonable and legitimate interests of business in having some certainty and there being an end at some time to the prospects of litigation.

One can well acknowledge the force of what Senator Vigor has said about latent defects that might show up and injuries being caused as a result of the intake of some good or access to some good some time before and one not being aware of that causal connection. One can appreciate in particular the force of some of the examples he has given of that phenomenon at work in various places around the world in recent years. I simply say to him that for latent defects or latent injuries any time period is necessarily arbitrary. Senator Vigor may be able readily to find cases where the seven-year time frame he indicates is itself arbitrary in denying a remedy to someone in respect of whom a defect has shown up eight or nine years after the event. In that respect it becomes a matter for argument and judgment as to what the appropriate time limit should be.

Given the clarity of the rule that time begins to run only after the injury is known or ought reasonably to have been known; given the fact that there is an outside limit of up to 10 years from the time of supply of the original goods; given the needs not only of consumers but also of business; and given the practice that prevails rather erratically as far as statutes of limitations are concerned, where it is by no means clear that the six years that one usually has from the accrual of a cause of action is any more generous than the provision in the way it has been written in the Trade Practices Revision Bill-given all those considerations, the Government believes that the choice it has made is appropriate. We are comforted in that respect by the reaction we had from all relevant potential interests to the floating of that particular proposal in the Green Paper two years ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vigor raised the question of the Dalkon shield. I imagine that the injury referred to by Senator Vigor would have occurred by reason of the fact that the intra-uterine device engendered-if that is the right term-infertility. It could be quite a period of years before this injury-if that is a proper definition in accor-dance with the legislation-could be known. It may be beyond the three years laid down in the Trade Practices Revision Bill. Under those circumstances it seems reasonable that a person ought to have available some remedy for the type of advice that is given.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been indicated clearly in papers in professional journals that a large percentage of those people attending for in vitro fertilisation treatment in the United Kingdom did so by reason of infertility caused by tubal occlusion and that the majority of those cases resulted from `contraceptive' advice given by the medical profession or family planning associations, to have IUDs inserted, or to have an abortion, or from the provision of contraceptives enabling a promiscuous lifestyle leading to sexually transmitted disease. If infertility emerges arising from that advice, surely the persons who adopted that advice from the professionals ought to have available some remedy. As I indicated, it would be unlikely that the results of that advice would be known within three years. I did not raise this question-Senator Vigor did-but I think it is a matter that the Committee should take into consideration.

On a different question, I take the opportunity to ask the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) whether there is anything in this legislation or in any of the amendments, either adopted or proposed, which would enable the rather un-Australian type of litigation that may develop in the United States of Ame-rica to develop in this country. I refer to propo-sals that there ought to be available in Australia suits for wrongful birth or wrongful life. I raise that as a very serious matter because I believe that very few persons in Australia would regard this particularly un-Australian type of suit as appropriate. Indeed, many people in North America regard it as particularly inappropriate. I wonder whether anything in this Bill, or any of the amendments made or proposed to the legislation would enable such suits to be taken in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — On Senator Harradine's latter question, I believe the answer is clearly no. All that is essentially involved here is a recasting of the existing common law duty of care, but giving it statutory force and extending its range a little in terms of this concept of fitness for purpose and generally in other ways giving a variety of other protections to consumers. There is nothing I can see in the Bill that would in any way give aid, comfort or nourishment to the kind of adventurous litigation which has become the norm-and many people would say regrettably-in the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the first point Senator Harradine made in support of Senator Vigor's arguments about latent defects, all I can say is that it is really a matter of balance and judgment as to how one weighs the chances of these sorts of things occurring against the risks of uncertainty that would be involved for business if this time period became the norm. I suppose it is always possible for Parliament to legislate to extend a period of limitation or a time restriction of the kind contained here and do so for some specific subject matter that comes up and seems to cry out for a remedy of this kind. I suppose if Parliament were to do so we would get the usual yowls about retrospective legislation and changing liabilities that did not previously exist. I am not sure that those yowls would have much force when one is talking about a purely technical defence that is available and would thus be removed. I do not particularly want to open up that mare's nest, except to say that if a case of overwhelming force should subsequently appear, crying out for a remedy and the removal of the restriction that is contained here, that argument would then be considered on its merits. The general policy must be one that is not quite as generous to potentially afflicted consumers as Senator Vigor would want.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with some disappointment because I believe that my proposal is eminently reasonable and in the interests of all Australians.
—You believe that about all your proposals.

—That is why I am in Parliament. I am here to represent and help my constituents. I believe that the Minister has such a case that needs special legislation-and it is the one I raised by way of example, the Dalkon shield. For some time I have been trying to get litigation in place to handle dangerous and hazardous products on the market, and in fact I will try to put up next week a private member's Bill to this effect. The major problem we have with the Dalkon shield is the period over which information about the shield has become publicly available. In fact today is a very important date for the Dalkon shield. It is the last day in the United States of America on which it will be possible to put a claim against the company, A. H. Robins, which made the shield, because that company has gone to ground and is hiding itself behind the United States' very generous bankruptcy laws. This will leave a large number of Australian women completely unable to claim. Because of Senator Evans's statement about the possibility of a really important case coming up which requires this type of legislation, I will seek leave to have a notice incorporated in Hansard-I have not had the chance to show it to the Minister because I had not intended to incorporate it-which has been put out by A. H. Robins and which says that today's date, 30 April, is the last day on which claims for injury may be filed as a result of the use of the Dalkon shield.

SPEECH.PARA: The Dalkon shield was introduced into Australia in the middle of the period when the difficulties were appearing in the United States. It continued to be sold in Australia for up to three years after it had been positively proven to be harmful to people in the United States. How do we differ from them? I believe there is real international banditry involved here, and I seek leave to incorporate the notice which shows that a number of Australians will be disadvantaged by the decisions made in the United States courts which will mean they cannot pursue the makers of the Dalkon shield.
Leave granted.
The notice read as follows-
IMPORTANT NOTICE-THE DALKON SHIELD

The manufacturer of the Dalkon Shield-an intra-uterine birth control device (I.U.D.) available during the early to mid 1970s-is advising women who may have used the device of the procedure for filing a claim if they may have been injured or may suffer injury in the future from use of the product.
A U.S. judge has established a date after which no further claims of injury may be filed as a result of use of the Dalkon Shield. That date is April 30, 1986.

If you intend to assert a claim against the manufacturer of the Dalkon Shield, you must do so on or before April 30, 1986. This applies to people who may have been injured because of use of the Dalkon Shield, who may have used the Dalkon Shield but not yet experienced an injury, or may have been injured because of another person's use of the Dalkon Shield.
To make a claim, you do not need a lawyer.
You should send a letter or postcard with your full name and complete address with a simple signed statement that you are making a claim to:
Dalkon Shield
P.O. Box 444
Richmond
Virginia 23203 U.S.A.
You will then receive a questionnaire which must be completed and received by the Court by July 30, 1986.
For further information, please contact Peter Brownlee or Sue Harris at Burson-Marsteller Pty Limited on (02) 27 3571 or Max Miller at A. H. Robins Pty Limited on (02) 534 1000.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would urge the Government and the Opposition to support this amendment because the period of seven years does not put any extra load on the companies concerned. They have statutory requirements to keep their records for seven years, so mounting a defence is not a problem. It is not a three-year period, which is a statutory requirement under the taxation laws, it is seven years. Therefore, all the records must be there. I believe that this will not put any extra load on the corporate sector and it will be much better for the consumers. I believe that seven years is the optimum figure for this particular statute of limitation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Vigor's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the second reading stage I raised an issue to which the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) responded. I thank him for that response. I accept the points that he made with regard to the lack of a conspiracy. I generally find conspiracies very difficult to uphold because of lack of organisation to get them running. However, I would like to raise again the question of whether the Government sees this Bill as in some way appropriating money. I refer here to division 165, `Administrative', sub-division 3, `Other Services', of the Attorney-General's Department estimates under which the money was appropriated for the purposes of clause 73. When the principal clause, clause 170, came before the House of Representatives, there was no accompanying message from the Governor-General. My last question on this is in response to the basic defence of the Minister that this was an abundance of caution. I question precisely why any caution at all is required, let alone an abundance of it. As I understand it, section 53 of the Constitution is not justiciable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Macklin has asked me very good questions. I can see their point and do not have any difficulty with them. I think, with the utmost respect to the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel, whose views on these matters I respect, that there has been not only an abundance of caution, but an overabundance of caution in this matter. I have a lot of difficulty in seeing this Bill properly describable as an appropriation Bill or one in respect of which the provisions of section 53 are to be regarded as applicable. There is nothing hanging on this. The only point I make, apart from Senator Macklin's reputation for perseverance, is in the sense that it is clear that, whatever the other kind of Bill this is, it is not an appropriation Bill appropriating money for the ordinary annual services of the Commonwealth such that it would be beyond the capacity of the Senate to amend it. Therefore some of the more comprehensive conspiracy theories that were being advanced earlier disintegrate, I believe, on closer analysis. I shall let Senator Macklin revel in his triumph in this matter. The closest thing I can offer to a total capitulation on this issue is that I will raise it through the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) with the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel because I think it reaches the point of absurdity. This has been in accordance with past practice and I do not in any way offer any critical comment about parliamentary counsel in this respect. They have been behaving as they have always behaved, but sometimes that might not be the most sensible way to behave. There are occasions when things ought to be done for the first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to express the Opposition's total rejection of this legislation and its continued opposition to it. In view of the very lengthy debates that have been held on this Bill and the fact that we got a bonus of two second reading debates because of the Government's splitting this legislation after it had already been in the Senate for some time, I do not propose to make a speech again, but I express the Opposition's total opposition to it as a whole. At the Committee stage the Opposition hoped that the Australian Democrats might support some of our amendments which would at least have ameliorated the increased burdens that the legislation places on the business and professional community and the vast increase in ministerial discretions of an almost unheard of kind in this day and age. However, because the Democrats have not supported our attempts to oppose this Bill, and because they continue to support this type of legislation, and in view of the lengthy debates and the fact that we are about to break for lunch I will not be calling a division on behalf of the Opposition to register yet again our opposition to this measure.
