QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and arises from his interview by Michael Schildberger this morning and his justification of the prices and incomes accord and the benefits that he says that has brought to Australia-after which, in response to a question, Senator Button said:

QUESTION.PARA: I think anybody who thinks about it recognises that gradually we have to free up some of the provisions of the accord.
He went on to say:
I see that as a necessary development into the future, and I think a lot of other Ministers do too, and I think the ACTU would.

I welcome that statement from the Minister. I ask him whether he could indicate to the Senate what areas of the accord he thinks can or should be freed up. I ask him also whether this is under consideration by the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those honourable senators who were paying attention at Question Time about 10 days ago will recall that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle asked me a question on a similar matter. In the course of that answer I said much the same sort of thing as I said on the Schildberger program this morning. I think that the important points about what I said this morning are as follows: First of all, I was asked what areas of the accord I thought should be freed up in terms of wage flexibility. I declined to answer that question because, as I said, it is a matter for consideration by the Government as a whole. I also made the point that it is a matter for consideration in conjunction with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I think that those two points are important because the distinction between this Government and the former Fraser Government on the question of wage policy is that there is now a prices and incomes policy in place in this country. That policy has been arrived at by a process of negotiation with the trade union movement.

ANSWER.PARA: Nothing in the statements which have emanated from the present Leader of the Opposition has suggested that that policy would ever continue into the future. In fact, in his own words, he predicts five years of industrial chaos if the wages policy which the Opposition was considering a few months ago were adopted. Not only is the present Leader of the Opposition in the process of predicting industrial chaos if the Opposition's former policies were to be adopted; one has only to look at the record of 1982 to see what sort of industrial chaos we had then in terms of levels of industrial disputation and to see the level of wage increases in 1982 compared with the moderate wage increases which have taken place since.

The position which I adopted this morning was simply to say that this matter has to be constantly under consideration by the Government-and it is. In answer to a question in the House of Representatives on 15 April this year, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations made a point very similar to the point which I now make. In the course of that answer he quoted from the report of the examiner for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is starting to sound like a dorothy dixer.
—I must say, in deference to all honourable senators, that dorothy dix questions sometimes have a degree of stupidity about them. That is true about the question just asked of me.
—Ask Senator Maguire. He knows.

—I am not saying for a moment that dorothy dix questions asked by members of this Government have a stupid quality about them, but that is the way dorothy dix questions are sometimes characterised outside this Parliament. That is the characterisation which I put on Senator Chaney's question. Mr Willis quoted from the OECD conclusions about the Australian wages system, which said:

ANSWER.PARA: While one would expect a flexible wage structure to aid labour market adjustment it is not clear how important this is in practice. Even in a situation of a relatively inflexible industrial wage structure labour mobility may occur smoothly on the basis of expected life-time earnings and availability of job opportunities.
In a particular reference to Australia the OECD went on to say:

In countries pursuing consensus policies to achieve aggregate wage moderation care is also needed to ensure that attempts to substantially increase relative wage flexibility do not compromise this goal.

It is those sorts of factors which the Government of course has to take into account in looking to the future. I might also add that the Business Council of Australia, in expressing a view on this matter, as a result of a survey of employers, commented:
. . . the operation of the current wage fixing principles was not a major causal factor in the development of labour market skill shortages. . .

Where shortages have emerged, wage flexibility and remuneration differentials are not a major contributing factor. Accordingly, there is little justification for `freeing up' the system solely on the grounds of trying to alleviate shortages of labour in a relatively narrow range of specific occupations. . .

I have declined to answer that part of the question directed to me by Senator Chaney in respect of what areas of flexibility the Government is currently considering. I think that matter is appropriately the subject of an announcement by the Government when final conclusions have been reached. In respect of the other parts of the question, I make the comments which confirm what I said this morning and which confirm what other Ministers have said.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce is no doubt aware of car industry sales figures which indicate a downturn for sales in the first months of 1986. In light of these downturns and the uncertainty of fleet orders because of proposed changes to the Income Tax Assessment Act, will the Minister state what part of this sales downturn is attributable to the fleet sales component of these figures and when the legislation on car fringe benefits taxation will be tabled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the answer to the final part of the question is early next week at the latest. In respect of the other part of Senator Foreman's question, in a sense his question covers some points which I answered yesterday in reply to a question. I made the point then that there are a number of reasons for the downturn in car sales in the opening months of 1986. Of course, amongst those reasons is the fact that 1985 was a record year. It is believed that there was considerable pull forward into 1985 because of a variety of factors but particularly because of the introduction of unleaded petrol legislation to operate from 1 January 1986. I think that there are a number of other factors which have been adverted to in debate in the Senate.
—Interest rates.

—Interest rates undoubtedly are a factor. However, another factor is the change to the wholesale tax regime for motor vehicles which was made last year. As I have pointed out on previous occasions, it was made as a result of an Auditor-General's report which simply pointed out that over a number of years, including the years of the Fraser Government, the proper wholesale tax regime has not been implemented and the Auditor-General required that that be done. This Government acted in accordance with the Auditor-General's decision on that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, I make the point that in previous years there has, of course, been a so-called fringe benefits tax in respect of motor vehicles, but this was never effectively implemented by the previous Government. It is because of that that the Government has pursued the course which it has now adopted in terms of a fringe benefits tax and because of the very big blow-out in fringe benefits as distinct from salary or wages income which attracts the income tax provisions. All of those factors have to be taken into account.

I said yesterday that the prospect of the fringe benefits tax on cars has obviously caused some decline in car sales, some of which will be temporary and some of which will be more lasting in effect. However, in answer to Senator Foreman's question about whether one can identify at this moment the effect on the market of the fringe benefits tax, I say, as I said before, that it is not realistic to make an estimate on the proportion of that downturn which is caused by the fringe benefits tax. Of course, it has never been so. The position has always been that the effects of the fringe benefits tax are highly speculative. A lot of the factors depend-if I might lapse, contrary to my usual eloquence in these matters, into bureaucratic jargon-on behavioural effects which cannot be determined with certainty. I am sorry for that temporary lapse into professional erudition but I think that is a good way of describing the speculative nature of estimates in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a question of the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. I refer to the statement by the Minister for Health, dated 8 April 1986, in which he undertook, in relation to the drug offensive, `A commitment' at the drug summit `by all governments to funding of $100m over three years-over and above existing funding'. Can the Minister confirm the statement by Dr Blewett that the funding for the law enforcement aspects of the drug offensive-specifically the $10m for extra staff and the $7.2m for improved computer capacity-is not the same funding promised by the Prime Minister before the 1984 election and, therefore, before the drug summit, and is in fact an additional commitment?
—I will have to take that question on notice. I will give the honourable senator an answer as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of claims by some producer groups that farm wages have risen to unacceptably high levels? Further, is the Minister also aware of a call by the Deputy Opposition Leader, reported in the Brisbane Courier-Mail, for direct wage fixing between individual employers and workers? In view of the substantial evidence that many families of farm workers would live in poverty without government assistance, how does the Government view the wages spiral allegations and does the Minister agree that the policies advocated by the Deputy Opposition Leader could have disastrous consequences for the rural work force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If experience both in Australia and abroad is any guide, there is, I think, no reasonable doubt at all that the policies of the Opposition Leader would lead to higher wage outcomes than have actually taken place under the accord in the last few years, with the inevitable higher inflation and other macroeconomic effects that that would have. A number of points should be noted in regard to the earlier part of the question. Firstly, wages paid on the farm constitute about only 5 per cent of farm costs. In an indirect sense, of course, wages are a much more significant component of total farm costs because of the reason I mentioned earlier. Even though it may be superficially attractive to some people who believe that the rate of wage increases of agricultural workers may be lower under a non-centralised wage fixing policy, it follows that the wage outcomes in almost all other areas of the economy would be higher. Because wages paid off the farm have a much greater effect on total farm costs than wages paid on the farm, the net effect of that on agricultural costs would be that the Opposition Leader's policies would lead to a higher cost for agriculture than do this Government's policies. For example, in 1982-83, the last year in which the discredited former Treasurer brought down a Budget, farm costs increased by 11 per cent. That figure fell to 6 per cent in 1984-85 and it is expected that it will fall to only 3 per cent in 1986-87. So, since Mr Howard ceased to be Treasurer, the rate of increase in farm costs will have been halved every second year if the forecast is fulfilled.

ANSWER.PARA: Moreover, looking more generally at low incomes in the countryside, whether they be low farm incomes or low non-farm incomes-there is, of course, a good deal of evidence to show that income levels in smaller country towns are not distorted to the same degree as the recorded level of farm income may be-a significantly higher proportion of workers have very low incomes. In that context it is important to note that under this Government's policies-again associated with the accord-the social wage has increased. For example, since we are dealing with very low income families, the family income supplement rate paid to working families has been increased to $16 for each child. That is something which has, I expect, helped some low income farm workers who are in permanent employment, a larger number of farm workers who are in temporary or seasonal employment on farms, and also a significant proportion of people who are actually farm proprietors.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is it a fact that the world's nuclear industry apparently does not have established methods to extinguish a graphite fire such as the one in the Chernobyl nuclear plant? Is the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's reactor at Lucas Heights fitted with combustible graphite control rods similar to those at the Chernobyl plant? If not, is the control rod material combustible? In view of the age of the Lucas Heights reactor, how effective would its containment vessel be in the event of a major cooling water loss at that reactor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Full details of the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant have not yet been made available by Union of Soviet Socialist Republics authorities. However, it does seem clear, from all reports to date, that the accident involved, as Senator Mason has intimated, a fire in the graphite moderator in the core of one of the four reactors at Chernobyl. The International Atomic Energy Agency understands that there has been some melting of the core but at this stage it is not yet clear whether that is as a result of heat from the nuclear reaction itself or rather from the burning graphite in the moderator.

ANSWER.PARA: Graphite can be a problem material in nuclear reactors and its use as a moderator was the cause of the 1957 fire at the Windscale No. 1 reactor in the United Kingdom. However, British authorities were able successfully to extinguish the Windscale fire with no significant lasting consequences. I think it should be clear for those who are minded to treat the USSR event as symptomatic of what is likely to happen in nuclear reactors around the world that the particular combination of a graphite moderator with a light water-cooled design is unique to the USSR. While the United Kingdom Magnox and advanced gas-cooled reactors are graphite moderated, the coolant is gas rather than water. It is only in the USSR that one has that particular combination. It is also the case that in the United Kingdom, as elsewhere outside the USSR, there is quite an elaborate system of protection through containment buildings, which clearly was not the case with the USSR reactor.

As to possible methods for dealing with the accident at Chernobyl which Senator Mason asked about, it is difficult, in the absence of specific details of the accident, to comment on that. As I have indicated, the only previous accident of this kind was successfully handled. I understand-and there have been media reports about this-that the United States has already offered technical assistance to the USSR in relation to this accident and the USSR is also reported to be in contact with nuclear authorities in other countries.

As to the question of comparisons with the high flux Australian reactor at Lucas Heights in Australia, the situation is this: The construction of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's research reactor here is entirely different from that of power reactors at Chernobyl, with heavy water, which, of course, is not combustible, rather than graphite being used as the moderator here. The only graphite which is contained in HIFAR is a neutron reflecting layer which is outside the reactor vessel. This particular graphite layer, I am advised and verily believe, is not exposed to sufficient fast neutron flux levels or, in less technical terms, is not subject to conditions of heat and radioactivity which could conceivably cause that graphite to ignite. It also should be said about the HIFAR reactor here that its containment building does represent one of the safety systems of the HIFAR reactor and, as such, it is tested at six-month intervals to ensure its integrity. The fact that the reactor is 25 years old has no bearing on the integrity of the containment under those circumstances. The containment has been carefully maintained and, where necessary, upgraded, and in fact is more effective now, I am told, than when it was originally installed.

As to the final part of the question about loss of water coolant and HIFAR, a number of studies have been undertaken over the years to determine the consequence of a possible loss of coolant accident associated with the operation of HIFAR. These studies demonstrate that in the unlikely event of such an accident the existing HIFAR safety systems, in conjunction with the 1.6 kilometre buffer zone around the HIFAR reactor, would provide a very high level of protection to members of the public. It should also be noted in this respect, just to finish it off, that HIFAR operates at a power level of only about one three-hundredth of that of the Soviet power reactor-ours is just a research reactor; very small by comparison-and it is not a pressurised system. So anyone minded to get very excited about the Lucas Heights system by comparison with what has happened in the USSR has, I think, no basis at all for such a comparison.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry been drawn to an article in the Australian on 23 April in which Italy's top millers were reported to have been critical of the level of contamination in the Australian wool clip, and to have called for a dramatic improvement in the classing standards for the clip? Does the Minister accept these allegations of excessive contamination? Does he believe they will adversely affect the export performance of the industry? What action will the Minister consider taking in this regard? Is the Minister satisfied with the classing standards administered by the Australian Wool Board?

—I am vaguely aware of the article to which Senator Elstob referred. I am in no position to verify or refute the allegations that are contained in it. I will ask Mr Kerin whether he will ask the Australian Wool Board to investigate that specific complaint and bring back a report on it to see whether, by reasonably objective standards, it could be justified as a valid complaint. However, having said that on the specific case, the complaints about classing standards of Australian wool and contamination go back certainly for as long as I can remember and probably a good deal further than I can remember. There is nothing new about such allegations. I think it would also be generally agreed by people who follow these complaints that they have not always been justified-occasionally they may have been-and there is certainly widespread suspicion out among wool growers that such complaints are virtually ritual complaints coming from customers as part of the psychological bargaining process, I suppose. I will ask Mr Kerin to procure a report from the Wool Board on that specific complaint.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and arises from an article in the Melbourne Sun of 28 April suggesting that 38 child care centres face a money crisis. I take it from the article that there appears to be some negotiation going on between the Commonwealth and the States and that the Labor Government in Victoria seems to want the Commonwealth to take over the financial responsibility for its 38 child care centres. I ask the Minister: Has the Labor Government of Victoria approached the Commonwealth seeking the transfer of funding for its child care centres to the Commonwealth? Has the Government in Victoria threatened to close the centres should the Federal Government not take up their funding, which is at present a Victorian responsibility? What is the state of any negotiations on the matter and what are the circumstances which led to this newspaper article, an article which must have caused considerable distress to parents with children in the centres?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised I am not, but I am not aware of the article referred to by Senator Peter Baume. As for the matters raised by him, the Commonwealth Government has been approached by the Victorian Government to take over the Victorian Government pre-schools which it has run over the years. I was first approached probably two years ago on this matter. We have not agreed to do so. Neither the Victorian Government nor the Minister involved at the moment, Mrs Caroline Hogg, have threatened to close all these centres if the Commonwealth does not take over the funding, although they believe, quite wisely, I think, that there should be a rationalisation of the children's services in Victoria, as there should be in other States.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know the circumstances in which this article was written, but I will certainly look up the article and find out the circumstances in which it was written. What I do know is that in Victoria in recent weeks and months there have been several articles of this type, some of them claiming that there would be widespread closure of child care centres in Victoria if the present changes to funding were introduced. That has not happened. In fact, new centres have been opening; I have opened new centres there in recent times. There have been articles claiming that fees would rise to astronomical levels in Victoria. That has not happened. That is not to deny that we have not got a problem with some child care centres in Victoria where the costs are very high-much higher than they are in some other States.

At the moment, officers of my Department are discussing with officers of the Victorian Government and have been for some time the future of the Victorian-run centres. We have not yet reached an agreement. I suspect that some of the centres which are clearly viable may be able to be converted in the Commonwealth-State agreements. Some which are not viable-they are too small or are in inappropriate housing-may in fact not continue at all. I hope that the expansion of the children's services program in Victoria, as in other States, will pick up any backlog that is created by those circumstances. At the moment discussions are taking place. I am under no threat from the Victorian Government. I find the present Victorian Minister does not operate that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —As distinct from?

—As distinct from some others. Certainly at one stage there was an attempt in Victoria to flick pass, as it is known in Australian rules, the responsibility for the funding of these centres to the Commonwealth, but as an old rugby league player and Australian rules player I see that sort of thing coming a long way off, and it did not happen.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories. It has been reported that the Union of Christmas Island Workers has criticised the Government in recent times over the handling of the future of Christmas Island. This has caused some unease to potential investors, the inference being that the sovereignty of the island may be passed to Indonesia. Will the Minister comment on these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that some criticism has been made about the future of Christmas Island. There is understandable concern by the Union of Christmas Island Workers as well as by those from whom the Government is hoping to attract some private investment in the Island. The Government is fully committed to the long term future of Christmas Island, bearing in mind that there will be a time when the phosphate will no longer be a profitable enterprise. However, it is committed to maintaining the mining operation while it is profitable on Christmas Island, and that will be for as long as possible, as well as moving towards economically viable non-mining enterprises on the Island in lieu of the earlier activities associated with mining of phosphate. However, if statements are made which create unease amongst the workers and also amongst the future investors, the future of the island is placed in some jeopardy.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no truth, for example, in the view that the Government is interested in establishing a military base on Christmas Island, nor is there any truth in the view that Australia is interested in handing over the island to Indonesia. We would be well advised to have some confidence in the capacity of the committee which has been established to look at the complex issues about the future of the island, recognising that the Government is, as indeed the previous Government was, committed to planning for the future viability of the island. That means establishing a climate that will enable all parties concerned to be adequately catered for when the mining operations cease. To that extent any comment that places those sorts of objectives in jeopardy is to be deplored.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy and Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. With the hardening of the Australian Government's position towards Indonesia, can the Minister now inform the Senate what will happen to discussions on the joint development zone-which of course, holds such great prospects for oil exploration-which discussions were to be held in May but were cancelled yesterday by the Indonesian Government? What effects will the cancellation have on the future of Australian resource development in the area? When now is the JDZ agreement likely to be finalised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were advised yesterday that the talks scheduled for next week were not cancelled but deferred. The present expectation is that they may be resumed as early as next month. Under those circumstances I think it would be quite premature to sound the death knell to that particular co-operative exercise. It is important for Australia's long term liquid fuels energy future that we be able to explore and hopefully then develop the oil fields which are reasonably thought likely to exist in the Timor Gap area. It is very much in the interests of both countries, not just ourselves, that that exploration and hopefully development take place. I believe that over the course of the next few months it will be possible to maintain some significant progress on the particular exercise which we have been very successfully embarking on over the last year of negotiating and resolving that very difficult and sensitive issue.

ANSWER.PARA: It is clearly only on the basis that the solution to the problem is in the interests of both countries that a successful outcome will be reached. I would imagine that it is on that basis that it will be perceived, not only here in Canberra but also in Jakarta, that it is in the interests of both countries that those talks resume and that that constructive process proceed as soon as possible. It is my expectation and the Government's expectation that that is what will in fact occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of a reputed survey carried out by the Federal Opposition into the distribution of the drug offensive booklet which the Opposition claims demonstrates that the national campaign against drug abuse is a flop? Does the supposed survey represent, as South Australian Liberal Senator Vanstone is quoted as saying, a major setback for the campaign? How does this obvious attempt by the Opposition, from members of both the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, to undermine the campaign sit with the attitudes of their State colleagues such as the Premiers of Queensland and Tasmania, who have thrown their support fully behind the campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see in one of the Sydney afternoon papers yesterday a claim by Senator Vanstone that, as a result of the findings of a survey by the Opposition parties of the distribution of the drug offensive booklet, the whole project was a failure and we all ought to give up and go home, or words to that effect. The first thing I should point out is that the booklet is only part of the overall campaign, which, as Senator Crowley has said, is part of a campaign by both State governments and the Federal Government-governments of Labor, Liberal and National Party persuasion-to do something about the drug problem in this country. Also as part of that program there will be changes to the rehabilitation, treatment, education and law enforcement mechanisms which are obviously essential in the drug campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the honourable member for Gilmore, Mr Sharp, is chairman of yet another task force set up by the Opposition-the Drug Enforcement Task Force, I think it is called. It seems to me that the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is very wisely giving his back benchers something to do by setting up endless task forces which are running around the country stirring up trouble, as in this regard. It is interesting to me that from the word go Senator Vanstone and Mr Sharp seem to have been determined to do one thing and one thing only, and that is to discredit the efforts of the Federal Government and the State governments and to do everything they can to demonstrate that the State and Federal governments are failing in this regard. Senator Vanstone and Mr Sharp in this case first of all did a telephone survey. A telephone survey is notoriously unreliable in any case. The second thing they did--

TALK.START.PARA: —You ought to know. You used it in the phone-in.
—If Senator Vanstone wants to help the drug pushers in this country, for whatever reason, she can go ahead and do so; she can denigrate--
—Order! I ask the Minister to address his remarks to the Chair and to ignore the interjections.

—Mr President, through you, if the good senator opposite wants to denigrate the efforts of the State governments and the Federal Government-governments of all persuasions-in this regard and therefore help the drug pushers of this country, let her do so and let Mr Sharp, a member of the House of Representatives from New South Wales, do so.
—That is a McCarthyist approach.

—I cannot believe that I am hearing Senator Michael Baume. Senator Michael Baume, who put more people into penury than anyone else in this country, has the cheek to get up here and criticise this Government and other governments--
—I rise on a point of order. I doubt whether I need to draw it to your attention, Mr President, but the Minister has made a totally offensive remark with respect to Senator Michael Baume.
—And untruthful.
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw his remark.
—I withdraw the remark.
—I ask the Minister to ignore the interjections and answer Senator Crowley.
—I will. I would refer honourable senators opposite to Harry Truman's famous statement, but if they do not wish to remember Mr Truman's statement they should stop their silly interjections.
—You cannot remember it yourself.

—Yes, I can. Senator Chaney knows about the heat in the kitchen. The Opposition task force conducted a telephone survey of 500 people throughout this country, obviously carefully selected, because I understand from the survey and Mr Sharp's statements that task force members particularly rang people in outback areas where there is a notoriously bad postal service and postal delays. They have denigrated not only the State governments and the Federal Government but also Salmat Direct Marketing, which is distributing these documents. All I can say is this: If any government or any organisation is to distribute 5.4 million pamphlets, obviously some will go astray. The Government and the people distributing the pamphlets were aware of this and set up arrangements whereby the distribution could be monitored. The distribution has been monitored. There have been areas in which it has been drawn to the Government's attention that in fact people did not get their booklets. In those areas the efforts of the Government and Salmat supervisors have in fact ensured that those gaps have been filled. People can also ring a toll free number and the booklets will be quickly made available to them.

ANSWER.PARA: What we have here, in fact, is a highly selective survey by an Opposition group whose sole motivation seems to be to denigrate not only the effects of the distribution of this pamphlet but also the whole offensive, which I repeat is a combined effort by the Queensland Government, the Tasmanian Government and all the other State and Territory governments. In continuously denigrating this effort, instead of making constructive criticisms and suggestions as to how the situation might be improved, these Opposition members are just spending their time rubbishing and monstering the whole program. In a matter as serious as this, I think that is a stupid way to go about things.

If Senator Vanstone and Senator Michael Baume, with his vast experience in this area, wish to make constructive suggestions to the Government, I suggest that they should do so. If they do not want to deal directly with the Federal Government, why do they not make suggestions to their National Party friends in Queensland or their Liberal Party friends in Tasmania? However, they do not choose to do this. They choose to conduct phoney surveys and to set up phoney task forces. If their efforts on this task force are as accurate as their efforts were in the well-publicised task force on waste-the waste watch group-I am afraid that they will only be treated with contempt by the rest of the community.

I repeat that everybody wants an effective effort in this regard. Everybody will accept constructive criticism and a positive approach, but people will not accept the knocking and the continuous denigration that we have heard from Senator Vanstone and Mr Sharp.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order--
—If they want to continue to do this, they ought to explain to the general public in this community why they are assisting the drug pushers in the way they are.
—Order! I call Senator Chaney on a point of order.
—Mr President, the Minister has now finished his answer and sat down. My point of order was that he was debating the question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LIBYAN ACTIVITIES IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that a recent meeting of so-called liberation movements convened by and held in Libya from 15 to 18 March was attended by a Kanak delegation from New Caledonia, a West Papuan OPM delegation, a delegation from Vanuatu, a Maori delegation from New Zealand and a New People's Army delegation from the Philippines? Is he aware that, amongst other things, the conference discussed what were described as `the Kanak struggle' and `the problem of the Australian Aborigines' and declared its absolute support for the liberation movement in New Caledonia and certain other islands? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in the International Herald Tribune of 7 April 1986 that Australian intelligence sources are aware that Kanaks sent to Libya for military training have viewed demonstrations of guerrilla tactics and received weapons training? I ask the Minister whether the Government is concerned about the spread of Libyan influence in the South Pacific region. What action is it taking to curb this dangerous and destabilising situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Affairs brief I have on this subject is a couple of weeks old and may need supplementing by some further information. I can say at this stage that the Government has seen reports to the effect that an agreement has been signed establishing a so-called revolutionary committee involving Libya, the Vanua'aku Pati in Vanuatu, the Free Papua Movement and the FULK faction of the New Caledonian National Liberation Front-FLNKS. According to the reports, which were based on an article in the FLNKS weekly newspaper, Bwenando-that may subsequently have been supplemented by some other media reports-the agreement was signed in Vila and adopted at last month's conference of liberation movements in Tripoli. The information that I have, dated 14 April, is that, at that stage anyway, the Government had received no conclusive evidence in substantiation of that.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the general question of our attitude towards such developments, I can say that the Australian Government has consistently expressed the view that it would look with considerable disfavour on any activities by Libya which could provoke instability or lead to the use, or threat of use, of violence and terrorism in New Caledonia or elsewhere in the region.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REVIEW OF THE REPATRIATION HOSPITAL SYSTEM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It follows the critical comments made by Senators Macklin and Lewis after the tabling by the Minister this morning of a statement on the Review of the Repatriation Hospital System. Is there any substance to assertions that the Government seeks to fob off the responsibility for repatriation hospitals to the States, or that it is dragging its feet in implementing the review recommendations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was somewhat surprised at the criticism that was levelled by Senator Lewis following my making a statement today in respect of the future of the repatriation hospital system. The Brand report is the third such report that has been prepared by governments in the last decade. Two of the three obviously were prepared in the period of the previous conservative Government. They all came to somewhat the same conclusions about what should happen to our repatriation hospital system. Firstly, it was never the intention of this Government to fob off the repatriation hospitals on to the States, but all of those reports came to substantially the same conclusion; that is, that the rationale for separate repatriation hospitals would disappear over time. I was able recently to get unanimous agreement from the State Health Ministers to the establishment of a working party for the purpose of bringing into being an arrangement whereby the repatriation hospitals would, over time, be integrated with the State hospital systems. I was pleased to find support for that proposition from all of the political parties represented at the Australian Health Ministers Conference.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government recognises-I hope that the Senate also does-that the veteran population in the next 25 years will drop from about 600,000 to about 100,000. There will therefore be a need for the Government to take into account the demographic changes as well as the fall in the veteran population so that we are able to provide for the veterans an option which currently is not available to them in the majority of cases. That is to say, those veterans who live far removed from repatriation hospitals will be given the option of using either the repatriation or the state system when agreement is reached with the States. An interdepartmental committee will be established, comprising representatives of my Department, the Commonwealth Department of the Treasury and the States, to work towards a process whereby veterans and their spouses will have the opportunity to be admitted into State hospital systems under proper financial arrangements and in a way which will not disadvantage either the States or the Commonwealth.

It seems to me that that plan, which was a key recommendation of the Brand report, had some relationship to the position of the conservative governments, which would not bite the bullet and were afraid to make that important decision about the future of our repatriation hospital system. The States were able to see, when it was explained to them, the advantages that they would have in taking over the repatriation hospitals, perhaps in the year 2000 on an agreed arrangement whereby veterans would have the opportunity to go into a repatriation hospital or a local State hospital at the expense of the Commonwealth. That, of course, is a vital aspect of the Brand report, which has been adopted by the Government.

Another point of criticism that was made this morning by Senator Lewis was that there was no reference in my statement to very many recommendations in the Brand report. Of course, I referred only to the major recommendations in the ministerial statement, but I can inform the Senate that 61 of the 236 recommendations have already been implemented, another 136 are being implemented and the remainder require formal Government approval before action is taken. The Government is therefore committed to retaining the repatriation hospital system for as long as is necessary, to modernising and to providing it with all the facilities to carry out its obligations to veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's promise in the National Agenda for Women that the Government would appoint `a special women's health resource person to co-ordinate development of policy', that is, health policy for women. Firstly, is or was the appointment ever necessary? I ask this in light of the public comments made by the newly appointed head of the Office of the Status of Women, Ms Brooks, to the effect that everything is under control because there is adequate competent female staff in the Department of Health to undertake that task. Secondly, if the Government regards the appointment as necessary, given that five months have passed since the promise was made, when will advertisements be placed and when will an appointment be made? Thirdly, who speaks both publicly and politically for the Prime Minister on this issue of the status of women? Is it the recently appointed head of the Office of the Status of Women or the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly the case that the Department of Health has a number of senior and very competent women. In fact, the Deputy Secretary, Ann Kern, who would be known to many honourable senators opposite, is one of the more outstanding public servants and, of course, is one of the most senior women in the Commonwealth Public Service. So I think it is quite true, as Senator Vanstone's question implied, that the attention given to the development of women's health policy would be expert and sympathetic. Whether or not my colleague Dr Blewett considers it necessary to make an additional appointment to bring in some additional expertise in the development of the women's health policy is something which I shall ask him about. I am not aware of his intentions in this regard. It may well be that he is waiting until the policy has developed to a certain point and then he will judge whether it is necessary to make an additional appointment. I do not have any details about his intention in that regard, although if he has made a commitment in that direction, I am sure he will be pursuing it.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly, the area of women's health is one that has received a great deal of attention from this Government. A major national women's health conference was held in Adelaide, I think, some months ago, and it was extremely well attended not only by women in the bureaucracy whose job it is to advise government, but also by women involved in the delivery of health paramedicals, women involved in the management of community health centres, and consumers of special women's health programs. I know that my colleague Senator Rosemary Crowley, who is a health expert, was at that conference. The matter of the development of women's health policy is well under way, but whether Dr Blewett still considers it necessary to make an appointment of a special health expert to bring the policy together is something which I shall have to ask him about.

Senator Vanstone also, in a way that I did not find quite connected to the first part of her question, asked who speaks for the Prime Minister on women's policy. Perhaps Senator Vanstone is not yet totally familiar with the role of the bureaucracy in relation to policy. It is the role and the responsibility of bureaucrats at certain levels of seniority to explain government policy. It is not their role to make a political defence or explanation of government policy. I suppose that they do that most frequently within the bureaucracy in their dealings with other bureaucrats. But, from time to time, senior bureaucrats make a speech in a public forum, or they are asked questions in a public forum, and they are entitled to answer them. I am sure that Senator Vanstone was referring to the fact that some comments of a factual nature were made by Ms Brooks, who is the First Assistant Secretary in charge of the Office of the Status of Women within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, concerning matters raised by Senator Vanstone during her address to the Women's Electoral Lobby conference. That is an entirely appropriate course of action for a senior public servant to take. Matters of fact such as the appointment of a women's health adviser and the development of the proposal that State governments be asked to co-operate in removing unnecessary regulations preventing the development of work-based child care are appropriate matters for a senior public servant to explain in a public forum.

On the other hand, the political defence of a government's program is the responsibility of the members and supporters of that government. Senator Vanstone will also be aware that my contribution to the Women's Electoral Lobby conference included such a political defence of the Government's program-one that is very easy to make, given the outstanding record of the Government in this area; but one which is my responsibility to make. I realise I have spoken for some time, but I hope I have explained for the elucidation of Senator Vanstone the difference between the role of public servants in explaining policy and that of Ministers in advocating and defending it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for her courteous explanation of the difference between the role of the public servant and that of the politician with respect to fact and policy. I suggest that she may care to send--
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to ask her question.

—Will the Minister make that explanation to those working in the Office of the Status of Women so that they too will clearly understand this difference? Secondly, with respect to the first part of my question, is the Minister telling me that it is a matter of fact that this appointment will proceed or is it a matter of fact that the Minister will check with the Minister for Health? In either case, why did the Prime Minister make his promise if both the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women--
—Order! The honourable senator is now extending her question beyond the area of a supplementary question.

—I will rephrase the question. Is it a matter of government policy, as outlined by the Prime Minister in his speech in November on the National Agenda for Women, that a health co-ordinator would be appointed? Will the Government make such an appointment, and will it do it soon?

—I thought that I had said quite clearly to Senator Vanstone the first time I answered her question that the matter of the appointment of that special co-ordinator is something that I shall have to ask Dr Blewett about.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION: VISIT TO NORTH QUEENSLAND

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Education to the recent visit by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, to north Queensland tertiary institutions. Is the Minister aware of the type of reception that Mr Howard received? Is it a fact that the Leader of the Opposition refused to admit that tertiary fees would be part of Liberal Party policy? Is the Minister also aware that Mr Howard is considering forcing young unemployed people to undertake education courses before they can become eligible for the dole? Does the Minister see this as a cost-saving proposal? What is her reaction to the proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did hear some news reports of Mr Howard's visit to north Queensland. Apparently he spoke, or attempted to speak, to some students in one of the north Queensland tertiary institutions. I was rather amused to hear also that he announced that he intended to make frequent visits to campuses because he believed that there was a great deal of potential support for Liberal Party policies among the under-25s. I was rather surprised to hear that speculation, because, given that one of the policies that the Liberals apparently intend to unveil shortly is the reintroduction of tertiary fees, I would have thought that he would have been very unwelcome on campuses throughout Australia and, indeed, that he would find some difficulty in getting access to them.

ANSWER.PARA: I also wonder whether Mr Howard, on any future visits to campuses in north Queensland or in any other part of Australia that he might care to make, would care to explain to students whether, if he is going to force unemployed young people who are on the dole to undertake education courses, he would be prepared to pay the dole to all students. If he is prepared to do that, I wonder whether he will explain how the many hundreds or, perhaps, even thousands of millions of dollars involved would be a contribution to more responsible public expenditure.

I also expected that the students would ask Mr Howard, as indeed I have asked him and my colleague Senator Walsh has asked him, but with no reply, how he considers that the provision of education places for unemployed young people as well as the granting of the dole can be seen as a cost-saving measure. My colleague Senator Walsh has made a preliminary assessment that the cost of providing extra education places into which young unemployed people would be forced would be in the vicinity of $600m. I understand that that costing was worked out on the assumption that the unemployed would go mainly into technical and further education places. Of course, if they were to go into college or university places, the costs would be very much higher.

It is not our policy to force young unemployed people to do anything; it is our policy to assist them to find employment. Of course we have had a very good record in doing that. At the same time it is very much our policy, and one which we have pursued energetically and effectively, to persuade young people to stay in the education system or to go back to the education system rather than to stay unemployed in a situation where they have very few skills and the youth labour market is very weak. We have taken a number of steps, including a drastic increase in the secondary allowance scheme and regular increases in the tertiary education assistance scheme-a program of increases to both those benefits which will make them the equivalent of the dole. These measures have already resulted in greatly increased participation in upper secondary years, particularly by disadvantaged young people, and a rapid expansion of the number of young people in higher education. I suggest that these measures, along with the traineeship scheme, which will also provide young people with some income, some work experience and skill training, are much more constructive and acceptable to young people and much more likely to result in a real and dramatic reduction of youth unemployment.

If Mr Howard cannot understand that and thinks that spending $600m on extra places to force young unemployed people into further studies is some sort of cost saving measure, and if he is unprepared to announce the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia of reintroduction of tertiary fees and privatisation of tertiary institutions-two measures which would achieve only a drastic reduction in access by the kinds of young people who are likely to be unemployed and a lowering of quality in our tertiary institutions-he is at liberty to run around the campuses of Australia and try to attract support on that basis. I would be absolutely amazed if he got anything other than very vigorous opposition from students on any campus in Australia. I conclude by saying that my colleagues on this side of the chamber and I would be very interested to see the fate of Mr Howard should he venture onto the campuses of Australia with these ludicrous policies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four sitting days ago Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question about the reason for the removal of Dilantin from the pharmaceutical benefits list. I now have the following information from the Minister for Health: Parke Davis Pty Limited manufactures Dilantin-phenytoin sodium-an anti-convulsant used in the management of epilepsy. Alternative brands to Dilantin are not available because the drug is subject to bioequivalence problems and the therapeutic dose range is close to the toxic dose level. In effect, Dilantin is a drug for which there is no direct substitute. Price increases for the drug were granted in July 1985, when the average increase was 11.18 per cent. The increases for the pediatric suspension and the capsules were those sought by the company and a pro rata increase was granted for the tablets.

ANSWER.PARA: In December 1985 Parke Davis advised that it would unilaterally increase prices by some 25 per cent from 1 March 1986. The company decided to take this action due to the claimed unsatisfactory price increases obtained for its total range of pharmaceutical benefit products during 1985. The pricing bureau could not recommend any further increase because no additional cost data had been provided since the July 1985 review and because the present prices represented a reasonable margin on the cost of the goods. The margins are higher than those previously enjoyed by the company.

Dilantin continues to be listed under the special patient contributor arrangements. Patients pay between $1.11 and $1.57 for the product. The alternatives would be to accept the manufacturer's proposed price or to delist the product. If the product were delisted, the patient would be required to pay the full dispensed price to continue using the product. The price would range from $11.50 to $15.50.

When the amendments to the National Health Act were passed in 1985 to allow for a special patient contribution where a drug manufacturer and the Government could not agree as to the price, members of the Opposition supported this move. Senator Peter Baume referred to it as a sensible procedure which seeks to deal with price disagreements between the Government and drug manufacturers. The honourable member for Moreton, Mr Donald Cameron, also said that the provision in last year's amendment to cope with pricing disagreements between drug companies and the Government was a sensible procedure. It is as a result of that procedure that we now have this situation with Dilantin.

It is not insignificant that the first drug on the pharmaceutical benefits list which has resulted in a dispute between the Government and the manufacturer is Dilantin-a drug which cannot be substituted, is widely used, and is produced by a large pharmaceutical company of this type. The Minister and I hope that this matter can be settled in the near future. In the meantime, unfortunately, some people will have to pay between $1.11 and $1.57 for their prescriptions, but this is far more satisfactory than that they should have to pay between $11.50 and $15.50. It is a far better solution to the problem than delisting such an important drug.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a ministerial statement on the Prime Minister's official visits between 15 and 28 April 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Between 15 and 28 April the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made official visits to Washington, London, Brussels, Rome and Athens. A principal purpose of these visits was to draw attention to the contemporary crisis in agricultural markets and to secure agreement on both short and long term measures needed to deal with that crisis.

Immediately prior to the Prime Minister's departure the Minister for Primary Industry tabled the Government's statement on economic and rural policy. This is the most comprehensive and important rural policy document ever tabled by an Australian government.
Despite the politically inspired efforts by some to diminish its significance, that statement is destined to remain on centre stage as far as rural policy is concerned for a long time to come.

The Government has clearly indicated that the farm problem must be addressed from both the income and the costs side. Both sides were addressed in detail in the statement. In reporting to you today the Prime Minister will focus on the income side, particularly in relation to international markets.

The crisis in world agricultural trade has been brewing for a long time. The level of consumer transfers and subsidies to European farmers has been escalating for well over a decade. In many of the world's other major producing and consuming areas, protection of agricultural producers has similarly been unchecked by any semblance of order in the international trading system.

Previous rounds of Multilateral Trade Negotiations have failed to address seriously the causes of our corrupted international agricultural trading system. Those causes lie fairly and squarely in the agricultural subsidy practices of the major consuming and producing countries.

The consequence for Australian agriculture has been a persistent, insidious erosion of our position as a major non-subsidising supplier of farm products. This has occurred despite the strong comparative advantage we have in agriculture-despite the fact that our farmers are among the most efficient in the world.

European farm stocks have been at very high levels even before the 1980s. During the 1980's the combination of European export subsidies and American farm policies resulted in a sharp downturn in the US share of world markets and the emergence of the United States as a stock holder of unprecedented proportions.

It was against that background that the United States enacted its 1985 Farm Act. That Act is unambiguously aimed at disposing of surplus stocks on the world market at low prices and with the aid of export subsidies. Its enactment has escalated what can only be termed as a trade war between the United States and Europe.

Australian farmers are caught in the crossfire of subsidy and countersubsidy as the treasuries of the United States and Europe wage an irrational battle with each other, using their own taxpayers' and consumers' money. It was because of the seriousness of this situation-or the nation as a whole as well as for the rural community-that the Prime Minister embarked on his trip to the United States and Europe.

His overseas visit has been aimed at two specific objectives. First, he has been drawing the attention of world leaders to the fact that the world agricultural trade war is dangerous and that it is in nobody's best interests. Second, he has been trying to win sensitivity for Australia's position as a non-subsidising supplier, to minimise the damage being wreaked upon us while the trade war continues.
In the United States he met with President Reagan, Secretary of State Shultz, Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng, and congressional leaders in both the Senate and the House of Representatives.
In Britain he met with Margaret Thatcher, Agriculture Minister Jopling and Secretary for Trade Channon, along with other Ministers and senior officials.

In Brussels, meetings were held with EC President Delors, Commissioner de Clercq and Commission officials. He continued his discussions with the Prime Ministers of Italy and Greece, along with senior Ministers and public servants in those countries.
Key points that he made to all of these world leaders were as follows:
First, the crisis in world agricultural trade is so serious as to warrant immediate world attention. This must be a major issue for the leaders meeting shortly at the Tokyo Summit.

Second, agriculture must be accorded high priority in the forthcoming round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations, under the General Agreement on tariffs and Trade. There is a need for fundamental reform of the rules governing world production and trade for farm commodities.

Third, there is a need for reform of the agricultural support and subsidy policies in many countries. In the EEC 60 per cent of the returns from agricultural production consists of subsidies paid by consumers and taxpayers. The cost is around $70 billion per annum. The common agricultural policy is costing Europe up to one Million jobs through its effect on the European manufacturing sector. The economic costs of the US farm program have not been fully documented, but they are extraordinarily high. In many other countries income and employment is much lower than it otherwise would be because of excessive agricultural protection.

Fourth, there is an immediate need for the exercise of strong restraint in agricultural production, price support and export subsidisation. We do not have time to wait for the MTN Round before beginning to restore sanity in world agricultural trade.

Fifth, Australian farmers are innocent victims, losing around $1 billion per annum in world market returns as a consequence of the CAP alone, let alone the impact of the agricultural policies in other countries. Our farmers' incomes are at the second lowest level in real terms recorded, and look set to fall another 20 per cent in 1986-87.

Sixth, the Australian economy as a whole is suffering from the atrocities being inflicted upon our rural community. We rely on the rural sector for almost 40 per cent of our export earnings. In contrast to Europe and the United States, we export around 80 per cent of production of our four major agricultural export commodities (wheat, wool, beef, sugar). We clearly cannot afford to join the irrational world agricultural trade war.

Seventh, in all the circumstances there is a demonstrable need for the exercise of sensitivity in relation to Australia's position. This applies both in the administration of the US Farm Act and in the conduct of the Common Agricultural Policy.

He is pleased to be able to report that the broad thrust of our case has been accepted in both North America and Europe. President Reagan and President Delors, along with the leaders of Great Britain, Italy and Greece, agree that the current world agricultural regime is intolerable.

In both the United States and Europe he received support for the view that agriculture must be given a prominent position in the forthcoming Multilateral Trade Negotiations. There is also strong agreement on the need for the immediate exercise of restraint on agricultural subsidies and disposal of surplus stocks pending the outcome of the new round.

He believes that there is also a good measure of understanding of Australia's particular circumstances and of the effect the corruption of international markets is having on our rural community and on our economy as a whole.

In relation to the United States Farm Bill, I have been able to build further on the assurances given to the Minister for Trade during his visit in February. In particular the United States Administration has assured him that:

the Export Enhancement Program will be administered on a targeted basis, aimed essentially at markets of subsidising exporters. Recipients under the EEP will be encouraged to maintain their normal level of imports from traditional non-subsidising suppliers such as Australia;
sale of beef in association with the whole herd buyout scheme will be handled in a way which seeks to minimise disruption in Australia's export markets;
we should continue to receive access to the United States beef market at least at the levels consistent with the operation of the existing Meat Import Law;
Australia's traditional share of the United States sugar market is being protected and our concerns in relation to the cotton and rice programs have been noted;

the consultative process covering bilateral agricultural matters will be extended to include Australia's concerns in the implementation of US export subsidy and surplus stock disposal programs. Periodic meetings between our respective Trade and Primary Industry Ministers will be central to that continuing process.

In Brussels he was also given some specific assurances in relation to the management of the Common Agricultural Policy. Most importantly however, he has been able to restore, and significantly extend, the consultative arrangements between Australia and the EC, within which these issues can be further addressed in the future. Key outcomes of his discussions with the EC were:

the Andriessen agreement, under which the EC has agreed not to subsidise sales of beef into our six major Asian/Pacific markets (Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Malaysia, Singapore and Papua New Guinea) has been reaffirmed. This was most important given the request on the United States Administration under the Farm Act to dispose of 200 million pounds of beef outside the US market.
the EC is committed to continuing to respect the minimum price provisions of the International Dairy Agreement;

there will be discussions later this year to try to find an alternative basis for dealing with the arrangement between Australia and the EC on so-called `balance sheet' beef. Certification procedures under the proposed veterinary directive relating to growth promotants will be the subject of consultation with Australia at an early date;
a new consultative framework, consisting of four components, has been agreed for future conduct of Australia/EC relations. These elements are:
high level Ministerial talks covering the full range of agricultural commodity and trade issues are to be resumed at an early date;
a basis is to be established for formal liaison on respective approaches to the new MTN round during the lead-up to the new round and for its duration;
an EEC mission in the field of technological research and development, including agriculture, will visit Australia in May or June;
continuing discussions will be held at official level between our delegations in Europe and in Canberra on all trade issues between the EC and Australia.

Mr President, the Prime Minister will not attempt to delude Australia's rural community by pretending that he has resolved the world agricultural trade crisis. He has not been able to change fundamentally the policies of the USA or the EC. Those policies will continue to corrupt markets and to depress prices for a considerable time to come.

He believes however, that he has been able to add some impetus to the urgency with which these problems might be addressed by world leaders. He has highlighted the burgeoning costs of allowing the present absurd situation to continue.
Only time will tell whether the problems of agricultural trade are given the high profile that they deserve in Tokyo, and in the MTN Round.
Only time will tell whether the world's leaders, and the political processes in major producing and consuming countries, will resolutely face the intractable farm trade problem.

Whatever time reveals, however, there is one thing that it will show. This is that no Australian Government has worked more determinedly, more comprehensively or more effectively in its efforts to have these matters properly addressed.

In the meantime, the Prime Minister has been able to win some sensitivity to Australia's position as a non-subsidising nation. A proper reading of history will show that this mission has brought Australian farmers some respite.

We have been able to establish some guidelines within which existing policies in the United States and Europe will be administered. These guidelines provide a framework for ongoing dialogue. We have a set of benchmarks against which we can seek redress, in the inevitable circumstances where the specific actions of others interact with the cold hard commercial world to damage our interests.

The recently announced subsidised wheat sale to the Yemen Arab Republic would be a case in point. While Australia can expect to maintain its 400,000 tonnes contracted sales to that market, the avenues for dialogue established during the Prime Minister's visit to Washington will be utilised with a view to minimising further subsidised competition from the United States in the additional market that has opened up as a result of the Yemen decision to open a new flour mill.

The structure of personal relationships and the consultative mechanisms that have been established through his visits are of enduring significance. These relationships and mechanisms provide a sound foundation for further determined efforts to bring about change in the world agricultural trading system, and to restore the fortunes of our rural community.
Let me make this pledge to rural Australia. The Government will do all that is humanly possible to carry on the fight for a fair go for Australian farmers in the world economy.

The Treasurer has had these matters uppermost in his mind during recent meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the OECD. He has sought a firmer foundation for more widespread and stronger growth in the world economy. He has sought a proper place for agriculture on the MTN agenda.

The Ministers for Trade and Primary Industry have already made frequent representations overseas on behalf of rural Australia. We are already trying to build a coalition of likeminded countries, at both a bilateral and regional level, to pursue agricultural trade reform.

Official discussions are proceeding in many countries at our initiative. This week we are participating in high level meetings with significant agricultural exporting countries in Uruguay. The Minister for Trade will be attending a meeting of Trade Ministers in Seoul in June and will go on to Canada for a meeting of wheat exporting countries. He will inaugurate a new, formalised dialogue with USTR Yeutter soon after. The Minister for Primary Industry will visit the US, Europe and other countries in June.

The Government's approach to international agricultural trade and diplomacy has been clearly set out in the statement on economic and rural policy. As indicated in that document, we will shortly be convening a high level official group to map out a more comprehensive bilateral agricultural trade strategy.

Finally Mr President, let me say that Australian farmers continue to face serious problems. We have addressed them comprehensively in our statement. We will act upon them comprehensively in the months ahead.

It is our sincere hope that the rural community as a whole, and the leaders of farm organisations in particular, will join with the Government in working constructively to seek and implement practical solutions to the problems we face. Australia's rural problems are problems shared by the nation as a whole.

While the major purpose of the Prime Minister's visit to Washington, London and other capitals, was to discuss the problems confronting Australia's trade in agricultural products, he took the opportunity to review a wide range of other matters.
ANZUS

President Reagan and the Prime Minister reaffirmed the importance of the ANZUS ties between us which are fundamental to Australia's foreign and defence policies. They also have important implications for the security and stability of our region. In reaffirming the importance of our security arrangements under ANZUS, the Prime Minister also made clear to the United States that, notwithstanding the current difficulties between New Zealand and the United States over ANZUS, Australia intended maintaining its bilateral defence co-operation with New Zealand.

The United States has already indicated that, if New Zealand proceeds to enact its proposed anti-nuclear legislation, the United States will review its security commitments to New Zealand. In his discussions with President Reagan, the Prime Minister reiterated Australia's firm view that, whatever may occur in the security relationship between the United States and New Zealand, the legal framework of the ANZUS Treaty should be left intact, and the security relationship between Australia and the United States reaffirmed. In the President's words: `Australia is a responsible ANZUS ally, an important trading partner and a trusted friend'.

In his departure statement at the White House on 17 April, President Reagan confirmed to the Prime Minister that, whatever New Zealand's decision, the United States commitment to Australia under ANZUS is firm.
Further discussions on matters related to ANZUS will take place at the Australia-United States ministerial talks which are scheduled to be held in San Francisco in August.
Terrorism

In the light of recent instances of terrorism and the United States military action against Libya, it was inevitable and appropriate that the Prime Minister should discuss these issues with political leaders in Washington, London, Rome and Greece.

He made it clear that the Australian Government unequivocally condemns terrorism. We deplore the loss of innocent lives and the poisoning of relations among States which result from terrorist outrages.

In his statement to Parliament before he left Australia, he said that the Government counselled restraint by both Libya and the United States. The Government does not accept that violence, in particular terrorism, is a solution to the complex problems of the world.

Senators will be aware that Australia drew the attention of the United Nations Security Council to a number of possible measures open to the international community to further the possibility of a peaceful solution. To those who have criticised such action as unrealistic, I would respond that the Government takes pride in the fact that Australia sought to play a responsible and constructive role in the Security Council in the face of the prospect of an intensifying cycle of violence.

Regrettably the Security Council has so far been unable to take any positive initiative. An essential condition for progress is a genuine and binding pledge by Libya to terminate its Government's direction and export of, and support for, terrorist activity against civilians and civilian targets. Such a pledge should make possible a reciprocal commitment from the United States to refrain from recourse to armed force.

The Australian Government accepts that there is a substantial body of evidence of Libyan direction of and involvement in international terrorism. While in the United States, the Prime Minister put it to the President and others that it would be in the best interests of all that that evidence should be made publicly available.
East-West relations and arms control

His discussions in Washington also covered the prospects for progress towards effective arms control and disarmament. He confirmed Australia's support for the United States-Soviet summit process and the deep concern of the Australian Government and people that the Geneva arms control negotiations have still not achieved any significant progress towards the conclusion of agreements to reduce nuclear armaments. The United States side reassured me of their commitment to continue negotiating seriously and in good faith.

At the request of President Reagan, Ambassador Paul Nitze, Special Adviser to the President on Arms Control, briefed the Prime Minister in Rome on the President's provisional thinking, before taking a final decision, on continued United States adherence to the SALT II agreement. Ambassador Nitze was in Rome as part of his assignment to brief the Heads of Government of European allies of the United States on President Reagan's views on these issues. The Prime Minister's discussion with Ambassador Nitze was part of the continuing process of consultation between Australia and the United States on major arms control and disarmament questions.

Although SALT II has not been ratified, both sides have publicly undertaken to adhere to its provisions. The United States has previously made clear its concern about Soviet compliance with the SALT agreements. The Prime Minister advised Ambassador Nitze that the Australian Government appreciates United States concerns about Soviet compliance with aspects of the SALT II Treaty and the ABM Treaty and believes that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has a case to answer. We remain of the view, however, that continued United States compliance with the SALT agreements is of great importance, especially as the United States seeks to ascertain Soviet intentions during the Summit process in the year ahead.
The Prime Minister has since written to President Reagan in these terms.
South Pacific

In his discussions in Washington, both with the Administration and with Congress, and also in London, he outlined the objectives of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. He explained that this Treaty represents the strongly held aspirations of the countries of the South Pacific, including Australia, to prevent the manufacture, acquisition, possession, testing and stationing of nuclear weapons in our region.

He made it clear that the Government regards it as a responsible arms control measure which enhances regional security and marks a positive step forward in the international search for peace and disarmament. He also emphasised to the United States and United Kingdom governments that the Treaty fully respects rights guaranteed under international law, specifically recognises the sovereign right of parties to determine access to their ports and airfields, and is completely consistent with Australia's responsibility under ANZUS. Indeed we would not have entered into the Treaty unless this were so. He urged both governments to sign the Protocols of the Treaty.
In addition, while in Washington, he took the opportunity to welcome the increased attention now being given by the United States Administration to the fisheries concerns of South Pacific countries.
South Africa
