In both Washington and London, the Prime Minister's discussions covered the tragic situation in South Africa where there is an urgent need to find a peaceful means of abolishing the abhorrent apartheid system. He reiterated the Australian Government's concern that time is running out for a negotiated settlement with moderate black leaders. It was significant, I think that the urgency of the situation was readily acknowledged by the United States Administration.

The Prime Minister also discussed in both capitals the work of the Commonwealth Eminent Persons Group, which is seeking to encourage dialogue between the South African Government and the various racial groups with a view to the peaceful establishment of a non-racial, democratic and representative government in South Africa. In accordance with the communique issued after the last Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Nassau in October 1985, Heads of seven Commonwealth governments, including Australia, will meet later this year to consider the report of the Eminent Persons Group. The report is due by 30 June and the Australian Government believes it is very important that the meeting take place as soon thereafter as possible.
Italy

This was the Prime Minister's first official visit to Italy. He was delighted to confirm the strong ties of friendship between our two countries and to pay a special tribute to the contribution which the Italian community has made to Australia.
He had valuable talks with Prime Minister Craxi on a range of international issues of importance to us.

A very important part of his meeting with him was for them both to sign the Australia-Italy Social Security Agreement which provides comprehensive social security coverage for people moving between the two countries. People in Australia and Italy who will benefit from the agreement include those who have lost pension rights by ceasing to be Italian citizens or by leaving Australia before being granted pensions and those who have not spent sufficient time in Australia or paid sufficient contributions to the Italian scheme to qualify for payments.

In addition to our discussions about the Common Agricultural Policy of the EC, the place of agriculture in the forthcoming MTN Round and our bilateral trade relations, he also took the opportunity to discuss with Mr Craxi Australia's Bicentenary celebrations. He emphasised how much we looked forward to a major involvement by Italy, pointing out that ten countries have established national bicentennial committees. The Prime Minister was pleased that Mr Craxi said that such a committee would be established in Italy, combining the government and private sector, to try to maximise the degree of Italian involvement in the Bicentennial celebrations.
He is now hopeful that as part of Italy's participation the Amerigo Vespucci, one of the world's finest sail training ships, will be able to come to Australia in 1988.

In the course of my visit I extended an official invitation to Mr Craxi to visit Australia. The Prime Minister is delighted that he accepted and he hopes it will not be long before the visit takes place. He also mentioned to Mr Craxi that we would be very pleased if an Italian Minister were able to visit Australia when Italy is participating in the America's Cup, at which time we look forward to welcoming many Italian visitors to Perth. At the same time our joint working group on trade will meet for its third meeting in Perth. This will follow the second meeting due to be held in Rome next month.

The Prime Minister's visit also provided the opportunity to acknowledge the splendid work undertaken by Australian Italians through the Southern Italian Earthquake Committee in rendering assistance to the areas ravaged by the Italian earthquake of 1980. Mrs Hawke had the pleasure of opening the Child Development Centre at Avellino. The construction of this Centre was funded through Australian contributions.
Call on the Pope
In Rome, the Prime Minister had an audience with His Holiness, Pope John Paul the Second.

Pope John Paul indicated to him the affection he holds for Australia and the enthusiasm with which he looks forward to visiting us later this year. The Prime Minister informed him of the intense preparations being made for his visit and of the very warm welcome he will receive from the Australian Government and people.
Greece

The Prime Minister had the great pleasure of making his first official visit to Greece, a country whose people have also made a most important contribution to Australia. In Athens, he had the benefit of interesting and fruitful discussions with Prime Minister Papandreou and also made a courtesy call on President Sartzetakis.

His visit coincided with ANZAC Day and served to remind us of the strong friendship between our countries forged in two World Wars, when Australians and Greeks fought side by side in defence of liberty and democracy.

Again a major focus of his discussions was the Common Agricultural Policy of the European Communities, the need for trade in agriculture to receive a prominent place in the forthcoming multilateral Trade Negotiations and the opportunities for increased bilateral trade with Greece.

In respect of bilateral trade, Mr Papandreou suggested that we examine the scope for an economic and technical co-operation agreement between our two countries, to which the Prime Minister responded positively and this matter will now be examined in more detail at an official level.

In addition, the Prime Minister mentioned the Social Security Agreement which he had just signed with Mr Craxi and indicated that he was happy to see continuing consultations with the Greek community in Australia and subsequently the initiation of work aimed at concluding a similar agreement with Greece.

He also sought the co-operation of the Greek Government in establishing a national committee linking government and private sectors to promote and plan the participation by Greece in our Bicentenary. Mr Papandreou responded positively and such a committee will be established. This will be an especially welcome reflection of the very valuable role played in our development by the Greek community in Australia.

Mr Papandreou accepted the Prime Minister's invitation to visit Australia, having previously visited us as an exile during the role of the junta. The timing of his visit, to which Australia will be looking forward enthusiastically, is now a matter of discussion between them.

The Prime Minister's visit to both the United States and Europe has he believes firmly established in the minds of both the American and European political leadership the seriousness of the contemporary agricultural trading crisis and the need for effective action to deal with it. No instant remedies are available, but comprehensive longer term approaches and medium term responses have been identified. The Prime Minister is satisfied that he has also raised within the countries visited sensitivity to Australian interests. This heightened sensitivity should inform the administrative decisions of the major trading nations.

At the same time, he is confident that his visit has served to strengthen the friendly relations that Australia enjoys with the United States, Britain, Italy and Greece. These relations in their different ways are each very important to Australia and will continue to be developed and consolidated by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MOTOR VEHICLE INDUSTRY: FRINGE BENEFITS TAXATION

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 30 April, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-

``That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency: The need for changes to the proposed fringe benefits tax because of its adverse impact on the Government's car plan and the threat posed by the tax to thousands of jobs in the vehicle industry.''
Senator for the State of Western Australia
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency: The need for changes to the proposed fringe benefits tax because of its adverse impact on the Government's car plan and the threat posed by the tax to thousands of jobs in the vehicle industry.
I am not surprised that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) does not want to stay and listen to this debate since we are supporting his case against the case of his Cabinet.

This is not the same motion as the one moved in the Senate three weeks ago on the same subject matter. At that time we asked the Government to abandon its fringe benefits tax because of the threat to jobs which it posed. We did not get the support of the Australian Democrats in that move, but in the light of the support that the Australian Democrats are prepared to give to some modification of the tax to ease the impact on the car industry, today we are seeking the opinion of the Senate on this matter in order to urge the Government to change its stance.

It is the right time to bring forward this motion, for two reasons. The first is that it it is now quite apparent that the car industry is suffering very badly from a combination of factors which have been discussed in this place on a number of occasions. I will return to that a little later. The reality is that we have a very substantial drop in car sales and car registrations in the first quarter of this year. In the last few days we have had the latest statistics brought out by a commercial statistical service, IDAPS, which are reported to show that there has been a fall in the number of registrations of almost 33 per cent from last year's record levels. Let us look at the section of the industry which is most important to Australian manufacturing-passenger cars. We find that passenger car registrations in the last month showed almost a 30 per cent drop from March of last year. There can be no doubt that it is no longer a matter of theorising and prediction. There can be no doubt that the industry is suffering a very significant downturn and that we are in a situation where the Government still has an opportunity to influence that in a positive way.

We know that because the second reason for making this a pertinent or timely motion today is that the Government has shown an inability so far to bring the relevant tax legislation into the Parliament. We have had a number of predictions that it would be in on a number of different occasions. The latest prediction we were given was by the Leader of the Government in the Senate when he was still in the chamber at Question Time about half an hour ago, when he said that the tax legislation would be brought in early next week at the latest. That followed the prediction of a few days ago that the legislation would be introduced today. The reality is that the fringe benefits tax legislation, and indeed much of the Government's tax legislation, has been stalled because of the Government's difficulties in drafting legislation which it now knows will cause great damage to Australian industry and considerable injustice to some sections of the Australian community. I think that some elements of the Government's tax package are still not widely understood. Most of the Australian community will be appalled if the Government proceeds with its proposals which will impose heavy tax burdens on, for example, voluntary organisations. Organisations which carry out the charitable, educational and health and welfare tasks in our community will find themselves saddled for the first time with Commonwealth income taxes because of this Government's fringe benefits legislation. Today we are dealing merely with one narrow aspect of the Government's tax proposals-its generally anti-business tax proposals-and its impact on Australia's central manufacturing industry, that is, its car and associated parts manufacturers.

We say that at this time, when the Government still has a chance to vary its legislation, and when the impact of this proposed tax and other adverse factors are showing up so clearly, it is time for the Senate to express its opinion and it is time for the Government to change its mind.

When John Howard assumed the leadership of the Opposition he made the point that the Opposition would not be afraid to agree with the Government on those occasions when it thought that the Government was right. That principle was stated very clearly by John Howard, but it was not a new principle. One of the illustrations of our preparedness as an opposition to support what we had thought of as government action which is in the national interest was our support for the Government's car plan. The Minister, Senator Button, brought that car plan down a couple of years ago. It was a car plan which made quite significant changes to the structure of Government regulation of that important industry. It is a car plan which, in all its major aspects, has had the continuous support of the Opposition. We therefore are particularly concerned that the Government's car plan, which to this point has been seen as something of a success, is being put under threat by the Government's own actions.

The Minister is not at the table and is not able to be with us for this debate. I understand that the first Government speaker will explain that he is in Cabinet. It is a sad thing that we are moving a motion which reflects the view of the industry's Minister himself. We are not putting a view that is adverse to Senator Button's view of this matter; we are putting a view that is adverse to the position that the Government has adopted over the objections of the relevant industry Minister. It is an unfortunate feature of the previous debates that we have had in this place that Senator Button has had no support from his back bench in his attempts to do something about a decision which is clearly wrong. There has been no attempt by Labor back benchers to bolster the very proper case which has been put forward by trade unions, by the Labor Government of South Australia, and by the industry itself, both the dealers in vehicles and the manufacturers of vehicles. Instead, we have seen a pathetic backing up of the Keating-Government line on this very damaging tax. I hope that the fact that Senator Richardson is going to lead for the Government in this debate-we are told that he is an influential back bencher-might lead to some change. We might see some semblance of support for industry, for the trade unions and for the Government of South Australia in the contributions which are made by Labor senators in this debate. I am pleased that Senator Foreman will be involved. His interest in South Australia and his interest in the vehicle industry ought to lead him to give some support to the Minister and to the case which is being put forward by the Opposition on this occasion with the support of the Australian Democrats. I hope that the example of Senator Georges being threatened with expulsion from the Party will not prevent Labor senators from at least speaking their minds on this very important issue, and that we might see something better than the rather pathetic defence of Mr Keating's position in the last debate.

Debates on the car industry need to be seen within the context of the wider debate on industry policy generally. The Opposition has on many occasions been prepared to support some of the statements which have been made by Senator Button with respect to the future of manufacturing industry in Australia. I would commend for the attention of people who are concerned about the future of Australia and the future of our manufacturing industry, some of the Press coverage of last weekend on this issue. There was a very lengthy article, for example, in the Australian newspaper which largely revolved around an interview with Senator Button. There was another excellent article on a speech given in this place by Senator Sir John Carrick on the Builders Labourers Federation legislation which related to our trying to come to grips with some of the fundamental problems of Australian industry.

We are in an odd situation. We have an industry Minister who is putting forward many ideas which are relevant to the needs of manufacturing industry, and who is admitting that the solution to the problems of manufacturing industry involves many changes, including an end to demands for greater protection from the Government, an end to many of the traditional roles of the trade unions in manufacturing industry, basic reforms to our education system, a greater understanding at the cultural level of what manufacturing is about, and so on. It is rather strange that in the midst of this message we get the Government itself taking action which is totally contrary to the sort of direction which the Government has tried to set in its car plan and which the Opposition has been prepared to support.

I would support the view that we need very substantial changes in Australia if we are to successfully compete with the rest of the world in manufacturing industry. But the sad fact is that the creation of those changes-and many manufacturers are trying to co-operate in that process of change-is being impeded by the Government with its taxation policies. The particular policy we are talking about at the moment, the fringe benefits tax which will affect company cars, is a classic case of the Government pursuing completely contrary directions in its policies. It really is a very sad day for the Government and for Australia when we get to the situation where there is that sort of internal conflict of policy. It is a matter of enormous importance to us because if we look at what is happening in world trade we will see that Australia is getting itself into an extremely gloomy situation. We have an unusual reliance on the export of primary production and the products of our mines. We have a situation where we have relied very heavily and successfully in the past on those exports. The reality is that world trade is changing. We are now moving to a situation where the trade in those primary products in which we have specialised is a diminishing and less valuable share of world trade. The great increases which have occurred in world trade have occurred in manufactured goods. We in Australia are simply not part of that game; we are simply not part of that action.

I think that the last trade figures showed that about 18 per cent of our exports were in manufactured goods. That is an extraordinary contrast to the percentage for most trading nations. It is the explanation of why we are falling further and further behind in international trade. It is extraordinary, if we compare us to other countries. In 1982 Australia had 22 per cent of its exports as manufactured exports. In the same year Brazil had 39 per cent; Spain had 71 per cent; and Uruguay had 32 per cent. We are in a situation where we are at the bottom of the league. The industrial economies with which we normally compare ourselves have 73 per cent of their exports in manufactured goods. Because manufactured exports are growing, that is the area that we have to look to if we are to solve the very pressing problems that we have with respect to our balance of payments that are putting us in a financial strait-jacket, in a policy strait-jacket, and in an economic strait-jacket. We are talking about matters which go to the heart of the future welfare of Australia, and I think that it is a tragedy that the Government's own attempts to come to grips with that in, for example, the car plan are being sabotaged by its ridiculously greedy policy with respect to taxing business, which is totally counterproductive and which is undermining the policies on which this Government's industry policy is based.

In summary, we have a situation in which the Government is preaching sense in the narrow area of direct industry policy, but it is totally inconsistent in its other actions. It persists with the accord and the inflexible labour market, it persists with policies which damn our exporters, and it persists with policies which ensure that our manufacturers will not be internationally competitive. All of that is relevant to this debate because the car industry is central to the health of our manufacturing industry at the moment. It represents a classic example of what is required. We have a small domestic market with a very large number of manufacturers involved. The present car plan is gradually removing the protective barriers that that industry presently enjoys and there is a very heavy requirement on Australian manufacturers to get more competitive and to get more competitive quickly.

We now have a situation where, as the Government admits, a whole series of pressures are diminishing the prospects for the car industry and the sales which are essential to the car industry. Those factors, which have been mentioned again in the Senate today, include high interest rates, steep increases in the price of cars because of the devaluation, and new statutory requirements, for example, the requirement that cars be made to work on unleaded petrol, and so on. What the Government is doing is adding to this mix a totally new tax which will severely reduce the prospect of sales of Australian made cars. We really are in some sort of cloud cuckoo land when the Government allows that sort of policy mix to develop.

It is dramatically necessary that the Government should be prepared to revise this tax. It is the Opposition's view that the tax should be totally done away with. We believe that there is a whole series of anomalies tied up in the Government's proposal, ranging from the imposts which are going to be put on the voluntary section I mentioned earlier and the fact that voluntary workers using cars that belong to charitable organisations will cause those charitable organisations to incur a tax liability, through to this section where we find that demand for cars on the part of business is being depressed and the whole car plan put at threat.

We are not seeking in this motion to ask the Senate to impose the Opposition's tax policy on the Government. What we are asking the Government to do is to modify its tax policy to reduce the impact of these tax changes on an industry that is struggling for a whole range of reasons. It has gone from a period of record sales which have given the industry a chance of survival and improvement into a period where sales are being depressed at a very rapid rate. We think the Government simply must make changes to take that into account. I want to make it quite clear that in putting forward this motion again we are not seeking to prescribe to the Government precisely what it should do. We are not saying that it should make a particular reduction. We are saying that it should do something to reduce the burden that is being imposed on companies that would otherwise buy cars. We are saying that the Government must, at the very minimum, phase in this tax, and that preferably it must reduce its impact on a permanent basis. It is the view of the industry itself that the Government stands to raise a much higher amount of revenue from this tax than was originally predicted-an extra couple of hundred million dollars. At the very least the Government should be shaving off any excess revenue it stands to gain if it retains the formulas announced many months ago.

I will refer quickly to some of the statistics which are causing so much concern to the Opposition, as they are causing concern to the industry, to the trade union movement, and to the Labor Government of South Australia. In the case of the automobile dealers, they have issued figures in the last few days that suggest that of the 36,000 people employed in dealerships there is a short term prospect of 10 per cent of them losing their jobs. In dealerships alone some 3,600 jobs will be lost in the short term. If we look at the figures brought out by the manufacturers, we see that they suggest the manufacturers will lose some 3,000 jobs, but with an overall job loss of about 10,000. They are predicting that this tax alone will cause a loss of 35,000 sales in 1986. That is a set of estimates on which I am prepared to rely. However, I remind the Senate that the trade union movement has been far more gloomy in its predictions as to what effect the tax will have on the industry. The vehicle unions have suggested to the Government that as many as 25,000 jobs could be lost because of this tax.

We have an unusual situation here. We have a unanimous view which is being pressed on the Government by industry, by trade unions, and by at least one State government. We have a view which has been supported consistently by the Opposition. We have a view which more recently has been pursued by the Australian Democrats following their consultations with the industry that there is a need for a reduction in the impact of this tax. It is a great shame that the Minister is not in the chamber to participate in this debate but has to be in Cabinet. This matter is so important that it is a pity we have not got the Minister here to explain again that in his view this tax is damaging to the industry and that in his view it is a tax that should have been changed.

I am not sure how the rules of Cabinet government work any more when Ministers can come in here and make these statements, but the reality is that we have Mr Keating and the Treasury maintaining a line against the wishes, I believe, of all interested parties and all people who objectively have tried to assess what the impact of this tax will be. I do not think this is a time for Mr Keating to try to maintain the line just for the sake of maintaining the line. I think it is time the Government accepted that there are very severe negatives for Australia in the tax proposals to be imposed on motor vehicles and the commercial users of motor vehicles. I think it is time for change. I hope the Senate will support this motion and that we will be able to convince the Government and the Treasurer that they should do something to amend this iniquitous tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As all honourable senators will be aware, the matter which is the subject of the matter of urgency today has already had a run through the Senate in a matter of public importance, it has been the subject of many questions at Estimates committees, and numerous questions have been asked at Question Time over recent weeks and months. Senator Button has on every occasion answered those questions and, in the case of the recent matter of public importance, of course, he led for the Government. However, as we speak today there is a Cabinet meeting taking place and, as Senator Button has carriage of the submissions which are going before the Cabinet meeting, he has to be there. Those submissions are important to his portfolio and he regrets his inability to be in the chamber. That is why I, a humble back bencher, stand here before honourable senators leading for the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I did discuss with Senator Button some of the matters I knew would be raised today, and on his behalf I can make a couple of observations. The first and most obvious, which I think would be known to Senator Chaney and the Opposition, is that later on this week there will be further discussions between Senator Button, the Treasurer Paul Keating, and the industry. Senator Button and the Treasurer wish to make it clear that the Government is still looking at this question, that the door is still open to change, and that the Cabinet will have to consider the outcome of the deliberations between the industry and those Ministers later on this week.

As Senator Chaney mentioned, it is expected that the legislation will be in the Parliament next week, by which time back benchers will have had an opportunity to put their views to the Government when the matter comes before Caucus. I am delighted to hear Senator Chaney refer to our back benchers as pathetically backing up Paul Keating. From all I have read in the newspapers in recent times, that is something I have not been doing a lot of. I read that Mr Keating and I have a chill in our relationship and that I am not supporting him at all. I intend, immediately I get a copy of Hansard, to send Senator Chaney's contribution to Paul Keating with the relevant part underlined just so he knows what my real role around here is. However, as I said, by the time the legislation gets back here the back benchers in the Government will have put a view to the Treasurer and to Senator Button.

I might say that, like many other senators, I have been lobbied by the industry. I was lobbied when introduced to them by a South Australian member of parliament who has been active in recent weeks and months in putting his point of view to the Government-a point of view shared by many. As Senator Chaney said, and as Senator Button readily concedes, the position so far adopted by the Government on this matter is, to quote him, so as to be exact, `not his preferred position'. However, the doctrine of ministerial responsibility is, contrary to what Senator Chaney said, alive and well. Obviously in the end the Minister will do all he has to do to implement Government decisions.

In opening the Government's side of the case there are two points that need to be made. The first is that, whatever the Government does, whatever it may decide, 1986 cannot be as good a year for the car industry as 1985 was. As we all know, 1985 was a record year. The results were far in excess of those for previous years, for a number of reasons to which I will refer later. However, when one comes off a record year, things cannot possibly be as good. The second thing that must be made clear is that there will be a fringe benefits tax. The Government will not walk away from its commitment to a fringe benefits tax. As I said earlier on, what the Government is still looking at, and what has still to be covered in discussions later on this week between the relevant Ministers and industry representatives, is what form the tax will take and how much it will be. That there will be a fringe benefits tax is definite. No one, including Senator Button, wants to walk away from that commitment.

I would like to take the Senate through why the Government has that commitment and why it believes it cannot walk away from it. When we came into government a few years ago we were faced with a tax system that was haemorrhaging dramatically. There was no doubt that the burden, day by day, was increasingly falling on those forced to pay pay as you earn tax. The major burden which they shouldered had shifted from those who were able to get all of the fringe benefits. One did not have to get a fringe benefit to get a benefit at all in that sense. There was also massive tax avoidance on a scale previously unknown. I recall that Mr Costigan referred to tax avoidance as a growth industry as heady as any since the days of the Victorian gold rush. So this is not something that I have made up. Obviously, when one considers the bottom of the harbour scheme and all of the other schemes that were allowed to flourish, we inherited a tax system that was in a mess.

We set about rectifying a system which had been allowed to decline and decay, as this one had, with courage and determination. This is something that the Liberal-National Party coalition, with John Howard, the former Treasurer, now at its head, had failed to do in all of the years that it held power. We set about the issue logically; we set about it by consulting with all of the community. We all remember the tax summit at which there was widespread consultation.

However, at the end of the day we have to look at the fringe benefits tax and the urgency motion we are debating today against the background that I have outlined-that is, the Government came in, saw a tax mess and set about rectifying it. The White Paper on taxation reform that the Government released last year showed that we were losing some $700m a year in benefits paid to employees by way of the provision of motor vehicles, free lunches, school fees, housing allowances and so on. The phenomenon of fringe benefits may have been around for some time but the extraordinary and rapid rate of its growth in the last decade was the reason the Government was forced to act. The reality is that it was rising at 25 per cent a year in terms of lost revenue to the Government. That is something with which the Government could not live. No respectable government could.

It is not a matter of being anti-business if one wants to change the system; it is a matter of trying to introduce some equity into the system. It may be all right to have the free car, the free lunch, the school fees and the housing allowances. The problem was that the ordinary Australians-the millions out there who did not have access to these benefits-were subsidising those who were able to get these benefits. This Government had to do something about it. I can recall in this chamber a few weeks ago hearing cries about what a terrible thing we had done to the hospitality industry and how many thousands of people had lost their jobs because of the hospitality tax. Of course, the figures over recent months have shown that job vacancies in the industry have grown and that there are not enough people to fill them. The Government approached this matter by looking at improving the equity of the tax structure. It had to remove these anomalies; it had to remove all of the avenues and the loopholes that the smarties had been able to use. The overall objective was not to increase the revenue obtained from companies but to make sure that income substitution for tax minimisation purposes did not occur and was effectively done away with by encouraging a move back to cash remuneration and by ensuring that non-cash benefits were taxed as income.

Just to show how much that meant to the Government in terms of its tax plans, the White Paper estimated that about $280m a year would be lost in tax on company cars. The Government expects to collect only $320m in the first year of operation of the fringe benefits tax in 1986-87. So the car component of the fringe benefit tax is very high.

It is easy when one is in opposition to say that such a tax should be scrapped. We notice so often that promises are made easily from the other side of the chamber. However, the reality is that if we want to maintain the integrity of the tax package, if we want to maintain the integrity of what the Government has done in its last couple of Budgets and what it intends to keep doing-that is, keeping budget deficits down-we cannot just forgo hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue. We have to work out what can replace revenue lost in this way. I have looked and looked, and searched and searched, but one can never find how this Opposition would replace any of the billions of dollars in promises that it has made, nor can we find what it would do to replace any tax on the vehicle industry.

I might say that I was encouraged when I looked today for the first time at the wording of the matter of urgency because I saw that the Opposition had changed from its position a few weeks ago of abandoning the tax to now just seeing a need to change it. I thought to myself that at last Senator Chaney and his colleagues have woken up. However, what happened, of course, is that Senator Chaney destroyed all of those illusions that were built up in my mind. I was crushed when I heard that the only reason he agreed to the proposal to look at the change rather than abandoning it was, hopefully, to get the Australian Democrats on side. I thought that there would have been more principle and more intellectual thought in Senator Chaney's decision than merely that-merely lousy old--

TALK.START.PARA: —That was naive, Senator.

—I have to concede now that that was naive on my part. I am disappointed in myself for ever thinking it was possible. Nevertheless, the Government, in the course of the last 12 months, has listened to the industry and made changes. If we look at the original White Paper and plan that the Government had for this tax we find in the final announcement at the end of the day that considerable concessions had been given to the industry in the tax package.

SPEECH.PARA: Companies now face two options in determining tax liability on company-owned cars. Standards have been set. The first option relates to a statutory rule, if one likes. As a second option, people can go to the log book method if they believe that their car has a high proportion of business use. Having seen all of the arguments put by the trade unions and the industry, the Government made those concessions and, as I have already stated, is currently looking at whether or not there will be further concessions and whether or not the tax can be altered. However, for all of the reasons I have outlined, it is not looking at abandoning the tax. This is something it cannot look at because our commitment to equity in the tax system remains as strong as ever. We do not intend to walk away from that commitment.

The difficulty is that for all of those years when the tax structure was ignored, when tax evasion was allowed to run rampant, when the burden increasingly fell on ordinary Australian families instead of where it really ought to have been, the people opposite who were in government at the time did nothing about it. They did nothing because they could never take the hard decisions. They could never take something away from those who had a benefit. Paul Keating and Bob Hawke showed the courage to do it last year. I, and all of my colleagues, support them in that. We are now looking at the level at which those taxes ought to be pitched. If we are going to take a tough stand on the Budget-and Paul Keating and the Government have made it quite clear that they will; a much tougher stand than the $9.6 billion deficit than the Opposition was prepared to leave us with-the Cabinet has to remain firm and has to protect the integrity of the tax package.

Let us look at some of the surveys, given that their contents have been quoted to us by Senator Chaney, to see the damage that the fringe benefits tax will do to the industry. It is obvious that the Opposition, for political reasons, has fanned, exaggerated and multiplied the effects of such a tax. It is also obvious that the industry, in coming to the Government to try and get what it sees as some needed changes, has seen fit to make an ambit claim. It has also made sure that some of these figures are great indeed.

The survey of the Australian Graduate School of Management released on 28 March this year reveals some fascinating facts and figures. For instance, half of Australia's company car fleet managers think that the Government's proposed fringe benefits tax will have little impact on their purchasing decisions. The Graduate School of Management found that there was no support for assertions of massive job losses. Three-quarters of large fleet company managers indicated that they would not change their practice of offering cars. The survey concluded that only 4 per cent of respondents said that they would stop providing cars as a result of the tax. That is backed up further by an article in yesterday's Chanticleer column in the Australian Financial Review which referred to the Martec survey-Martec being an independent and respected consultant to the automotive industry. This article explained why there has been a drop in the market this year. We saw on the front page of the Australian this morning an article about a very large drop. The reality is that 1985 was a record year for all sorts of reasons.

It should not be forgotten that when the Government came to office the car industry, for which Senator Chaney now pleads, had been the subject of a pretty deaf ear for years. In the period 1975 to 1983, when members of the Opposition were in government-they do remember those years; I hope they can live on the memory for a long time because I do not think they will experience the practice again-they have to remember that 20,000 jobs were shed in the car industry. When the industry pleaded with the then Government to do something about that, it chose, as usual, to do nothing. It finally got around to organising a plan, announced in 1982, which was to take effect from 1985.

There is no doubt that since the 1960s the competitiveness of the industry has declined significantly. I would have hoped that that is unable to be disputed. The reasons for that decline are many and varied, but it is pretty obvious that the Liberal-National Party coalition Government which ruled Australia for 24 of the previous 30 years was only ever able to patch up short term solutions. It could never look at the direction of the industry; it could never face up to what was happening in Japan. All it could ever do was hand out a bit here and hand out a bit there and hope that it would get through another election. In those 24 years there was never any hope of the industry seeing some sort of concrete vision of where it might go or what might happen to it. Therefore there were rising levels of protection, allegedly to save jobs, and a continuing shedding of jobs in the industry over that period, culminating in 20,000 jobs being shed in the eight years before we came to office. To use a word Senator Chaney used earlier on, that performance is pathetic. Nothing was done in those 24 years.

Our Government came to office during 1983 and saw what a mess the industry was in. It was able in the short space of 12 months to come up with a car plan which it announced and put into effect. It started to do something about increasing efficiency in the industry and gave it some hope of survival. Since that car plan has been announced honourable senators have not seen the industry screaming and complaining about it; all they have seen is the creation of an Automotive Industry Authority which has been able to co-ordinate what the industry, the unions and the Government think should be done and to act as an honest broker consulting with all of those groups. Its objectives in promoting efficiency and export awareness have worked. Because of that policy and because of the enlightened plan which Senator Button came up with, which was welcomed by the industry, there was a record year in 1985. We cannot keep record years going and therefore there had to be a downturn.

In conclusion, in our period of government our record has been first class because of the car plan. We have nothing to apologise for. We are still talking to the industry and honourable senators will see the results and the fruits of those discussions over the next week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating an urgency motion proposing that there should be modifications to the Government's proposed fringe benefit tax on motor cars. The Australian Democrats support this motion. We believe that there is an urgent need for modification to the Government's original proposal for taxing motor cars. The reasons we believe there is an urgent need for modification, I hope, will be made clear during my remarks. I was very pleased to hear Senator Chaney say that the Opposition's attitude is that it is the Government's responsibility to make those modifications. That is also the Democrats' view. We certainly do not think it is our responsibility as a political party, or the Opposition's responsibility, to tell the Government what modifications should be made, but it is apparent to us that modifications are necessary. I was also pleased to hear Senator Richardson say that the Government still has an open mind, is still prepared to consider the matter and in fact is doing so with the industry later this week.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are that there are three fundamental sectors of our economy on which our economic prosperity depends. Whether we like it or not, we are dependent on the car industry, the home building industry and the farming industry. If any one of these sectors of our economy turns down or is depressed for any reason, the whole economy is affected. If these three sectors of our economy turn down together, disaster is facing us fairly and squarely. The Democrats believe there is a very real danger that this may, in fact, happen-that the three vital sectors of our economy may turn down in concert. We already know that the farmers are complaining bitterly about their position. We have seen forecasts that the home building industry expects a downturn during the next 12 months. Hopefully the Government has attempted to do something about that downturn and it will not be prolonged. But it is inevitable there will be some downturn.

As Senator Chaney pointed out, there is already a 31 per cent drop in new car sales for the month of March. I think there has been a 33 per cent drop for the quarter, and we have just been told today in the Press that there was a 31 per cent drop in March. So that sort of trend has to be averted. It is, therefore, vitally important that the Government carefully assesses the impact of this new fringe benefit tax on motor cars so that it does not have the effect of hammering the industry down further.

There are very cogent reasons why the Democrats are concerned that the Government has miscalculated the effect of this tax on the industry. First and foremost, there is a great discrepancy in the figures. We find that the car industry has come out with one set of figures and the Treasury has come out with another set of figures. If one looks into those figures carefully, one finds that the argument revolves around the number of pool cars or the number of cars that are garaged during weekends. Those cars, of course, do not attract the Government's tax. The discrepancy between the number of pool cars, as the jargon goes, is 100,000. The Treasury says there are 100,000 fewer cars to be taxed than does the industry. If one does a little bit of simple arithmetic and assumes that there is a flat tax on all motor cars of, say, $1,500, which is what the industry recommends, and one multiplies that by the 100,000 discrepancy in the figures, one finds there is a difference of $150m.

I submit that this Parliament and the Government could not readily accept a proposal based on statistics where there is such a wide discrepancy. The Government's first responsibility to the Australian people, surely, is to get agreement between the Government departments concerned and the industry so that we can assess what effect this tax is going to have on overall revenue. Until the Government can get agreement on the basic statistics-the number of cars to which this tax will be applied-it is very difficult to debate just what is going to happen to the industry. Once the Government has got agreement between those three bodies as to the basic statistics, we believe the Government should carefully re-assess this proposed tax on the basis of figures that are agreed to by the industry and Government departments, including the Treasury, and then look at the effect of the tax in three vital areas. The Government must be sure that, firstly, the tax will not act as an incentive that depresses the market for Australian made cars. Secondly, it must ensure that the tax does not torpedo the 1984 car plan. Thirdly-this is important to the Democrats-it must come up with a modification which is neutral in revenue raising; in other words, it will not raise more or less money in total than was originally budgetted for by the Government in the overall tax package.

Why are these three areas or criteria so important? First of all, we have already heard estimates of the effect on employment if this tax has a depressing effect on Australian-made motor cars. The employment figures have varied from a loss of 10,000 jobs to a loss of 25,000 jobs, but that sort of loss of employment would be an absolute disaster at this point in Australia's development. It would be a disaster as far as the management of the economy is concerned. The second thing the Government must ensure does not happen is that the 1984 car plan is torpedoed. The 1984 car plan is important. It was the first time an attempt was made to get a coherent long-term plan for the automotive industry. It is a plan that has the support of all three political parties-the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia and the Democrats. It is a plan that has the support of the trade union movement and the industry. If this tax introduces a new factor that upsets that fundamental long-term car plan, we are back to where we have been for the past 20 years in the automotive industry in this country-we are back to ad hoc solutions and letting the industry rip without any real government directions.

It is also important from our point of view that, whatever modifications the Government makes, they are revenue neutral. This is important because, as we have already noticed in the media, there are vested interests in the community, both in the Labor Party and certainly in the Opposition ranks, which would look for an excuse to torpedo the whole tax package. There was a conference over the weekend which drew attention to the fact that maybe the Government could renege on its promise to reduce marginal rates of tax, particularly the top marginal rate of tax which the Government has promised to reduce from 65 per cent to 49 per cent. Of course, the Opposition has said that it wants to see the whole tax package abandoned, particularly the capital gains tax. The Democrats believe that there is need for tax reform in this country. We have been at great pains to tread a very fine line between putting maximum pressure on the Government to ensure that the changes to the tax package did not impact unfairly or unevenly on any one sector of the community, and ensuring that the Government was not given an excuse to abandon the whole tax package, particularly the very necessary reductions in marginal rates of tax that are crippling incentive in this country at this stage-marginal rates of tax which mean that tradesmen and ordinary Australians are taxed at rates which applied originally to millionaires. There has to be reform.

We believe that, with the initiatives we have made and with the pressure we have applied to the Government, the package is now in a form that should proceed. We do not want there to be a fundamental change, particularly insofar as the revenue raising aspects of the package are concerned. Although we claim that the tax package is now reasonable, it is interesting to note that we have supporters in this contention. An editorial in the Age on Monday, 2 December, said:
The changes to the package arising from the Democrats' pressure appear to be a sensible improvement, with which both the Democrats and the Government should feel pleased.
The editorial went on to say:

The Liberals have adopted the rather weak-kneed and opportunist policy of opposing only `the nasties' in the tax package. The Democrats have at least pursued a consistent line and achieved something-in fact, 80 per cent of what they had sought.

We believe there are some very real advantages in the tax package that are equally distributed right across the community now. We believe that the proposed capital gains tax is in a mild form and is one that will not impact unfairly. But that we need a capital gains tax is, as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, indisputable if we are to crack down on tax avoidance. We have been able to ensure that the family home was not included in capital gains tax. We have been able to ensure that losses were taken into account and deducted against gains, that the tax would not be retrospective, and so on. I do not want to go through it all. There has been a lot of work and negotiation, and it would be a great tragedy if an excuse was given to the Government for it to renege on the package at this stage. However, we believe it is critical that there are modifications to the fringe benefits tax as it applies to the motor industry, particularly as there are such worrying signs as to the future strength of the economy in the three vital areas that concern its prosperity.

In summary, we say that the ball is fairly and squarely in the Government's corner. We believe it is vital that the Government modify the fringe benefits tax, but it is up to the Government to say how it should be done. We know the industry has come up with suggestions about a flat rate of tax on various categories of motor car. That may be the way to go or it may not. That is for the Government to assess. But it must modify its package in a way that preserves the three vital criteria-that it is revenue neutral, that it does not impact on the 1984 car plan, and that it does not act as an incentive for buyers to move away from Australian-made motor cars.

The Democrats do not believe that the 1984 plan is the final answer to the motor car industry in this country. We would like to see the Government now look at the long-term view. There is no reason why, say over a ten-year period, the Australian industry could not produce an Australian-designed car with an Australian engine designed to use fuels that are in abundance in this country, such as natural gas. It would be a very simple matter for the Government to lay down criteria now for such a project. It would give the industry time to design and develop such a car, and then, as the 1984 plan proceeds along its course, the industry would be ready to take up the challenge of something which is specifically Australian, which is exportable, which is fuel efficient and which faces up to the fundamental problem that sooner or later we will run out of Bass Strait crude oil. When that happens, under this suggestion, we would have a motor car that could run on an alternative fuel. We should look 10 years ahead, and now is the time to do that. In the meantime, we should make sure that we do not face disaster with massive unemployment in the motor industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion that has been moved by Senator Chaney, which is also being supported by the Australian Democrats. I think all of us on this side of the chamber appreciate the problems facing the motor car industry and the need to restructure that industry, and we all support the general thrust of the Button plan that has been referred to during this debate. The problem as we see it is that the Button car plan will be seriously jeopardised because of the fringe benefits tax to which we are referring. The tremendous publicity that has been given in recent times to the downturn in sales of motor vehicles gives weight to the concern that we have expressed during this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year when the fringe benefits Bill was debated in the Senate I referred to the fact that 1985 would be long remembered as the year of the Hawke Labor Government's taxation mess. I said that it would be long remembered for the Taxation Summit, which revealed the disorder and disunity of the Hawke Ministry. I finished by saying that the Bill was a result of the confusion and ideological vindictiveness of the Hawke Government towards small business. I note that Senator Richardson referred to the restaurant and catering industries. He said that the Government's imposition did not seem to have any effect on those industries, but that is not so. Many small businesses and small restaurants have certainly felt the pinch as a result of the taxation measures that have been thrust upon them by this Government. I also said that I believed that the Bill was a disastrous one; however, the people of Australia had voted the Australian Labor Party Government into power, for better or for worse, and they would realise next year that it would be for the worse.

Here we are in the next year, 1986, and the people are beginning to realise what a disastrous policy this fringe benefits tax proposal in particular is. Even the Labor Government in South Australia has come out very strongly in oppo- sition to the tax. I notice that an article in the Adelaide News of today's date states:
Drop car tax, says Bannon.
A 25 per cent drop in new car sales sparked a renewed call from the Premier, Mr Bannon, today for an urgent rethink by the Federal Government on its proposed company car tax.
Mr Bannon said the tax should be substantially modified, or abolished if its impact continued to seriously damage the car industry and cause job losses.

He referred to the fact that the State Government had made submissions to the Federal Government, that he had spoken to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and Senator Button about the matter and that `up to 4,500 jobs in the car industry and associated industries are at stake in South Australia if the tax goes ahead in its original form'. The article also pointed out that General Motors-Holden's Ltd has reduced its work force by 500 workers in South Australia alone since the beginning of the year because of the fall-off in sales-a huge 26 per cent in the first quarter of the year.

That is what the South Australian Labor Government thinks about this fringe benefits tax. I hope that the Government will be encouraged to revise its thinking on the way in which it is to be imposed. Not only the State Government in South Australia has shown an interest in the matter. It is natural that the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia is beginning to understand the effects of this particular taxation measure. I feel sympathetic to Senator Foreman, who is very interested in that organisation, because I think he will be asked to attempt to defend what I regard as an indefensible, foolhardy policy of this Government.

As we have heard, the motor industry has recorded its worst March sales in 12 years. Registrations have fallen by almost 33 per cent from last year's record levels. According to the survey that was carried out professionally for the motor industry, registrations last month fell by 32.9 per cent, a fall from March 1985 of 21,469 vehicles. The sales for the year to date are down by 25.3 per cent. I understand that 40 per cent of car sales involve fleet cars. In particular, the Falcon and Commodore ranges of vehicles would be largely affected. Earlier this month I opened the international motor show in Adelaide and talked to some industry executives there. One firm in Adelaide had noticed a downturn of 60 per cent with respect to fleet car sales. I think this is symptomatic of the psychological effect this measure has already had on this industry, even before it is due to be brought in, in July.

I believe that there is time for the Government to reconsider the way in which the taxation is to be imposed. The Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries recently issued a Press release, the details of which would be well known to the Government. It states:
The FCAI does not object to the taxing of employer-provided cars. It is essential, however, that the major adverse effects listed-
by the Chamber-
are reduced.
I will not go through that list at present. The Chamber goes on to say:
This can be done if company car tax rates are at more affordable levels and do not exceed the revenue objectives.
The Chamber requests the Government to reassess the heavy and damaging penalties which will be placed on the automotive industry if it proceeds with the company car tax in its present form.

I am encouraged by what Senator Richardson said-that the Caucus has yet to examine the proposals put forward by the Ministry. I hope that, in the light of the statements that have been made here today and in the light of the concern that is being expressed nationally with respect to the slump in car sales, some serious modification of the measures will take place.

The impact of these fringe benefits taxes can only be estimated. The Treasurer has claimed that he will raise, I think, $350m from the tax, but he has never substantiated that figure. The Government refuses to produce any tangible evidence of where that money is likely to be raised, although other organisations have attempted to do so and have given a pretty accurate idea-as accurate as can be-of the devastating effect that this can have, is having and will have on the motor industry in Australia.

One thing is certain: The proposal for a fringe benefits tax on company-provided cars is harmful to the vehicle manufacturing industry. It is harmful at a time when the industry is experiencing many other difficulties, many of which have been induced by this Government. I stated earlier that estimates of the impact of the tax vary. The Vehicle Builders Employees Federation estimates that up to 25,000 jobs in the industry will be lost as a result of this new tax. The Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries is more conservative, estimating that about 10,000 jobs will be lost. Of course, jobs will be lost outside the industry. For example, the Automotive Dealers Association of Australia has predicted that some 3,600 employees in the retail trade will lose their jobs in the initial stages of the introduction of the tax. I have a note from the Australian Automotive Dealers Association on a survey of retrenchments it carried out. The points it makes are as follows:
The Association has completed a survey of dealers concerning potential retrenchment of employees in that industry.
Currently, approximately 36,000 persons are employed in dealerships associated with sales of passenger motor vehicles to fleet, business and commercial operations.
Potential retrenchments in this segment of the industry will range from a minimum 5% to a maximum 30%.

However, the Association believes that initially retrenchments will be around 10 per cent, or 3,600 employees. If the Government had counted on obtaining fringe benefits tax of, say, 11 per cent of the 35,000 vehicle sales that will be lost in the first year-it will be 25 per cent per year thereafter-the revenue will be reduced in the first year by something like $56m. The problem and the revenue lost are compounded should 10,000 workers lose their jobs because they would not be paying income tax and there would be another reduction in government revenue of about $50m. Should those workers and their families, unhappily, be forced on the dole, there would be a further impost on the Treasury of about $75m as a result. The Federal Treasury would net $169m and not $350m, as the Treasurer is now predicting. The Treasury would also lose the revenue from sales tax on 35,000 new vehicles. It would lose considerable excise and sales tax on oil products, and, of course, the State governments would likewise lose revenue from stamp duties, registration fees, and insurance revenue.

Some estimates put the net income to be derived from this tax as low as $49m. So for a mere $49m, and perhaps the endorsement of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, the Treasurer has seen fit to throw out of work at least 10,000 workers in the car building industry, plus thousands of others in the retail industry and associated businesses. He has seen fit to undermine the cost effectiveness of manufacturing vehicles in Australia, at a time when the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) is attempting to put into effect his car plan to rationalise the vehicle building industry in this country. Both those matters are serious. The loss of work will mean that the lives of thousands of Australians will be seriously affected, with far-reaching economic effects on a wide range of other businesses. Likewise, the disruption to the car manufacturing industry will have far-reaching effects on many commercial activities, including the steel and aluminium industries, which are already reeling from the effects of the fringe benefits tax on company houses. Inflation in Australia is twice that of the worst affected of our trading partners, and many times that of West Germany, Japan and the United States of America. It is largely being driven by the public sector and, in particular, by Government economic policies. So we cannot afford to jeopardise further an industry which is of such great significance to Australia.

Senator Siddons pointed to three industries that are very important to Australia, namely, the farming industry, the housing industry, and the motor vehicle industry. The first two have been suffering as a result of impositions placed upon them by the Government. It would be very serious indeed if the motor vehicle industry were to suffer as a result of the introduction of an indiscriminate fringe benefits tax. As I have already stated, this is regarded as a very serious matter in South Australia. The State Government is very concerned about it. I hope that this Government will have regard to the very sensible submission put to it by the Bannon Labor Government and that it will have regard to the seriousness of the matter of urgency we have moved today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has moved this matter of urgency today because it feels, in its words, that the Government's car plan is a threat to thousands of jobs in the vehicle industry. There is, of course, another threat in this taxation package which it is not at all keen to bring to the surface. The threat, naturally enough, relates to tax avoidance. The payment of non-taxed income to certain privileged income earners is a burden to the rest of the community. The Opposition believes, or seems to believe, that certain high income earners have rights of which, naturally, the vast majority of wage and salary income earners should be deprived. It is hardly surprising that members of the Opposition get up here and defend one tax rort after another. They are, of course, protecting some unsavoury practices which this Government has had the courage to challenge. The Opposition wants to protect its natural constituency-the tax avoiders. I say protect because when Opposition members were in government they showed reluctance to tackle tax avoidance. They were soft on the issue and, despite their seven years in office, the industry flourished. Now in opposition they come in here time and time again to defend every tax rort that is under threat.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what their real concerns are here today. The spirited defence they offered of tax-free lunches is rather symptomatic of their stance. They believe that the Sunday lunch in a plush restaurant ought to be a legitimate tax deduction. No doubt members of the Opposition will get up here and defend the private school fee component of some high income package as well. The inescapable fact is that in a civilised society taxes have to be paid, no matter how painful that process may be to some. The fact is that, in the words of Franklin Roosevelt, taxes are the dues we pay for living in a civilised society. The Opposition seems to want to change the phrase `the dues we pay' to `the dues they ought to pay'-namely, the legitimate wage and salary earners who do not have the luxury of tax free income as part of their income package-so that we can live in a civilised society.

The point must never be forgotten that taxation is a burden for all income earners which must be fairly shared. The benefits of living in a civilised society are likewise there for all to share. It is, therefore, right and proper that the tax burdens should fall upon all members of that society and should not be avoided by a privileged section of the community. One point that is certain is that one person's tax avoidance is another's burden. The tax that is avoided has to be paid by others. In this way tax avoidance is stealing-stealing from every legitimate taxpayer an extra amount of money that rightfully should be his or hers. One other anti-social practice which needs to be exposed here, and the Opposition is doing this well, is the defence of tax avoidance. To this end it stands condemned by the vast majority of legitimate wage and salary earners who can see for their own eyes that members of the Opposition shed tears for tax avoiders but did very little to halt the growth of this unsavoury practice when they were in control.

The tax package that was developed during 1985 was an attempt to regain some justice and fairness in taxation. As a consequence, employer-provided non-taxed benefits were to be taxed. If an employer provides a benefit as part of an income package, that benefit should be taxed. The provision of cars, as with the provision of free private school fees, credit cards, expense accounts, and all the rest of it, are simply ways of avoiding tax. The problem in the vehicle industry, which the Opposition now seems to be latching on to, is the effects of the tax package on motor vehicles and any impact such a proposal may have on the Button plan.

Quite clearly the tax package in its present form is defensible in the interests of the community at large. My concern with the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles is not with an application of the principle. If a motor vehicle is supplied as part of an income package for personal use, in my view it should be treated as income. However, in this particular area some special conditions arise. Firstly, the level of tax to be applied has been seen by some in the industry as a problem. Unlike the straight provision of private school fees, which involves a clear monetary amount, the provision of a car involves private as opposed to employer use. For this reason it is important that the Government get the formula correct. The principle of fair taxation is sound and so too must be the implementation.

I must express a concern with the car plan in its present form, because the stakes are very high. At stake, of course, is the vehicle industry itself, which is already experiencing a decline in 1986. Such declines have an abnormal impact on South Australia. Dealing with the last point first, it should be noted that approximately 40 per cent of all new vehicle sales are fleet sales. Of all new vehicles sold, South Australian car plants are responsible for the production of 25 per cent of Australian vehicles. If one adds to that the fact that South Australia has only 8.3 per cent of the population, some simple arithmetic says that any impact on vehicle sales will hit South Australia three times as hard as the national average. South Australia has already experienced problems in this area. The impact of the Chrysler rationalisation and the closure of the General Motors-Holden's Ltd plant at Woodville have already hit South Australia.

One of the suggestions that have been made is that a significant downsizing of vehicles may result from this tax. The shift would be from six-cylinder to four-cylinder models. The fear is that the shift would be from locally produced models to imported ones. The impact of such a shift, if it were on a grand scale, would seriously undermine the Government's car industry plan or, as it is widely known, the Button plan. The basis of the Button plan is high volume sales of locally produced motor vehicles. Two options which could be exercised would prove disastrous. There could be a shift to imported models or fleet purchasers might not renew fleets at all.

No doubt what the Opposition wants to lay at the feet of the Government is that all of the decline in sales so far this year is the fault of the proposed new tax. The sales figures of 685,000 units for 1985 involved not only greater consumer confidence because of the economic improvement but also people buying in advance of more costly lead free models and before the impact of the depreciation of the Australian dollar on vehicle prices. Certainly there is no doubt that sales figures for 1986 will probably be lower than in 1985, which was a record year for many reasons and would be hard to duplicate in 1986. Moreover, a significant downturn in sales or a shift to imported models will have employment impacts in the vehicle industry. As to the extent of this impact, we have all sorts of wild and woolly figures which the doomsayers opposite wish to latch on to.

The one thing that is absolutely essential is that the Government give serious consideration not to the principle of this tax but to how such a measure can be implemented. It is essential for the vehicle industry, to which this Government has shown every commitment in the Button plan, that this tax structure not create an environment in which locally produced models are unduly or savagely hit. Furthermore, if such changes take place, South Australia-a State that has already paid part of the price of the vehicle industry restructure-will be severely hit. The point remains, though, that the Opposition is not interested in helping the vehicle industry, except in that it promises a convenient mask for the defence of what is really at stake-tax avoidance for its high income constituents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating as a matter of urgency the need for changes to the proposed fringe benefits tax because of tax's adverse impact on the Government car plan and the threat posed by the tax to thousands of jobs in the vehicle industry. We have heard from the South Australians Senator Jessop and Senator Foreman and we are now about to hear from the Victorians, as I am to be followed by that old battler Senator Cooney. Whenever the Government has some sort of matter of public importance and it does not know who else to call on, it calls on the old warrior Senator Cooney because he is a barrister of long standing and can handle a brief, no matter what the Government gives him, even an impossible brief. Unfortunately, his colleague Senator Foreman was unable to handle a brief in the same way. I do not blame him, because I understand that Senator Foreman is a former member of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia and he must be worried about his--
—He is still a member.

—He is still a member, of course. He must be very worried about what his colleagues will say to him about the effect of the fringe benefits tax on their jobs. Senator Foreman was unable to answer the facts and figures produced by my colleague Senator Jessop; nor did he even attempt to make any response to the statement by his State leader, Mr Bannon, who is reported in the Adelaide News of today as demanding that, as a result of the 25 per cent drop in new car sales, the Government should drop the car tax.

SPEECH.PARA: My fear as a Victorian-I hope Senator Cooney will respond to this-is that General Motors-Holden's Ltd will stop manufacturing vehicles in Australia. I understand that that prediction has been made by a large number of people in the motor vehicle industry and that there are signs around Australia, and particularly in properties being put on the market, which indicate that General Motors-Holden's may give away the game in Australia. I do not know where the vehicle building industry and the back bench Labor senators will be if and when that happens, but it is a grave fear.

This fringe benefits tax has resulted from the terrible National Taxation Summit which was held last year. As a result of union activity we ended up with the nasties, and this one is one of the nasties. We said at that time that it was a nasty that would cause grave difficulties to manufacturers in Australia-and here it is.

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, is the Minister responsible for the implementation of the car plan. He has indicated that as far as he is concerned-I will quote Senator Richardson, who quoted Senator Button-`the fringe benefits tax is not my preferred option'. I would agree. It is interesting that Senator Button has not taken any part in the debate today. The explanation was given-I have no doubt that it is true-that he had to attend a meeting of Cabinet. But this debate has already gone on for almost an hour and a half and I presume that it will go on until about 5 o'clock. I would have thought that at some time between 3.15 and 5 o'clock Senator Button could have found time to come into the Senate to tell us why the Government's fringe benefits tax ought to continue. On 29 May 1984 Senator Button detailed to the Senate a car plan with the central aims of:

. . . holding down the price of cars, the reduction of job losses in the short term, the provision of job stability in the industry and long term viability for Australian vehicle and component manufacturers.

That plan had the substantial support of the Opposition. But the headlines in the newspapers today are `Car industry stalls to a 12 year low' and `car sales slump by 25 per cent'. The stories go on to detail the sorry fact that the motor car industry has recorded its worst March sales in 12 years. New car registrations slumped by 25 per cent in the year to 31 March, and according to the latest IDAPS figures, passenger vehicle registrations are down by 24 per cent. The fall has been far in excess of the gloomiest predictions made for the industry with the March 1986 figures being down one-third-33 per cent-on the March 1985 figures.

Fleet and company buyers, traditionally the mainstay of the market, as mentioned by Senator Foreman, appear to be staying away in droves. The manufacturers place the blame on the Federal Government's proposed fringe benefits tax, claiming that it has scared off fleet buyers, or at least made cars a less attractive investment. While I accept that, I stress that the truth is that all the Government's economic policies are damaging the industry through many measures. It is almost as if the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and this Government are determined to attack a number of our major producers-manufacturers in general and primary producers. Today we are debating the effect of this iniquitous tax on the vehicle manufacturing industry, but I might mention in passing that this tax equally imposes additional serious burdens on primary producers. Its consequences have not been thought through.

It is not Senator Button's desire, but the fact is that this tax is being imposed by Senator Button's Government. Today in answer to a question he gave as a reason for the fall in car sales the introduction of unleaded petrol. I suggest that that was a decision which could have been deferred for the industry or that perhaps even another solution could have been found. I believe that there were other solutions. In particular there could have been some sort of system of registration of vehicles going into Melbourne and Sydney, because it is only those two cities which face the problem. Another reason given today by Senator Button as a cause of the fall in car sales was interest rates, but high interest rates are part of this Government's policy; so it is this Government's policy which is creating that difficulty for the industry. Other reasons given were the change to the wholesale tax, which again is being implemented by this Government, and the falling value of the dollar. Again, this Government's policies have caused the massive devaluation. Now we have this fringe benefits tax added to the change in the sales tax, the massive devaluation of the dollar and the record interest rates.
