The result has been that prices of cars in Australia have risen by as much as 60 per cent for some imported models and by more than 10 per cent for popular locally produced models. Because of the fringe benefits tax, the cost to companies of providing vehicles for their employees will rise by as much as $1,200 per car per year, which is an increase of about 29 per cent. That is an additional burden on companies providing vehicles for their employees.

Unions, manufacturers and State governments all forecast massive reductions in the workforce as a result of this Government's actions. The South Australian Government estimated that 4,500 jobs in that State were at risk. The Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries has estimated 10,000 jobs at risk Australia-wide and the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia has estimated that 25,000 jobs are at risk. Whichever figure is accepted, it is clear that many thousands of jobs will be lost in the industry. Of course, as I have already mentioned, we have unleaded petrol, which has added up to $350 to the price of a new vehicle. Notwithstanding all of those things, the real nail in the coffin is the fringe benefits tax. The National Institute of Economic and Industrial Research, which did a study for the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries, the Department of State Development in South Australia and the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation, believes that there will be a total reduction in vehicle sales in 1986 of 90,000-35,000 of which would be attributable to the new taxes imposed by this Government. The report indicates that there will be massive losses of volume sales of Falcons and Commodores. The Button car plan is clearly under threat and it appears that Senator Button has been rolled in Cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has put his finger on the destruct button.
—Yes, he has. In March this year he was quoted in Business Review Weekly, in an article about changes to the fringe benefits tax on cars, as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I think you will find we've arrived at a satisfactory solution.
There is no doubt that Senator Button would not say that today in the light of the evidence produced by the March figures.

It is not only the vehicle industry which is suffering, but manufacturing industry itself must also feel the chill winds of the funeral director Treasurer that this country now has. So must the vehicle component industry, manufacturing industry generally--

TALK.START.PARA: —And the car salesmen.

—And car salesmen, as Senator Jessop reminds me. Automotive dealers recently conducted a survey and they estimated that retrenchments initially will be 10 per cent or 3,600 employees throughout Australia, and in some areas they believe that retrenchments will be as high as 30 per cent. There is no doubt that this Government is pursuing policies which, far from making Australian industry more competitive, enterprising and profitable, which is what Senator Button wants to achieve in the manufacturing sector, are placing millstones around the necks of manufacturers with taxes on employment and industries and support for ambit claims by militant unionists. Employers simply cannot afford the increased costs and taxation burdens which are being imposed by this Government and still remain competitive. The infamous accord has the Government locked in with the ACTU dictating ruinous policies. Recently, in a paper which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) tried to keep secret, Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is necessary for the Government to face economic realities--
and I suggest it takes note of what he said--
The truth is that at the present moment the taxation and economic policies of this Government are a bit like the Mad Hatter's tea party-half right and half wrong.

The trouble is that the half wrong part led by the Prime Minister and Mr Keating and the ACTU has rolled the half right part led by Senator Button, and the result is that we are faced with economic disaster in this industry, the manufacturing industry and our primary industry.

Where is the support from the Government's back benchers? After all, Senator Foreman and other back benchers should be in there supporting Senator Button. But no, what are they doing? They are glibly following the Keating-Treasury taxation line. Those Treasury officials have all those sorts of policies lined up; they have drawers full of policies like this, all designed to extract money from Australian taxpayers. That is the problem with this Government-it has allowed itself to be led by the nose by Treasury officials who say that the solution to the problem is to take more money from the taxpayers of the nation. That is not the solution to the problem. The solution is to reduce the Government's expenditure, and the primary reason that Mr Keating and other members of the Government have rolled Senator Button over the car plan is their failure to exercise discipline and restraint in government expenditure. We have the highest level of taxation in our history, the highest level of real interest rates in at least 60 years, the lowest value of the Australian dollar since World War II, a public debt in excess of $7,000 for every man, woman and child in the nation, and inflation which is twice the average of other Western nations and four times that of Japan and West Germany. I draw attention to the fact that the inflation rate in West Germany is heading towards the zero figure while ours is up at 9 per cent per annum. Yet this Government's insatiable desire for more revenue continues and it resorts to ever more complex and inefficient tax measures to satisfy its demands without any regard for the future or long term effects such as taxes, and I beg the Government to do something about this fringe benefits tax before the motor vehicle industry of Australia collapses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a most interesting debate because the area of difference between honourable senators who have spoken is limited. I suppose it can be labelled as a debate that has endorsed in the most resounding terms the policies of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who represents the policies of this Government on the car industry. I make it clear from the start that the only point the Opposition has picked up is the question of fringe benefits taxes. Everything else has been blessed by the Opposition and by the Australian Democrats-and bless them too. This situation may be unique-I have not read through the Hansards over the years. On how many other occasions has this chamber been so united in its praise of a senior Minister of this Government, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button?

SPEECH.PARA: The one area of disagreement is the fringe benefits tax. Let us look at the fringe benefits tax and see where we go with it. Senator Foreman, in a great speech, indicated that it is part of the tax package. But, says the argument, if we impose a fringe benefits tax on the motor industry, the whole industry will collapse. Presuming that to be the situation for the moment, it is perhaps a sad commentary on the motor industry that the one thing that can bring it to its knees is people who receive the fringe benefit of the free use of a car having to pay tax on it.

Senator Foreman raised the point that if the remuneration were paid by way of cash then tax would have to be paid on it, but because the remuneration is paid by way of a fringe benefit through the use of a car it is suggested that tax should not be paid on it because, if it is paid, the car industry will collapse. Leaving aside the economic consequences of that, what is the morality of it? If a person is remunerated by being given the use of a car instead of by wages, he does not have to pay tax. If that same remuneration is given by way of cash, he or she does pay tax. The reality is that a self-employed plumber who pays for his own vehicle and for the private use of that vehicle does not get tax concessions, whereas the person living next door who works for somebody else does get tax concessions. The Opposition and the Democrats say that that ought to be allowed because the wider benefit is what results from that situation. Is that in fact so? First of all, and here I must agree with Senator Siddons, the statistics that are put forward are not confirmed one way or the other. I agree that those statistics ought to be well established, but the Opposition does not take that position. It says that the statistics being as rubbery as they are does not really matter because it is going to use them to show that there ought to be no tax in the situation of which I have spoken and which Senator Foreman so lucidly explained. Is it fair to use rubbery statistics, statistics that have not been established, to support an argument that one section of the community should get benefits that another section does not? That is the question that has to be asked and has to be examined closely.

The next matter put forward for the Opposition was by Senator Siddons who expressed it perhaps more lucidly than did any other speaker. He said: `This is bad. This tax ought to be modified. True enough we have to get taxes, true enough the Government has to make expenditures but we simply say, along with the Opposition, that the fringe benefits tax the Government will get from the use of cars is wrong'. We ask: `What should we do? How should we collect the taxes? How should we finance the various government expenditures that have to be undertaken?' The answer to that was: `You work it out'. It would have been better, perhaps, when Senator Chaney brought this debate into the House-it is a very proper debate to be brought into the House-and people spoke well and lucidly on this subject, to say: `This is what we say. These fringe benefits are affecting the motor car industry so seriously and we will now show you the way forward'. But that is not the position taken. The position honourable senators opposite put forward is that the car industry is going to be affected by this tax, the Government must work out something. It must go to some other sector of the community and hit it. It must make intrusions elsewhere. The Oppposition does not tell us where to go, but as soon as we make those intrusions elsewhere-and this has been implicit in what has been said-the Opposition will be in here to condemn us.

It is agreed that this Government has done very well in this area. For example, Senator Lewis talks about the infamous accord, but of course the accord was operating last year when the sale of motor cars was at its peak. There has never been a greater number of cars sold in any year than in 1985, when the accord was in the full flowering of its operations. So if we are going to look at the number of cars sold and say that that is the test of whether the accord is working, clearly up until now the accord has been working very well. What has happened to make that situation change? We can look at things in a certain way and quote statements in the Senate which give an impression which may suit the argument. Some quotes have been made from the Australian Financial Review of today, Wednesday, 30 April 1986. It was pointed out that the fleet company buyers appear to be staying away from the market. It is put forward that the manufacturing lobby has blamed the Federal Government's proposed fringe benefits tax, claiming that is has scared off fleet buyers, or at least made cars a less attractive investment. Another paragraph from page 1 of the Australian Financial Review which was not quoted states:

But 1985 was a very good year, and factors such as the introduction of unleaded petrol make it difficult to decide whether the sales slump is a short-term cyclical variation or suggests the market is contracting because of a harsher economic environment.
The significance of the paragraph that was not quoted is that many factors have to be looked at. Simply to rush in on the fringe benefits tax as the panacea for all problems is just short-sighted.

With great respect to the Opposition senators and to Senator Siddons, who all made great speeches, what they are really saying is this: `We will pluck out one element from a variety of elements and say that is the one problem that faces the car industry'. True enough, honourable senators opposite have spoken about unleaded petrol, but all in very muted tones. What those opposite are really saying is that the problems in the car industry are due to one thing and one thing only-the proposed imposition of a tax on a form of remuneration which those opposite say should allow one group of people to benefit over and above others. That is the proposition they put forward, and that sort of proposition gives this Government some concern because it wants to treat people fairly as far as the imposition of taxes goes.

If these other terrible consequences follow, or look as though they will follow, modifications may have to be made. As has become quite apparent, particularly during Senator Richardson's speech, the Government is prepared to look at all those factors. However, even if the Government does make all those modifications which Senator Chaney and Senator Siddons asked for, nevertheless the fact remains that this is a very unhappy situation. It is an unfortunate situation when the only way in which the motor vehicle industry in this country can be saved is by giving tax concessions which will impose an unfair burden on other parts of the community which do not enjoy those fringe benefits. If that is the situation surely it is time that industry in this country looked very closely at itself and looked at the degree of efficiency with which it runs and the initiatives it has taken to see whether perhaps it can lift its own game. It becomes a very sorry state of affairs if that is indeed the situation.

I think it is interesting to look at the newspapers in light of what Senator Lewis said about rumours of General Motors-Holden's Ltd closing down in Victoria. I have looked at the Australian and the Australian Financial Review. I have looked at them again since Senator Lewis suggested that there are rumours afoot in regard to closure. There is certainly no such suggestion in those two papers. It is a story which ought to be run to ground very rapidly, either by having it confirmed or by having it completely put to rest. That sort of thing will not help industry or the security of people employed in the industry if it has currency for any length of time. Certainly if one looks at the publicity about the matter there seems to be no sign of such a closure other than from the people with whom Senator Lewis has spoken.

Something that should be repeated-it is something which Senator Foreman said and which I think Senator Chaney candidly admitted-is that we are dealing today with a narrow part of the tax package. It has to be remembered that this was part of an overall tax package of which, Senator Siddons candidly said, the Australian Democrats approve. When we look at the overall tax package we see that, although some people may be affected, and affected adversely, others will be affected to their benefit. For example, a tax package will give tax cuts to some. It will give tax cuts to those who really over the years have been most subject to the sorts of taxes that have been imposed so far. The pay as you earn taxpayer has suffered as a consequence of the sorts of concessions that other taxpayers have been able to get through arrangements and through both legitimate and illegitimate methods. Therefore, when one looks at this and says that there is an imposition of tax that will affect some people adversely, that is only half the story. As I have said, people who have suffered very badly over the years will get relief. Of course, in September or whenever the tax cuts come through there will be more money available to buy not only cars but also other goods in the community. That will increase the amount of material that manufacturers have available to sell.

Finally, as time is drawing to a close, I think a point should be taken from Senator Chaney's speech. He said that it is to the manufacturing sector that we should look in the future. I think that is correct. It is a matter of developing policies in the country which will help the manufacturing sector. In circumstances in which rural production will not take so much of the market overseas as it used to do and in which the products of mining are not so attractive as they used to be in introducing income into this country, it is the manufacturing group that has to be looked at. It is certainly clear that this Government is very devoted to the fostering and development of the manufacturing industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate on the motion which I moved, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for changes to the proposed fringe benefits tax because of its adverse impact on the Government's car plan and the threat posed by the tax to thousands of jobs in the vehicle industry.

In particular I thank Senator Don Jessop from South Australia and Senator Austin Lewis from Victoria for their support of the motion. Indeed, I thank Senator Siddons from the Australian Democrats for indicating that the Australian Democrats also will support the motion. I do not wish to recanvass the arguments which were put by those who supported the motion, including me, but I want to make some brief comment on the reasons that were put forward by Government speakers for opposing the motion. I think the most consistent thread of opposition that came through in the debate was based on support for the Government's tax package and for the fact that this was an element of the tax package which was presented in very complimentary terms by Australian Labor Party speakers. Honourable senators opposite seem to have forgotten the birth of the tax plan and the rather grubby circumstances under which it came into account. They seem to have forgotten the rather questionable circumstances and qualities of the Government's tax plan.

What happened was that the Government set out fundamentally to reform the Australian tax system. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) produced a White Paper. The Treasurer pronounced that he had a preferred option. That preferred option was one that substantially recast the taxation system in favour of having a much heavier reliance on a broad-based indirect tax. As a part of a broadening of the tax base there was also a series of new business taxes. What happened to this glorious proposal of the Treasurer's was that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) went off with representatives of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. They took out the broadening of the tax base in so far as it introduced a new broad-based indirect tax and left intact only those elements of the tax package which placed new imposts on business.

We all understand why the Prime Minister did that deal with the ACTU. He did it because the politics was that he was not going to have an imposition of taxes on workers, so why not put all the increased taxes on to business? If one looks at the White Paper on tax and the papers that the Government produced about the tax package one will find that the changes that the Government proposes raise in a full year something over $1,300m of tax. Virtually the whole of that comes from employers.

Sure, that makes political sense but what we are now running up against is the fact that it does not make much economic sense. This particular element of the tax package, this particular impost on employers, is simply another way of reducing employment in Australia. It is a job destruction tax package and it might be described in terms of being very noble--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the restaurants. Tell us about the jobs lost in the restaurants. Tell us about the 8,000 jobs.

—I am not interested in the interjections of the Minister for Finance on this matter. His colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) admits over and over again in this place that the new tax will have an adverse effect on the industry and employment in the industry.
—Tell us about the 8,000 jobs.

—I really am not interested in the Minister's interjections because I think his own colleague Senator Button is a much more reliable informant on these matters. I agree with what Senator Cooney had to say. There are limited areas of difference in this debate. I am just sorry that the speakers from the Australian Labor Party showed none of the real concern for the industry that has been evidenced by the Minister, whom I thought they might have supported. I am sorry that that element was totally missing from the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson made the one comment which I think will cause some cheer. He suggested that the door is still open for change. The Opposition also welcomes that possibility. I hope that in the time that remains between now and the introduction of the fringe benefits tax the Government will revise its proposals. The Opposition will be fully in support of revision. Although we will continue, of course, to oppose the tax generally, we certainly will support the idea that it should be revised in some way. I do not know what authority Senator Richardson had to make the statement that he did but I hope he is correct.

Senator Foreman really devoted his speech to trying to suggest that the whole argument was one about protecting high income earning people from tax. That over-simplification is, of course, denied by the very clear arguments that have been put here; it is denied by the statistics which are now available and which show that the industry is suffering; and it is denied by the actions of his own Minister, Senator Button.

I want to mention a couple of other points in regard to what was said by Senator Cooney. The honourable senator suggested that the debate was difficult because, to use his expression, `we were all stuck with rubbery statistics'. I can only say that whilst it may have been true that the debate up till Christmas was one which was in the realms of prediction and therefore where the statistics were of necessity estimates of future activity and, as a result, by definition could be regarded as rubbery, we are now in a situation where we are assessing the first quarter's figures for 1986 which show a very considerable decline in sales and in registrations. We are no longer dealing with theory; we are dealing with uncomfortable fact. Jobs are under threat today, both in industries which service the car industry and in the manufacturing sector. In those circumstances I am sorry to say that we have got beyond rubbery figures. We have got to the situation where there is a genuine problem which the Government simply has to face.

The suggestion that this tax package is one which has the general approval of the Australian Democrats is, I suppose, a suggestion that Senator Cooney was entitled to make because I think, in the broad, that that point was made by Senator Siddons in debate. I can only say that it is not the view of the Opposition that the tax package that has been brought down is fair. I have tried to indicate in a very brief way why we think the tax package is a case of a genuine tax reform package having been hijacked by the trade union movement. Only now is the trade union movement, through unions such as the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia, seeing some of the very unfortunate side effects of what happened last year.

The situation is that a significant impact is being made on an industry which is centrally important to industrial activity in Australia. The Opposition has been generous in its support of the industry Minister in those areas where it believes that he is behaving correctly and in the national interest. We would agree that in some important respects he has tackled long term structural problems in a way which has warranted our support. We have done no more than assess the national interest and ensured that our voices and our votes follow our assessment of that interest. Our deep concern here is that the Government's own actions are sabotaging some of the positive elements of industry policy.

I want to close the debate by saying that I think the most significant, difficult and serious challenge that we face as a nation is in fact to revive the industrial sector of our economy so that we can take part in a competitive way in world trade, so that we can do something about the balance of payments crisis which threatens to engulf other areas of policy in this country. I think this is a central problem for this Government; it will be a central problem for the next government. I regret that in this tax package we are seeing conflict with the Government's better elements of policy. I hope the Senate will support the motion. I hope even more that the Government will comprehend what we are about and will change the policies which are causing some destruction.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I am pleased to rise today to say a few words on the first report of the Cocos Islands inquiry which is being carried out by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The Commission has been asked by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) to conduct an inquiry relating to the level of services and standard of living enjoyed by the Cocos Malay community. This inquiry is being carried out following the decision of the people of Cocos Island to integrate with Australia. That decision meant that the Cocos Malay people acquired the rights and privileges of Australia and in consequence accepted the obligations that these rights and privileges imply. The rights and privileges referred to are principally the right to certain Commonwealth benefits and the right to vote in Federal elections.

Following the decision of the island to integrate, the then Minister for Territories, the Hon. Tom Uren, undertook in early 1984 to see that appropriate measures would be taken to raise services and the standard of living to comparable Australian levels within 10 years and the Commonwealth Grants Commission would be used to review these standards. This report stems from that undertaking. As one of the three Federal members representing the people of the Cocos Islands, I welcome moves to see the standard of living of those people brought into line with those applying in the rest of Australia.

As honourable senators would well know, the Cocos Islands are included in the Northern Territory for the purposes of the people of the islands voting in Federal elections. The point has been made that the ties of the islands with mainland Australia are stronger with Western Australia than the Northern Territory. However, constitutional considerations prevent the islands from being attached to a State for voting purposes, and the Northern Territory was therefore chosen as the electorate which would take in the Cocos Islands. Cocos Islanders now have representation in both Houses of Parliament and participate in Federal elections. Our experience in the Northern Territory has made us familiar with the problems of distance from centres of government, and in the Territory there is certainly an appreciation of the need to ensure that territories enjoy living standards comparable with those of the States. Indeed, the Commonwealth Grants Commission has been called upon by the Commonwealth to determine the levels of funding to be provided to the Northern Territory. In doing so, it has had cause to consider the costs involved in providing services in the Northern Territory which are not appreciably different from those provided in the States.

I might say that the successful development of the Territory since self-government was introduced in 1978 has in some measure been as a result of the insistence of the people of the Northern Territory that the Grants Commission be the arbiter of its financial arrangements with the Federal Government. I have a great deal of confidence in the capacity of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, having seen it in action over the last few years, to determine what action and assistance will be required by the people of the Cocos Islands to ensure that they achieve parity with Australian living standards.

Briefly, I return to the constitutional problem associated with the attachment of the islands to a State, and make the point that a slightly different question will arise if the Northern Territory is successful in making its bid for statehood. Will the Cocos territory become part of such a new State, and perhaps even return a member or members to the new State legislature? This is, of course, a matter beyond the inquiry of the Grants Commission, but it will be a very important consideration when the time does come to determine how it will be resolved.
Returning to the report, I note that the Commission proposes that the level of services to the Cocos Malay people be defined in the following terms:

Services should be provided for the benefit of the Cocos Malay community at standards that are not appreciably different from the standards of the services provided by the Australian Government (or by State and local governments) to remote communities in other parts of Australia and at a cost to the community that is considered to represent a reasonable effort after taking into account the economic and other circumstances of the Cocos Malay community relative to the community used as a standard and the contribution made by that community.
Considering the level of services provided to some rural areas within Australia, this definition might not hold all that much promise for the people of the Cocos Islands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the first report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. I welcome the approach adopted by the Commission to proceed directly to the preparation of a draft report-that is this report-outlining its preliminary conclusions on the inquiry and its tentative response to the matters raised in the terms of reference, and to circulate this draft report for comment by the parties to the inquiry. I believe that that approach will tend to reduce the regurgitation of submissions that some people would have made had the Commission gone the longer way round.

SPEECH.PARA: At present only some 400 Cocos Malay people live on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. It would seem that such a small number of people would not attract much debate within the Parliament. However, there is no doubt that people from both sides of the chamber have a deep concern for the Cocos Malay people who live on those islands. I am sure that I speak for members of the Government as well as for members of the Australian Democrats and the Opposition when I say that we are concerned for them. In particular, I am concerned that they are being led into a role of dependency on our social security system. I see that Senator Walsh is in the chamber. I hope he will take this to heart, because I know this is the sort of thing which concerns him.

When I was on the islands last year I was disturbed to see that the copra plantation is now being attacked by a beetle because it is not being properly managed. Each mature islander is required to collect 100 coconuts each week. They can just wander around, pick up 100 coconuts and bring them in. That is a very moderate task, but there is no one around managing the copra plantation-in other words, clearing up the debris and the old coconuts around the trees. The result is that this disastrous beetle is now getting into the coconuts. The coconut plantation is less than 25 years old and is perhaps one of the most modern plantations in the world today. In Vanuatu and similar areas most of the coconut trees are in excess of 75 years of age. So there is 50 years of cropping at least in those coconuts. It is a matter which is not being properly attended. As I indicated, it is much easier to be dependent upon the Australian social security system rather than to enter into some active economic attempt to become self-sufficient. There is no attempt to become self-sufficient that I could see, although some building is going on in regard to the replacement of housing. There is not even an attempt by the islanders to grow their own foodstuffs and provide themselves with food. Why should they? After all, at present Australia is flying in all the necessary foodstuffs, clothing and all other requirements. In accordance with the Government's arrangements, these products are being sold to the people without the cost of air freight being added, and they are being sold at what is described as an Australian rural town price, or some such definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —All the products are duty free.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne says, all the products are duty free, so they are very cheap. These people have lost their boat building skills. A beautiful wooden boat was purpose-designed for the islanders by one of the Clunies-Ross engineers who was living on the island at one stage. He purpose-designed this boat for them. The islanders have not built one of those boats for about eight or nine years, so that skill is being lost. There is a desperate need for some economic inducement to be brought into the factors operating one these Islands. I ask the Minister and this Government to apply their minds to inducing some economic factor which might encourage these people to attempt to be more self-reliant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the report on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands inquiry to the Senate and fully endorse the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission contained in the report and the remarks made by Senator Lewis. In 1984, the Cocos Malay people who live on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands voted to join Australia through an act of self-determination under United Nations supervision. They received an undertaking from the Australian Government prior to this vote that the Government would help the Islands to become more self-sufficient economically by broadening the Islands' economic base and that within 10 years the Government would take steps to raise services and standards of living on Cocos (Keeling) Islands to levels comparable to those in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Lewis said, there are approximately 400 Cocos Malay people living on Home Island. The Australian Government administration and departmental employees, with their families, are segregated on the only other populated island, that is, West Island. Enormous anomalies exist between living standards on the two islands, not least because Government officials are fully employed, whereas a considerable proportion of the Cocos Malay work force are not fully employed and, as Senator Lewis has said, are dependent upon what social security system there is. The main source of income of the Cocos Malay people comes from Australian Government activity on the islands. This income may well decline when the current housing program is completed. Thus, the future well-being of the islanders depends very heavily on employment initiatives which have yet to be conceived.

The disparity in living standards between the Cocos Malay people on Home Island and Australian Government employees and their families on West Island has led the Commission and the islanders to propose that the Government would fulfil its pre-self-determination promise to the Cocos Malay people by giving them comparable living standards to those enjoyed by non-local residents on West Island. However, the Department of the Treasury has objected to this, ostensibly hiding behind some rather unconvincing technical objections. I suggest that the real reason is that Treasury considers that public servants on that particular island enjoy a much higher standard of living than average Australians. In my view, to prolong such an obvious local discrimination between racial groups, however it may be caused, must result in envy and ill-feeling in the local people when they face stresses resulting from the pressures of modern Australian living. It is indeed a wise move by the local administrator, local Cocos Malay people and the Commission to adopt as their standard of Australian living the example of the Australian public servants who are based on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. In this way a source of future friction between the islanders and the Australian Government will be removed.

The Australian Government is committed to achieving parity of living standards for the Cocos Malay people with Australians on the mainland by 1994. That leaves only eight years before they must face world scrutiny on their good faith. Three or more of these years will pass by until the Commonwealth Grants Commission completes its inquiry-this report is just the first part of it-into how this will be achieved. Yet another year at least is likely to pass while administrative procedures can be set up. Hence, in the end only four years will remain to complete the full program and to introduce the Australian way of life into this isolated community.

I fully endorse the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission that a three-year program be undertaken immediately before the final reports in 1989 so that changes can be introduced gradually and not hurriedly, in the final three years, after the Government has had time to consider the final report. Time is of the essence, as the wheels of administration are apt to turn very slowly, especially when Government expenditure is necessary. I believe that we should not bow to the Treasury pressure to wait until the last minute. So while commending this report to the Senate, I urge the Government to finalise the terms of reference as soon as practicable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time available I would like to refer briefly to a couple of points already made relating to so-called dependency of the islander community on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. I point out that no unemployment benefit is paid to anyone in that community at the request of members of the community because they are seeking to avoid dependency. As a result, they are, in fact, living on very low incomes. Regarding food costs, I point out that the same subsidisation applies to the people who live on West Island, who are very well paid and getting a tax free and duty free income. So it is a very different matter from what was implied by Senator Lewis. I also point out that this is not a draft report. I think there is some confusion there. The report on the Cocos (Keeling) inquiry refers to a draft report but this is, in fact, a first report. A previous draft report has already been circulated and discussed.

SPEECH.PARA: I am speaking today because as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources I recently had the opportunity to visit the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Although we were there on another matter, the visit gave me the opportunity to experience, to some extent, life on the Islands, and, more importantly, to have some lengthy discussions with the Islanders. I would like to note the respect that I found amongst the community leaders for Mr Justice Else-Mitchell. The way in which the inquiry was carried out and his willingness to consult in a co-operative way and to take time over that consultation was very much appreciated. This report has been eagerly awaited by the leaders of the Island community, who I note are referred to in this report as Cocos Malays. That is not their preferred name because in fact the only permanent Islanders are those people of Malay extraction, but that was many years ago.

The report discusses at length the question of how a standard of living can be set as an aim. In fact, the Commission determined to defer that decision until 1989 and to consult in the meantime with the Department of Territories and other interested parties and to visit the Island, probably on an annual basis, to see developments there. I found it difficult to understand the Treasury comments about this matter, which are quoted at some length in the report. Indeed, I wonder whether the Treasury officials have very much knowledge of the history of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands or the situation that applies there at present.

I do not think one can look at Cocos without looking at its history. Its history is very relevant to the situation there now because Cocos has gone from what was virtually a feudal society, to put it at its kindest, a few years ago to one where there is full Australian citizenship. There are no adult members of the community who have had anything like what we would call an adequate education. Most of the community leaders, in fact, cannot read or write, and that is an indictment of the previous regime under the Clunies-Ross family. There are people there who can relate what it was like to work for plastic tokens, what it was like to be punished if one spoke to outsiders without the permission of Mr Clunies-Ross. I think that needs to be borne in mind when discussing the present situation.

There is a massive deficit, in social terms, to be made up. For example, I was surprised to find recently-I think this shows the general lack of understanding back here on the mainland about conditions-that Islanders are ineligible for a secondary allowance because they are not taxpayers. These people would not be taxpayers if they lived on the mainland because their incomes do not reach the taxable level. However, mainlanders are not denied benefits because they do not pay tax. I am pleased to say that the Department of Territories is looking at that anomaly, now that it has been pointed out, with a view to solving the problem. There are other inequities that are evident, particularly in education and health, and I am pleased to note what the Commission said-to save time I will not read it-about departments and others working towards a better situation over the next few years.

It is not going to be easy, for the historical reasons I have mentioned, to solve the long term economic problems of the community. Even the problem of the coconuts is not as simple as Senator Lewis suggested because we had expert advice that the coconuts are not of good quality and that the soil is probably not very suitable for a high yield anyway. The only reason it was an economic proposition before was because the people were not being paid, or were not being paid in the terms that we understand.

The Commission is clearly aware of the economic and social problems. I welcome the report and hope that its recommendations on the way the departments should proceed, not only towards the review in 1989 but also towards the Government's aim of raising the standard of living to Australian levels by 1994, is well heeded and acted upon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the vote by the Cocos Malay population on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands for integration with Australia in an act of self-determination, Australia made an undertaking that the standard of living of the Cocos Malay people would be raised to the Australian standard within a period of ten years. This first report on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands by the Commonwealth Grants Commission is in response to a letter by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) of August 1984, as I recall it, to the Grants Commission asking that it inquire into that reference. That is totally and wholly desirable, but whether it ought to be the task of the Grants Commission to set out what might be described as a socialist blueprint is another matter. What comparable standard one should use is a further matter. The Minister's letter, in its terms of reference, specifically envisaged the possible adoption of the standards of a comparable community in an isolated part of Australia. What that isolated part of Australia might be is, of course, anybody's guess. The Chairman of the Western Australia Local Government Grants Commission suggested that the town of Laverton in Western Australia ought to be the model upon which the Commission based its recommendations.
—It is hardly isolated in the same way.

—It is not isolated in the same way, but it is isolated with the same disadvantages and liabilities. However, ultimately the Grants Commission decided that a comparable community ought to be that of West Island, which is part of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands but is that part on which the whites reside as distinct from the Cocos Malays, who are quite separated and quite segregated and who live in splendid isolation on Home Island. Frankly, if the Commission is to use West Island as a model upon which it structures the lifestyle and the standard of living of the Cocos Malays, I could not think of a worse comparison. In fact, as the Treasury said in its submission:

SPEECH.PARA: While the desires of the Cocos Malay community should be taken into account in choosing a standard, the standard chosen should also be acceptable to other Australians, particularly those in other remote communities. It submitted that West Island was not typical of other remote Australian communities in that it was a `Public Service town' and, as a result, the standards of government services provided were higher or involved greater concessions than those provided to other remote communities.

Of course, that is absolutely the case. I think that by any standards West Island is a very bad example. The real challenge for the Grants Commission is to find a definition of `standard of living'. My primary concern is that Home Island will end up as a classic example of a social welfare community with the local people lacking in skills, occupations, initiative, incentive or a substantial future. If the standard is to be based on the West Island model, that is absolutely certain to be the case.

To my knowledge there is not a single person employed either on West Island or on Home Island who is employed by other than the Commonwealth Government or the local co-operative, which in turn is funded by the Commonwealth Government. When the building program runs down, that level of employment will drop away dramatically. It is sad to see what has been a healthy, robust economy deteriorate. The world market for coconuts is responsible for that, but perhaps the coconut plantations at Cocos ought to be not dissimilar to the rural economies in Australia and be provided with some sort of short to medium term assistance.

Perhaps the answer, in many respects, is tourism. It is an idyllic island. Provided that tourism is sensibly and carefully approached with a sensitivity to the environment and the people of the Islands, it seems to me that that is a worthy way of achieving some sort of income. I fear, frankly, that the Cocos (Keeling) Islands will end up very much like the Torres Strait Islands, where the local people rely exclusively upon social welfare benefits. The one blessing, of course, is that because they are of the Islamic faith, they do not rely on alcohol as some sort of compensating crutch.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES COMMISSION AND ANSETT TRANSPORT INDUSTRIES LIMITED

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Australia should be the country with the most well developed aviation industry in the world-we have vast distances to travel and we have good flying weather-but unfortunately, this is not the case. Aviation in Australia has been hamstrung by two factors-one is the dead hand of the Department of Aviation bureaucracy and the other is the two airline policy. The joint report of the Australian National Airlines Commission and Ansett Transport Industries Limited deals with the two airlines policy. The paper involves consultations on passenger revenue load factors and aircraft utilisation during 1985 and it points out that during 1985 regular consultations were held at an operational level to minimise the impact of fluctuations in passenger demand on aircraft utilisation. Nowhere does it say anything about consumer convenience or lowering fares. What both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines are concerned about is keeping their aircraft utilisation at a very high level so that they can make more money.

We have heard much in this place and outside it about parallel schedules and how they cause inconvenience and overload facilities. It all has to do with keeping the aircraft full for profits. We desperately need some competition. East-West Airlines Ltd is trying to furnish that competition. East-West is not taking any passengers away from Ansett and TAA. It is in fact creating new passengers, people who have not flown before, because it is giving a cheap, fast and enthusiastic service. People working for East-West believe in what they are doing. East-West now wants to buy three new Boeing 737s from the Boeing company in Seattle. It has Federal and State approval to run a service in Queensland, but it cannot get the aircraft. Why can it not get the aircraft? It is because on 1 April Ansett applied to the High Court of Australia for an injunction to prevent the Federal Government from giving such approval. Ansett was later joined in that matter by TAA.

What we desperately need in this country is deregulation. Deregulation, according to Ansett and TAA, will lead to aircraft crashes, lack of service in remote communities and higher fares; but in fact the opposite is true. In the Canberra Times of 15 April 1986 a visiting United States economics professor was quoted as saying:
The deregulation of the airline industry in the United States had had a favourable impact on services to small communities and the fares charged . . .

Professor Clinton V. Oster of the University of Indiana pointed out that about 500 small communities in the United States had regular airline services and a study of 300 of them had shown that a better service had followed deregulation. Deregulation has not caused any increase in aircraft accidents in the United States of America. It has, in fact, caused increased services, lowered fares and increased employment in the aviation industry. We desperately need that sort of go-ahead thinking in Australia. The Government, however, is loath to bite the bullet. For one thing, the Government is not keen to take on Sir Peter Abeles and Mr Rupert Murdoch. For another thing, the Government has a vested interest in protecting TAA. It is high time the burden of high air fares and inconvenient service was lifted from the backs of the Australian people. It is time to dump the two-airline policy.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 17 April, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 9 April, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee was made after consideration by that Committee of the Artificial Conception Ordinance 1985. That Ordinance was considered by the Committee under its terms of reference and on 13 February this year the Committee Chairman, Senator Cooney, gave notice of a motion for disallowance of the Ordinance to enable it to be properly considered. The Committee obviously gave the Ordinance a great deal of consideration and was not in a position to report to the Senate until the final day upon which the Senate could disallow it. The Committee then gave notice of its intention to withdraw its notice of motion for disallowance. Obviously, any member of the Senate could have taken over, as is the custom, that disallowance motion. I was considering taking that action, but I believed that it would not be appropriate since the matter would have been, as it were, lumped on to honourable senators without their being given an opportunity to give mature consideration to the issues involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The more I think about the question, the more I agree with what the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee has said; that is, that these issues deserve searching consideration by the Parliament. What are the issues raised by the Artificial Conception Ordinance? They are issues of absolutely vital importance not only for those children born by virtue of the procedures described in the Ordinance but for the whole of this nation. The procedures outlined by the Artificial Conception Ordinance are defined in the interpretation clause, clause 3. They are:
(a) artificial insemination; or
(b) transferring into the uterus of a woman one embryo derived from an ovum fertilized outside her body.

Those are the procedures with which this determination is concerned. It is concerned only with the parentage of the children born as a result of those procedures. The fact is that the parentage of those children is a very important matter not only for those children but also for the law. In the Artificial Conception Ordinance the biological parent is presumed not to be the parent of the child. I understand the argument that has been advanced for that proposition. I am also aware of some arguments that have been put forward for the other proposition. Suffice it it to say that I am completely aware of the arguments that are put forward in favour of the proposition which has exercised the Government's mind in this regard.

However, we are dealing with the effects of procedures the nature of which this national Parliament has not come to grips with-for example, artifical insemination by donor. I have not heard a debate in this Parliament on that question. It has simply been left to the scientists. As has been stated in the professional journals, we are simply applying to human beings the science that has been developed for animals. Suffice it to say in the very short time that I have that there has not been intelligent discussion at legislative level on these very important questions. This Ordinance is an attempt by the Government to pick up some of those pieces and at least to define, for the purposes of the law, who are the parents of the children who are born as a result of those procedures.

I have previously spoken in the Senate about how we are avoiding a comprehensive debate on the fundamental implications of ordinances of this nature. I said that introducing piecemeal amendments in isolated ordinances or Bills was certainly not the way to deal with such fundamental issues. I am pleased to say that the Regulations and Ordinances Committee has acknowledged that problem in its report, as it has done on previous occasions. I have a fistful of examples of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee stating that it is contrary to democratic principles for the Government to deal with major matters of national policy by way of subordinate legislation. Indeed, on this occasion, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, on page 6 of its report, states:
These issues deserve searching consideration by Parliament.

It suggests that one vehicle for the consideration of these issues could be the debate on the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentations Bill 1985 after the report has been brought down. I do not quite agree with that proposal, because that Bill deals only with the question of experimentation on human embryos. It does not go into the other questions. Nevertheless, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee emphasises the need for a thorough-going debate on these questions and the need for them to be determined by substantive legislation and not by subordinate legislation.

Other aspects of the Ordinance are of concern. For example, as is pointed out on page 22 of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee report, the Ordinance applies to de facto couples. A woman in a de facto relationship is under the same definition as a married woman. Again, that definition is something that has slipped through by regulation and it was not determined after a thorough-going debate by this Parliament. Every honourable senator should be aware of the justification advanced by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that the removal of legal responsibility may facilitate better record keeping by eliminating the legal consequences of the eventual identification of genetic parents. However, I really do not think that the Attorney-General could have understood what he was signing when he wrote his letter to the Committee as detailed on pages 52 to 55 of the report. The Attorney-General stated:

. . . the Ordinance may in fact encourage proper record keeping and participation in AID and IVF programs because it removes concerns which a potential participant may have in relation to future responsibilities for the child born as a result of their donation of gametes.

As the Committee has rightly pointed out, the complete severance of the links between the genetic donors and the resulting children in the future affects the legal and biological definitions of incest. The Committee warns that it could create a variety of emotional and physical risks for the offspring of persons who were artificially conceived. Despite the claim of the Attorney-General--

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Dolphins and Whales in Captivity

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Senator Georges:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to complete my remarks on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on dolphins and whales in captivity. Although there are a dozen good sections within the report, there are three which I find I am unable to support. I support the dissenting report, but I go even further than that. The main report recommends that we no longer capture whales or dolphins, because they are now breeding in captivity, that we no longer import any and that we gradually close down the dolphinaria that already exist in Australia. The dissenting report disagrees with the final recommendation and says that regulations can be formulated to continue running dolphinaria in this country. It recommends that no more licences for dolphinaria be issued, and that no more dolphins or whales be imported. I do not see why we should deny ourselves or the whales or the dolphins the opportunities that would exist if we captured more, providing we were able to look after them, or if we imported them.

SPEECH.PARA: The last time I was speaking on this issue I described to the Senate the enormous affinity that exists between whales and dolphins and man. I told honourable senators that I had had a swim with some whales and dolphins. I found that they take great care of one and would not harm one for the world. I recounted how in the past they had been able to pilot ships quite safely in and out of ports. I remember I cited the case of Pelorus Jack, who used to guide ships in the Cook Straits. I referred to the many stories in The Killers of Eden about whales that had helped the whalers operating out of Eden.

I imagine that it would be perfectly easy to introduce a set of regulations that would ensure that these animals were not exploited adversely. For example, we could work out how much sea space they need in dolphinaria. Their feeding could be taken care of. The quality of the water, the condition of their bodies, their feeding, their breeding and even the hours they work are all facets that could quite easily be regulated to see that they are not adversely affected by capture.

One thing I point to is the general thrust of this report, because many reports coming out now are opposed to our contacts with animals, be they farm animals, pets or animals in circuses, zoos and rodeos. I think that the people who look after these animals will have to become more vocal and will have to be able to explain and justify their contacts with animals to ensure that they are not exploited adversely. I go further than the dissenting report. I say that we should be able to issue more licences for dolphinaria. We should be able to import dolphins and whales, and we should be able to breed more dolphins in Australia.
Debate (on motion by Senator Cooney) adjourned.
