The speech read as follows-

The primary purpose of the Bill I am introducing today is to amend the law relating to partial take-over bids. The Bill also makes certain other amendments to the law relating to the disclosure of substantial shareholdings.

I am introducing this Bill pursuant to the Commonwealth's obligations under the co-operative companies and securities scheme. A detailed description of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated.
Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme

The Formal Agreement executed by the Commonwealth and all the States on 22 December 1978 provides the framework for a co-operative Commonwealth/State scheme for a uniform system of law and administration regulating companies and the securities industry. The scheme covers the relevant law operating in the six States and the Australian Capital Territory. The Northern Territory Government has now joined the co-operative scheme and is in the process of drafting legislation to apply Commonwealth companies and securities legislation.

In accordance with the Formal Agreement, this legislation has been agreed to by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. If passed by this Parliament, it will have the effect of automatically amending the corresponding State companies and securities legislation.
Outline of Proposals

Subject to some modifications agreed by the Ministerial Council, this Bill will implement recommendations made by the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee (CSLRC) in its report on partial take-over bids. The CSLRC reported to the Ministerial Council following consideration of public submissions on a discussion paper on partial take-over bids issued in March 1985.

The takeover amendments in the Bill are essentially about equity amongst all shareholders in a target company-they are not part of the broader debate whether we have too many or too few takeovers in Australia. The Bill should not be read by the investment community as a signal that the Government has adopted a general anti-takeover position. The Government recognises that the takeover process, which involves the maximisation of returns on assets employed, is a crucial ingredient of a healthy economy and long term growth in output and employment.

The amendments are not designed to prohibit partial takeover bids but to remove the problems identified by the CSLRC in relation to pro rata partial bids. Since the announcement of the proposed reforms in December 1985 the Ministerial Council has received strong representations from both business and employee groups that the amendments be enacted as soon as possible, without the usual exposure of draft legislation, because of a possible spate of pro rata bids launched in an endeavour to pre-empt the proposed legislation.
I draw your attention to some of the more important proposals contained in the Bill.
Partial Take-Over Bids

At present, a bidder may make a partial take-over bid by making offers for a specified proportion of each shareholder's holding (a proportional bid) or for all or a part of the holdings of each shareholder up to a specified maximum proportion of the capital of the company (a pro rata bid). I understand that most partial bids in Australia have been structured on a pro rata basis.

The Bill will confine partial bids to proportional bids. This will reduce both the coercive pressures on shareholders to accept partial bids and the uncertainty faced by a shareholder as to the number of shares which will eventually be bought by the bidder. The Bill will deem prospectively any existing pro rata bid at the commencement of the legislation to be a proportional bid. The Ministerial Council considers that this approach is justified on the grounds that the proposed legislative changes were announced in early December 1985 and because of the concern and belief in the market place that a large number of pro rata bids would be launched before the enactment of the legislation in an attempt to pre-empt the proposed reforms.

The Bill also addresses the problem of pre-bid escalation agreements. Under such agreements, pre-bid sellers obtain the advantage of selling their shares to the bidder as well as participating in any premium later offered under the bid. Other shareholders do not enjoy such benefits. Under the Bill, any escalation agreement entered into by a bidder in the 6 months prior to a bid may not be triggered by higher prices offered under the bid. This rule will apply whether the bid is a partial bid or a full bid.

The opportunity has also been taken in the Bill to clarify the existing policy underlying s. 25 of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980. That policy is that there can be no so-called `multiplier effect' permitting a larger proportion of acceptances to be made in relation to an original block of shares where the offeree shareholder accepts a proportional bid and then sells the balance of his shares in the target company to another person, who in turn accepts the offer for a proportion of the shares he has purchased.

In addition, a company will be entitled to include in its articles a provision requiring a shareholder plebiscite before a partial bid may proceed. The Ministerial Council believes that such a shareholder plebiscite will reduce the coercive pressures on shareholders to accept a partial bid.
Disclosure of Substantial Shareholdings

Shareholders who acquire interest in 10% or more of the voting shares of a company (that is, a `substantial shareholding') are required to notify the company and provide detailed information about those interests. Subsequent changes must also be notified.

A survey of market participants conducted by the National Companies and Securities Commission indicated that these provisions, by requiring detailed notification each time the smallest change in a substantial shareholding occurs, are creating a major paperwork burden for companies and shareholders while often providing information of little or no value.

The Bill contains amendments to the companies legislation to impose a threshold below which a change in the level of a substantial shareholding need not be notified. The amendment will require a change to be notified only where it involves the acquisition or disposal of interests in 1 per cent or more of the voting shares in the company. This will remove the burden of disclosing and recording insignificant changes and at the same time assist the provision of more meaningful information to the company and shareholders.
Financial and Regulatory Impact Statement
The changes made by this Bill should not have any financial impact on Government revenues and expenditure.

The proposals on partial take-overs can be expected to improve the position of the small shareholder although the benefits are difficult to quantify. The proportional bid route is not `costless' for the bidder to the extent that it does increase his risks. However, it is impossible to quantify such costs.
The proposals on the disclosure of substantial shareholdings should result in cost savings to companies.
The Government commends this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes various amendments to Customs and excise laws to implement government decisions which, in particular, alter the arrangements relating to concessions on goods re-imported after repair or renovation, provide for the termination of compulsory maturation for brandy, whisky and rum and remove a sex discrimination provision in the Excise Act. A number of other amendments of a technical or administrative nature have been included in the Bill and I will provide brief details of the more important of these in a few moments.

The provisions of clauses 16 to 18 which introduce new procedures into the Customs Act for concessions on goods re-imported after repair or renovation follow the Government's acceptance of the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations contained in its Report on Re-import Concessions dated 16 November 1984. That report recommended a number of new arrangements for re-imported goods, the bulk of which were implemented on 22 November 1985. At that time it was announced that the proposals affecting concessions on goods re-imported after repair or renovation would be delayed until necessary amendments could be made to the Customs Act.

It would be useful if I were to first outline the measures which were implemented on 22 November 1985 by way of Customs tariff proposals. From that date any goods or parts of goods re-imported without change to their identity have been eligible for duty free entry if all taxes and charges payable on original entry have been paid and not refunded. This duty free eligibility applies to re-imported goods or parts irrespective of the length of time the goods have been overseas, and irrespective of whether the goods or parts had entered the commerce of another country or changed ownership. Additionally goods re-imported after being repaired or renovated are now assessed for duty on the repair value only and the rate of duty applicable is the rate applying to the parent goods if there has been no change in the identity of the parent goods. Finally, any goods repaired overseas, or replaced, under a specific warranty may be re-imported duty-free.

The provisions of this Bill complete the re-import package by authorising the Comptroller-General of Customs to make a commercial tariff concession order which will permit duty free entry of goods re-imported after repair or renovation if it is established that the repair or renovation is not capable of being performed in Australia in the normal course of business. Provision is made for orders to be made in respect of repairs or renovations to particular goods or particular repairs or renovations to a class or classes of goods. The Comptroller-General also has the discretionary power to refuse to make an order if the making of the order would be likely to have a substantially adverse effect on the market for any goods or services in Australia or would not be in the national interest. Concessions for goods repaired overseas have operated for many years but have lacked the precision and simplicity proposed by the new arrangements. The new arrangements are to be inserted into part 15A of the Customs Act, which contains the provisions governing the administration of the commercial tariff concession system.

By utilising the established commercial tariff concessions system in that part of the Act the Government believes that Australian repairers will be given a much better opportunity to demonstrate their capacity. Applicants for the concessions will need to fully document and support their applications. If a prima facie case is established, notification of a proposal to make the relevant tariff concession order will be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. The concession order will only be issued if after 28 days following publication, no objections to the order have been received.

The provisions of Part VI of the Bill propose to terminate the compulsory maturation requirements for brandy, whisky and rum as currently contained in the Spirits Act. I should emphasise that the termination will not take place until 1 April 1990. Following a review of regulations applicable to spirituous beverages the Government announced on 4 May 1984 that the compulsory maturation of the spirits would be retained at that time but that the issue would be examined with a view to abolition in three to four years.

The Government's examination of the issue, which involved, in particular, health and quality standards, revealed a significant divergence of industry opinion on the question of compulsory maturation. Firms with a tradition of producing matured spirits favoured retention while other interests suggested that the market, and not government regulation, should be the determining factor. The Government considers that removal of compulsory maturation will allow producers to prepare unmatured products if the market dictates such a requirement. Production of matured products could continue, commanding whatever price the market would pay. Removal of the requirement is also consistent with the Government's policy to remove unnecessary business regulation. It should be noted, however, that States and Territories, which are currently responsible for food and beverage standards in Australia, still require maturation under State and Territory law. Further, some investment in wooden casks has been made for maturation purposes. In view of this, we have decided to postpone termination until 1 April 1990. This will, we believe, provide more than adequate time for any necessary adjustments to be made within the industry.

The amendment proposed in clause 24 of the Bill proposes to bring the Excise Act into harmony with section 40 of the Sex Discrimination Act. If the Excise Act is not amended as proposed, section 40 of the Sex Discrimination Act will render search of persons under the Excise Act unlawful. The amendment therefore proposes that where persons are to be searched for the purposes of the Excise Act they are only to be searched by persons of the same sex as the person to be searched. Section 104 of the Excise Act currently restricts searches of females by a female searcher but would permit a female searcher to search a male person.

I now turn to the more important amendments of a technical or administrative nature. Part II of the Bill proposes to amend the Coal Excise Act to now provide that the excise duty imposed by that act is to be paid on the amount of coal sold by a producer as shown on the invoice document provided by the producer to the purchaser. The legislation currently requires excise to be paid on the quantity of coal produced and removed from mine. In today's operations some producers have difficulty in complying with this requirement, since beneficiation or raw coal to meet higher quality standards often takes place at locations remote from the producer's mine. This contrasts with the situation in the industry at the time the excise was imposed in 1949 when practically no beneficiation took place. The amendments will align the Act with current industry practice and will have no effect on the amount of duty paid by the producers.

The proposed administrative amendments in Part III of the Bill amend the Customs Act as a consequence of the introduction of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill 1985, currently before the Senate. That Bill proposes to protect Australia's heritage of cultural objects and extend certain forms of protection to the cultural heritage of other nations so as to enable Australia to accede to the 1970 United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation convention on the means of prohibiting and preventing the illicit import or export of cultural property. Regulations under the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act will specify the material to be controlled. The amendments now proposed to the Customs Act provide the necessary authority for officers of Customs to seize cultural objects as notified by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment when those objects are subject to the control of the Customs.

Finally, the significant technical amendment in Part V of the Bill proposes to bring the provisions of the Excise Act into line with the Customs Act provisions which relate to entry of ship's and aircraft's stores. The proposed new section 58d of the Excise Act makes provision for the regulations to exempt goods from the requirement of entry as ship's and aircraft's stores in certain circumstances. It is intended that exemptions will apply, for example, in cases where stores are removed and placed on board aircraft under Customs supervision and permission.
Financial Impact Statement
The provisions of this Bill have no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The main purpose of this Bill is to incorporate into the Excise Tariff Act 1921 a number of excise tariff proposals requiring enactment following tabling in the Parliament.

The Bill also proposes to introduce a new item into the Tariff Act as a consequence of the introduction of inwards duty free shopping at international airports and to vary the excise duty concessions available to vice-regal persons following a review of existing arrangements.

Clause 3 of the Bill which operates from 23 May 1985 abolishes the excise duty on wine produced with added sugar and introduces revised definitions and restructured tariff items dealing with brandy, whisky, rum and liqueurs.

The item relating to wine produced with added sugar was introduced in the 1930's for the purpose of inhibiting the manufacture of wine made by adding sugar before fermentation. State legislation prohibits this practice, rendering the provision in the excise tariff redundant. The new definitions and restructured tariff items relating to brandy, whisky, rum, and liqueurs stem from a detailed review of legislation covering wines and spirits undertaken jointly by the food standards committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council and Commonwealth government departments. The provisions in this Bill bring the Excise Tariff Act into harmony with new standards for wines and spirits accepted by the Government and being adopted by State governments.

The changes in clauses 4 and 5 of the Bill alter the excise duty rates on manufactured tobacco and on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) with effect from 20 August 1985 and 1 October 1985 respectively. Progressive increases in the tobacco duty were foreshadowed in the 1983-84 Budget when measures to progressively align the excise rate for tobacco with that applying to cigarettes and cigars were announced. The increase in clause 4 of the Bill represents a further step towards elimination of the difference between the relevant excise duty rates. The increase in the excise duty on LPG in clause 5 is made in accordance with the Government's LPG excise policy. Briefly that policy provides for the LPG excise rate to be calculated on the basis of 60 percent of the amount by which the weighted average price for naturally occurring LPG exceeds $147 per tonne. The average price is calculated as a weighted average of the price received from exports and local sales of LPG.

The proposed new item 21 of the Tariff as contained in clause 6 of the Bill is part of the legislative package necessary to facilitate the introduction of inwards duty free shopping at international airports in Australia. The provisions of item 21 will remove the excise duty on any excisable portion of the limited quantity of airport shop goods available as passenger concessions if purchased at inwards duty free shops. The bulk of the legislative package was passed by the Parliament in the budget sittings last year. It contained amendments to the Customs Act, the Excise Act and various sales tax laws. Amendments to appropriate regulations are being undertaken separately and it is proposed that the total legislative package come into force on 1 May 1986.

Inwards duty free shops which will be located at the airports between the disembarkation area and the Customs barrier will sell only alcoholic liquor, tobacco products and perfume to passengers arriving on international flights. The duty concessions available to passengers will not alter. They are currently 1 litre of alcoholic liquor and 250 grams of tobacco products. There is no specific limit on the amount of perfume eligible for the duty concession, provided the amount does not represent a commercial quantity.

Finally the provisions of clause 7 of the Bill alter the excise duty concessions available to vice-regal persons and their staff. The provisions propose to remove the concessions on articles for the personal use of vice-regal persons, and articles for the official or personal use of staff members who are not Australian citizens.

The existing concessions date back to when Governors and their staff were nearly always appointed from outside Australia. This is now not the case and the Government therefore believes that there is no longer any justification to continue duty concessions on goods for personal use or on goods for staff members who are not Australian citizens. There is no change to the concessions available on goods for the official use of the Governor-General or State Governors or members of their families.
Financial Impact Statement
The alterations contained in clause 3 of the Bill have no direct financial implications.

Increases in the Excise duties on tobacco and LPG as set out in clauses 4 and 5 of the Bill are expected to result in increases in revenue of $3.75 million in 1985-86 and $5 million in a full year in the case of manufactured tobacco and $18 million in the case of LPG in 1985-86.
The introduction of inwards duty free shops is expected to benefit airport concessions revenues by about $5 million in a full year.
The alterations to the vice-regal concessions will have minimal financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

BARLEY RESEARCH LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1986

This Bill provides for an amendment to the Barley Research Levy Act 1980 to increase the maximum research levy rate to 75 cents per tonne. The operative rate within this maximum is set by regulation on the recommendation of the Australian Wheatgrowers' Federation representing barley growers of Australia. The levy is collected at industry's request and held in trust to fund research projects.

The Minister for Primary Industry announced in February 1985 the Government's intention to encourage rural industries to raise the level of their research contributions to 0.5 per cent of their gross value of product (GVP) within five years, and reaffirmed the Government's commitment to match expenditure of the levy contributions from industry dollar for dollar to that level. This followed a thorough review during 1984 of rural research and the contribution of the Rural Industry Research Fund Scheme to this effort.

The Minister made further comment on the need for Government action on rural research in his second reading speeches on the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Bill 1985 on 20 March 1985 and the Rural Industries Research Bill 1985 on 17 April 1985.

The Barley Research Levy Act is one of the few rural industry research levy acts in which the maximum rate is not already at or above the 0.5% of GVP level. The proposed amendment would establish a maximum rate of industry contribution to barley industry research at about 0.5 per cent of the industry's GVP, at current prices. This will give the industry considerable flexibility to increase its research contributions over some years consistent with the Government's policy, but avoid the need for frequent amendments to the legislation.

From the industry's point of view passage of the Bill will ensure that a request by the industry for an operative rate increase, which is effected by regulation, is not delayed by the pressure of legislative business in the Parliament at the time the request is made.

No additional budgetary outlays will result from the amendment itself. However, the Bill would enable the Government to agree to an industry request for an operative rate increase above the current maximum, which would then generate additional matching budgetary outlays. Last year the barley industry sought, and was granted an operative rate increase to 35 cents per tonne. This raised the industry's contribution to its research program to about 0.24 per cent of its GVP. I take this opportunity to compliment the industry on its positive support of this applied research scheme, which is aimed at increasing profitability of producers.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
DRIED FRUITS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1986

This Bill provides for an amendment to the Dried Fruits Levy Act 1971 to increase the maximum research levy rates to $5.00 per tonne of dried vine fruits and to $30 per tonne of dried tree fruits. The operative rate within this maximum is set by regulation on the recommendation of the Dried Fruits Research Committee. The levy is collected at industry's request and held in trust to fund research projects.

The Dried Fruits Levy Act is one of the package of Research Acts under my portfolio in which the maximum rate is not already at or above the 0.5 per cent of gross value of production (GVP) level, and for which I have brought forward amendments here today to bring the rates up to that level.

The proposed amendment would establish a maximum rate of industry contribution to dried fruits industry research at about 0.5 per cent of the industry's GVP, at current prices. This raised the industry's contribution to its research program to about 0.14 per cent of its GVP. I compliment the industry on its positive support of this applied research scheme, which is aimed at increasing profitability of producers.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

This Bill provides for an amendment to the Live-stock Slaughter Research Levy Act 1964 to increase the maximum research levy rate to 15 cents per head for bobby calves, 20 cents per head for sheep, lambs and goats, 50 cents per head for calves and $2.00 per head for cattle and buffaloes. MEAT CHICKEN LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1986

This Bill provides for an amendment to the Meat Chicken Levy Act 1969 to increase the maximum research levy rate to one cent per chicken hatched. The operative rate within this maximum is set by regulation on the recommendation of the Australian Chicken Meat Research Committee. The Meat Chicken Levy Act is one of the package of Research Acts under my portfolio in which the maximum rate is not already at or above the 0.5% of Gross Value of Production (GVP) level, and for which I have brought forward Amendments here today to bring the rates up to that level.

PIG SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1986

This Bill provides for an amendment to the Pig Slaughter Levy Act 1971 to increase the maximum research levy rate to 50 cents per head. The operative rate within this maximum is set by regulation on the recommendation of the Australian Pig Industry Research Committee. The levy is collected at industry's request and held in trust to fund research projects.

The Pig Slaughter Levy Act is one of the package of Research Acts under my portfolio in which the maximum rate is not already at or above the 0.5% of Gross Value of Production (GVP) level, and for which I have brought forward Amendments here today to bring the rates up to that level.

The proposed amendment would establish a maximum rate of industry contribution to pig industry research at about 0.5 per cent of the industry's GVP, at current prices. This will give the industry the flexibility to increase its research contributions over some years consistent with the Government's policy, but avoid the need for frequent amendments to the legislation.

No additional Budgetary outlays will result from the Amendment itself. However, the Bill would enable the Government to agree to an industry request for operative rate increases above the current maximum, which would then generate additional matching Budgetary outlays. Last year the pig industry sought, and was granted an operative rate increase to 20 cents per head. This raised the industry's contribution to its research program to about 0.17% of its GVP. I compliment the industry on its positive support of this applied research scheme, which is aimed at increasing profitability of producers.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
DAIRYING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND PROMOTION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Act 1972. The Act imposes levies in milk and butterfat production for the purposes of funding dairy research, promotion and to finance the operations of the Australian Dairy Corporation.

The Bill will increase the maximum rate of levy for research purposes. The present maxima are 1.2 cents per 100 litres whole milk or the equivalent rate of 30 cents per 100 kilograms of butterfat. The Bill provides for these rates to be increased to 10 cents or $2.50 respectively, the increase will give scope to the industry to have its contribution to research raised progressively by regulation up to 0.5 per cent of its gross value of production (GVP).

The Minister for Primary Industry announced in February that the Government had adopted the objective of raising the level of industry contribution to rural research to 0.5 per cent of GVP within five years and to match that contribution dollar for dollar to that level.

The Australian Dairy Research Committee, supported by the Australian Dairy Farmers' Federation, has requested that the Minister for Primary Industry seek the increase in the maximum rate of levy which is the purpose of this legislation.

Research activity has an important role in enabling an industry to adapt to change. This is particularly relevant for the Dairy Industry which must accommodate itself to those few remunerative markets that have not been destroyed by subsidised dairy products, particularly from the European community.

Increased research effort is also required to assist the industry to continue to improve its production efficiency, to develop new products and to compete with the producers of other countries on export markets and on our own domestic market.

Dairy industry contributions to research have been about 0.05 per cent of GVP over the last three years; that is one tenth of the Government's objective over five years. It is now evident that there has been under investment in research and development in this industry, and there is an urgent need to increase the contribution to assist in improving its viability. The Australian Dairy Research Committee has had to draw heavily on its non-matchable reserves to finance its 1985-86 research program which is at a level of expenditure on research activities no higher than in 1984-85.
In addition to providing for a much increased research program in the future, an increase in the levy will provide funds to rebuild these reserves.

The industry has moved immediately to increase its contribution to research. It has requested an increase in the operative rates to two cents per 100 litres whole milk or 50 cents per 100 kilograms butterfat. An amendment to the regulations will be sought when the new maximum rates are incorporated in the Act. In the meantime, action has been taken by regulation to increase the operative rates of levy to the permissible maximum in the current legislation of 1.2 cents per 100 litres of whole milk and the equivalent of 30 cents per 100 kilograms of butterfat.
It is rewarding that the industry has responded to the Government's objective and taken positive steps towards achieving substantially increased funding of research.

The amendments proposed in the Bill will have no impact on budgetary outlays for the Commonwealth in 1985-86 because the 1985-86 Government contribution to the Research Program has already been approved. Assuming the operative rates are increased from 1 cent to 2 cents or its equivalent, there is a potential budget revenue increase in 1985-86. At the level of production recently forecast by the BAE this revenue increase would be some $330,000 in 1985-86. In a full year and not taking into account any reduction in production, the increased revenue would be about $600,000 making a total revenue from levy in a full year of the order of $1.2m.
The Commonwealth commitment to match expenditure from the increased levy revenue will arise in 1986-87 and future years.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill, the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill, the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill, the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill, the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Amendment Bill. Jonathon Swift once wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . whoever could make two ears of corn or two blades of grass to grow upon a spot of ground where only one grew before, would deserve better of mankind, and do more essential service to his country than the whole race of politicians put together.

He was basically saying that anybody on the land who could increase production was better than all the politicians. These levy amendment Bills are all about encouraging research, to increase production, whether it be livestock or grain. As I indicated, there are seven Bills. They are routine Bills which come before the Parliament periodically to increase the rate of levies applicable to each particular industry.

I will not go into the full details of each Bill, but I will give the maximum amounts by which the levy can be increased. For barley it is 75c per tonne; dried vine fruits, $5 per tonne; dried tree fruits, $30 per tonne; dairying, 10c per 100 litres of milk, or $12.50 per 100 kilograms of butter fat; livestock export, 20c per head for sheep, lambs or goats, or $2 per head for cattle or buffaloes; livestock slaughter, 15c per head for bobby calves, 50c per head for calves, 20c per head for sheep, lambs or goats, and $2 per head for cattle or buffaloes; meat chicken, 1c per chicken hatched-I do not know of any chickens that are not hatched, but that is the terminology in the Bill-and pig slaughter, 50c per head. This legislation will take the levies up to 0.5 per cent of gross value of production. Currently the operating rates vary between 0.1 and 0.2 per cent of the gross value of production. Those rates do not rise automatically-the increases are made as the industry requires and requests of the Government. The increases are handled under these pieces of legislation by regulation. On top of that, the Federal Government subsidises on a dollar for dollar basis up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production.

As has been indicated as recently as today in the report of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the other place, we are facing a corrupt world market situation. For many years the European Economic Community has been dumping subsidised products on world markets and on some of our traditional markets. We are currently facing the situation of the United States Farm Bill allowing the United States to do that same thing. We have learnt recently of a sale of 50,000 tonnes of wheat to our traditional market of North Yemen. Significantly, that sale was concluded on the day the Prime Minister left Australia for the United States of America. That is certainly one of the problems which is facing Australian producers of livestock and grain in this day and age. That has been the case for some time; successive governments have known about it and have tried to come to grips with it. The Prime Minister has recently undertaken a trip in an effort to come to grips with that situation and to draw the attention, particularly of the United States, which has been a friend of Australia, to what the United States Farm Bill could do to our producers. Many of us have spoken to representatives of the United States Government and drawn their attention to this problem. We have pointed out that as well as encroaching on our traditional markets, the United States is itself a traditional market for many of our products. Primary industry is not subsidised in our country and it must compete on a free market basis wherever it can sell its products in the world. The overall situation facing our producers could have quite a deleterious effect on their returns in the near future.

This levy Bill provides money for research, and we hope that some of that research money will also go to promotion, packaging and presentation. It is no use our making the best products in the world or being efficient within the farm fences if we cannot sell our products because they are not packaged or promoted properly. I understand that part of the money raised by this levy will go towards that promotion and packaging. There would not be one person on either side of this chamber who would argue with the fact that the Australian primary producer is efficient. That does not mean to say that continued research is not necessary in order to provide better crops, better strains of livestock, and better counters for diseases amongst all types of produce.

It is necessary that our research be kept up to date and that we are fully aware of world trends in research and in the handling of particular diseases or pests. I cite one instance that occurred recently in Australia-the biological control of groundsel, an introduced weed, which has caused great problems in some country areas. This is particularly so in south-east Queensland, where I have my farm. However, after many years we have released a gall wasp and, while it does not destroy outright the groundsel plant onto which it is released, it certainly prevents that plant from reproducing. That is just one small instance. There are many other pests, both plant and animal, which are bedevilling our primary producers, and coming to grips with these is part of the total scene of making our producers more efficient so that they can compete. One of the big problems facing our primary producers now is the drought which is manifest right through the eastern States. Once again there has been a complete failure of our wet season. I do not know the country areas of New South Wales and Victoria as well as I know Queensland, but I understand that there is very little likelihood of any winter grains being planted this year. I am sure that my colleague Senator Brownhill, who knows that scene better than I do, will speak about that.

On top of all this we have the Government's imposts. Just about every financial statement or Budget the Hawke Government has brought down since it came to power has had a deleterious effect on primary producers. My colleague the honourable member for Gwydir, Mr Ralph Hunt, has indicated that the cost to primary producers since the Hawke Government has been in power is $442m. Our primary producers can compete against almost anything, but when a government takes to them with a big stick, as the Hawke Government has done, it is pretty hard. No Bill on primary industry can go through without mention being made of this Government's attitude to primary producers. Other imposts which this Government has introduced in its various budgetary measures and which affect the manufacturing industry also affect primary producers. The automatic indexation of excise, even though it is rebatable to the farmer, is certainly an impost on the transport operator. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), in answer to a question today, recognised that even though costs might be one thing within the farm gate and even though a farmer might be very efficient, once the product leaves the farm gate he has no control over it and the added costs there are a further burden. It is quite significant that, as I have indicated, a primary producer can be very efficient but the people who handle his produce beyond the farm gate end up making more money out of handling that produce than the farmer who produced it originally.

There are many problems facing rural producers today. Those have been outlined by myself and many of my colleagues in the debates that have taken place in this chamber. The primary producer's terms of trade have declined by 37 per cent over the past 10 years. The return on capital for primary producers this year is estimated at minus 6 per cent. There are plenty of problems. Having said that, I point out that primary producers still contribute greatly to this country's economy. Even with our present massive current account deficit, primary producers are still responsible for about 40 per cent of our export income. So it is essential that proper research be done-that is what these Bills are all about-and that this Government recognise the imposts it has put on primary producers and starts to look at easing that burden, thus enabling those producers to become more competitive on world markets. The Opposition supports these Bills and wishes them a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill 1986 and a number of other levy Bills relating to primary industry. The levies are raised at the request of the industry for the purpose of the development and research of the products involved. From time to time these various Bills come before us to increase the percentages. I wish to look briefly at some of the spin offs of this research and to give a couple of current instances related to the last Bill on the list-the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Amendment Bill 1985. I mention the current efforts by the Australian consortium to export dairy products to Asia by the development of a special milk to suit non-Caucasian tastes. That consortium, which includes the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Australian Dairy Corporation, Sumitomo Chemical Company, Milk Laboratories (Australia) Pty Ltd, APV-Bell Bryant, intends to market lactose-reduced milk powder to Asia. Many Asians find that the sugar or lactose in milk is difficult to digest, so the consortium has developed the process here in Australia to break down the sugar-lactose content.

SPEECH.PARA: This lack of tolerance to the lactose in our milk has obstructed this country's plans for some time to move milk surpluses and in particular to increase our dairy exports in the markets to which we believe we should be exporting, namely, the Pacific Basin and the South East Asian countries. This milk powder is being manufactured at the Drouin Co-operative Butter Factory in Victoria, which has constructed a multi-million dollar plant to process the new product, and I understand that currently a consignment of some 16 tonnes of lactose-reduced powdered milk is being shipped to Singapore. The Australian Democrats wish the consortium all the best in this new export trade, which I think epitomises the type of new ventures that primary industry in Australia is undertaking and will be required to undertake in the future. It is not sufficient in primary industry, as it is not in secondary industry, merely to rest on products which are tried and true. We are faced with changing tastes, changing demands and the need to develop and seek new markets. It is important to look, as the consortium has done in the dairy industry, at the problems in a clear way, and at some stage stop wringing our hands and saying that everybody else is being nasty, and see whether there are opportunities, with vigour, ingenuity and investment, to expand our export trade by developing alternative products. Research can identify the gaps in the overall marketing of our primary products, as it has, for example, in the milk industry. The hindrances to the expansion of the milk trade have been looked at and deliberately removed from the products. To give another example, many consumers still believe that milk contains as much as 20 per cent fat when in fact in Australia the average is about 4 per cent. This type of information could provide a basis for educating the consumer about the nutritional values of milk. This, coupled with better packaging, could produce, here in Australia and in similar markets overseas, another basis for the expansion of our product.

We have to admit that there are changing tastes and demands. Health conscious people are obviously looking at the fat content in milk. We have to provide them with information which is real and genuine, so that they do not have to move away from nutritional products which have formed the basis of a staple diet. These products can then be consumed in the knowledge that they are not causing any harm to health and that they are nutritional. It is not good enough simply to say that we will leave things as they are. We have to pay very close attention to the changing needs and desires in the market.

The Australian Democrats believe that increased research is essential if we are to maximise these opportunities. It is not just productivity we need to improve the situation, but we need to improve our marketing. It is no good producing more and more commodities for overseas markets that are already glutted with and corrupted by the types of things that Senator Collard talked about, particularly the types of subsidisation regimes that are in place in the European Community and in the United States of America. Clearly, we need to plough funds into identifying new markets. As Julian Cribb said in the National Farmer, in one of his very incisive editorials, we need to `supplement our rather inflexible statutory marketing structure with incentives for small companies and individuals to claw out their own markets and beat our competitors to the punch'. If we are talking about the fact that this is a free enterprise society, that is the type of thing we are talking about. Part and parcel of the approach that Julian Cribb has urged, would be to increase the proportion of processed and manufactured foodstuffs and industry materials. The Democrats have always strongly supported the idea that research committees should have a majority voice of producers. The rationale for this belief, which we have put consistently to the Senate, is that it is the grower representatives on those research committees who are most likely to know the current concerns of growers, the current demands for research and the directions for future research.

More importantly, any research that is undertaken can be of value to the industry only if it is implemented. Research on its own is utterly useless. The communication of research means that we need to have people who know what research is being done and know the people who are going to be consumers of that research. Therefore, we believe that the grower representatives on research committees act as salesmen in the area. They communicate the type of research that is being done, the benefits that that research has for the individual producers. Those producer representatives are listened to. They are, after all, representatives of the producer bodies. They are not from some outside group seeking to tell people what they should do and what they should not do. Before we go down the track of changing those research committees and having on them what we consider to be experts we should look at the fact that research must be implemented and used. That requires a selling job. Far too much research done in Australia sits in articles, books and conference papers and is never implemented. We need more innovative research, but also we need that research to be implemented. We should not move away from having on those committees those producer representatives who play that vital and very important role.

There are a number of research and marketing challenges for each of the commodities that we are discussing this evening. We trust that the increased levies provided by these Bills will be used effectively to develop market opportunities, not only in Australia but also in what we believe is our natural market, the Pacific Basin and South East Asia. The major problems remain in terms of international trade with the European Community and with the United States. Recognising those problems, we still need to see what we can do with those massive impediments which currently operate.

Another matter of concern is that 60 per cent of all arable land in Australia is currently threatened by soil erosion. The loss of top-soil in many parts of Australia is disastrous. There is a growing concern that widespread adaptation of practices such as retaining crop cover and stubble will significantly reduce the volume of sediment lost in flood flow. In my own State, as you would know, Madam Acting Deputy President, a very large majority-about 80 per cent is the most recent estimate I have seen-of farmers are retaining stubble in an attempt to reduce erosion. These types of rapidly changing practices in agriculture demonstrate clearly that there is not such a massive gulf between the people in Australia who call themselves conservationists and the people who call themselves primary producers or farmers. The interest of both groups in this major area of conservation is identical; that is, the conservation, the protection and the recovery of the top-soil for current farmers and for future farmers.

With the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill and the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill there are growing concerns. We have had some spectacular victories in recent years in the brucellosis and tuberculosis campaigns. They have proved very successful because of the co-operation of all producers in Australia. We must make sure that their efforts are not pulled down by the lack of efforts of people around them. In research that is being done we need to emphasise herd management, nutrition, and stock death due to the protein deficiencies, which is a particular problem in north Queensland and the Northern Territory. The waste and inefficiency resulting from herd mortality, particularly of calves, is a serious problem, as shown by the statistics. Fairly obviously this demands closer investigation and, again, innovative research. I think it is doubly important that those people carrying out the research do so with regard to the demands of the people in the industry in relation to the problems that arise and the problems they are facing.

At the moment Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation scientists are researching a method of painless, hormonal castration of farm animals, something which I am sure Senator Brownhill, who is to speak next, will have a great deal of interest in, being a member of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I know that that is an area which that Committee has been looking at and working on. I refer also to the Victorian deer breeding industry. A recent research investment by a Victorian company has in fact given Australia a remarkable world lead in venison production. This is quite extraordinary for a country which in fact has only gone into that industry in very recent times. Again, I think it shows the innovative approach that primary industry producers in Australia are able to take and the opportunities that are available to many primary producers.

I mention also the agricultural chemical development branch of the Queensland Department of Primary Industries and its development, in particular, of a new sunflower seed with a better oil quality for the margarine industry. Here, we have the example of a request from a particular manufacturing industry, a feed-back to a government department and the development of a product specifically designed for that particular industry. These co-operative types of ventures which, in the past, have put Australia in the lead in many areas of primary industry are continuing. I believe that they need to be fostered. Again, it is money which comes through the levies raised by the Commonwealth Government that assists us to carry out these types of research. While often it is easy in the media to have a little bit of a poke and a bit of a laugh at some of the types of research that go on, I think it is also very important to remember the enormous contribution to the economy that researchers make. I think that even only those very few examples which I was able to give-due to lack of time-show that.

There are still some areas of concern. The Australian Democrats are particularly concerned that the Federal Government does not shift too many of its resources in CSIRO from research in agriculture to research in manufacturing. Undoubtedly the pressure must exist as a result of the proposed commitment of the national technology strategy to move the Australian economy away from high bulk, low value-added exports towards high value-added goods and services with a high unit value and a low volume. We believe that pressure ought not to take us so far away that the types of innovative research to which I have alluded will in fact be seriously hampered. By and large the Federal Government, through these levies it raises, is the major funder-and will remain the major funder. I think we have to recognise that the tradition in Australia is that governments have always taken that role. While many people seem to suggest that that might be socialist, it is fascinating to see that in this area Australia has always relied on public moneys to produce those types of researches in the primary industry area.

I think we need to be very careful when we are talking about low government. Some comments in this regard were made today in a maiden speech and have been made previously in regard to a variety of other matters. I think that if one is not willing to nominate the areas which one wants to cut out, I think that some of these research areas may be the first ones to get the chop. I think that would be absolutely disastrous in terms of our primary industries. I hope that when people wish to talk about low government, they might specify which particular area they want to chop so that we know precisely what we are talking about. I believe that unfortunately research often becomes a low priority because people often cannot see the benefits immediately or they do not take enough time or effort to follow through the research efforts as they flow through to production and then through to the economy.

I have only one other item that I wish to raise. It concerns the procedures adopted by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation with regard to the voting procedures on levies. Considerable concern has been expressed, by the Livestock and Grain Producers Association in particular, to the effect that the existing methods used in fact make it almost impossible for growers to reject a levy increase. I believe that this situation really is not conducive to good relations within those areas. I think it is far better, in terms of the vital importance to research, that there always be a continuous and voluntary support by the industry for the levying of funds for research. I think that if we move to the point where we are suggesting that it is almost impossible for the growers themselves to desist from raising those levies, we will get to a point of compulsory levying-such that without industry support the research effort could be brought into disrepute. I do not think that there is anything in it for the Government. I do not think there is anything in it for the industry. I hope that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), in his response, will address that particular problem. I will wait on that response and possibly then raise this matter again during the Committee debate. I believe it is an important issue. Hopefully, the Government, having that in mind, might be able to look at altering arrangements so as to take away that obvious feeling of resentment that is now rising, at least in the LGPA, with regard to the levying procedures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Collard in the remarks he made in leading for the Opposition in this debate on the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill 1986 and allied Bills. Each of these Bills provides for increases in the maximum rate of levy on produce for research activities, broadly to a level of about 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production. In most cases the operative rates of the levy are between 0.1 and 0.2 per cent of the gross value of the product. These Bill do not automatically raise the operative rates but they provide for levy increases-as required by the industry-to be set in consultation with the industry. The levy payments up to the operative rate will be matched by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a self-help operation by the industries involved. These are industries that produce so much of our export income and that give all Australian's a good standard of living. However, let us look at some of the incentives and assistance that have been taken away from the rural sector in the last few years by this Labor Government. In fact, this is the Government that when it came to office did not maintain the existing drought arrangements in 1983. This cost the farmers in hardship when they were seriously drought affected. In fact, in some cases the Government asked for the money back. In June 1983 the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) announced an increase in rural adjustment funding-only to have it reduced in the 1984-85 Budget by about $18m, or more than 40 per cent, to a reduced figure of about $24.8m. The impact of the 1983 Budget was to increase the meat inspection services by some 200 per cent. The Government gave only $20m for wool promotion after promising $28m. This was the Government that cut back on the petroleum freight subsidies to country areas. It removed tax concessions for the clearing and cultivation of new land and swamp drainage. It removed the sales tax exemption on fuels and lubricants and tied the excise to rises in the consumer price index.

What happened in the 1984 Budget? The indexation of diesel fuel rebates for off-road users was not implemented until February 1985. This cost farmers some $25m. Of course, barley growers, whom we are discussing in the debate on the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill, are large users of fuel. The Government's fuel policies are definitely hurting those particular growers. The Government crucified the wine industry, just to mention another industry, by the imposition of the 10 per cent sales tax and a reduction in duty on imported wines from 20 per cent to 10 per cent. This was also the Government that changed the national disaster funding so that in my State of New South Wales the trigger base amount was raised from $10m to $18.49m before Commonwealth financial intervention came into place. This also put more burdens on the State before the three-for-one Commonwealth funding became operative. All this time the plight of farmers has been totally ignored. At the moment New South Wales is very dry with some areas probably in a drought situation. Assistance for research for industries such as the livestock industry will be of no value if farmers cannot afford to feed their stock. I imagine that farmers who are listening to this debate at the moment will be wondering whether the Government will produce a drought package this year. This is all very relevant to funding for research, which is the subject of this debate.

The rip-off continued in the May mini-Budget of 1985. Since the Labor Government came to power in 1983 it has removed some $440m from the rural sector in its Budgets and mini-Budgets. Decreases in government spending in rural Australia serve only to increase the cost burden to individual farmers in the long term. Research funding will become irrelevant if these problems are not addressed. The statement made only in the last week or so by the Minister for Primary Industry that world prices are the problem epitomises the Federal Government's continued failure to focus on the inadequacies of domestic economic policies over which it has direct control. Mr Kerin should have concentrated his statement in this area. Of course, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) should have done a little more in his recent trip around the world to make sure that Australia has a better say in the United States of America which has recently dumped its produce in places such as North Yemen. I do not know whether our wheat growers are very happy about what has happened in that respect. Likewise, I do not think our rice growers would be happy about rice being dumped in Papua New Guinea.

It may be that world prices are contributing to the current rural crisis in Australia. But surely the repeated raids on the primary industry portfolio by the Hawke Government since 1983 have served only to compound the farmers' problems rather than alleviate them. Budget outlays for primary industry amount to 0.5 per cent of the total budgetary outlay. The cost to Australian farmers of the manipulation of the exchange rate is estimated to be $750m in a full year. The fuel excise has been increased by 157 per cent since the Labor Government came to office. It is only now, several months after the drop in world oil prices, that the Government has replaced the fuel excise rebate which it took away in one fell swoop.

We have been told in the recent statement of the Minister for Primary Industry that, because primary production represents less than 10 per cent of economic activity in Australia, there is no way the Government is going to redesign our entire economic policy for the sole benefit of a single sector; that is, the primary industry sector. This is a sell out, considering the fact that Australia's rural exports provide approximately 40 per cent of this country's export earnings.

The Government claims that the success of the economy and the labour market implies that there be `minimal inflation, strong economic growth and international competitiveness'. To say that the Hawke Government has had success on these issues is a long way from the truth. Our inflation rate of 9.2 per cent is more than twice that of our major trading partner, Japan, and over five times that of the United States inflation rate. The Hawke Government has relied on the forecast rate of economic growth to get it out of the economic quagmire. It has failed us. The artificial support afforded the Australian dollar via domestic interest rate policies has served only to weaken the Australian rural exporters' international competitiveness rather than enhance it. Why should the farmers of this country have to wear the effects of this piecemeal monetary policy approach when all along they are striving to increase their efficiency and gain much needed foreign exchange via the export of their produce? Here again, exports will be helped by a research levy on barley and on the other produce which is the subject of the legislation before us.

The balance sheet indicates that since 1983 the Australian Labor Party has taken away $440m and has given back some $100m to the primary industry sector. This does not compare very well with the $120m that the Government recently gave to the banks for the building sector. Why has not the Minister for Primary Industry told other Cabinet Ministers that high interest rates caused by this Government's support of the Australian dollar are sending primary producers to the wall? Let us hope that the primary producers of this country do not have to suffer this unsympathetic government much longer before it vanishes to the history books.

As Senator Collard intimated when leading for the Opposition in this debate, we support the research Bills that are now before the Senate. I hope that the Government addresses itself to some of the other problems that face rural communities. As I have said before, if it does not this great country will not have the industries or the expertise of people on the land to carry us forward in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the comments that Senator Collard made on behalf of the Opposition in relation to the group of Bills before the Senate. I join with him in supporting the thrust of the legislation which has been proposed by the Government. We are, of course, talking about the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill 1986 and allied Bills which are concerned with rural products and all of which propose to increase the maximum rate of levy which can be applied for research purposes in accordance with the provisions of the relative principal Acts. The Bills propose an increase in the maximum rate of levy to be applied for research into the relevant products. All of the Bills would have the effect of increasing research contributions to about 0.5 per cent of the current gross value of production of the industry concerned. Of course, the operative or actual levy rate remains unchanged and will not be affected by the proposed amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments have the virtue of facilitating action on any request by the industry for an operative rate increase made by regulation and thereby will avoid delays caused by the pressure of legislative business in the Parliament at the time a request is made. I believe that one of the difficulties that industries in Australia have when they get involved with government, particularly with levy payments and the like, is that parliamentary, governmental and bureaucratic delays lead to unconscionable delays in payments or receipts by industries. The method being proposed in this package of Bills is, therefore, commendable to the extent that it will reduce those delays.

I also note that no additional budgetary outlays are going to result from the amendments. Rather, the Bills will enable the Government to agree to an industry request for an operative rate increase above the current maximum which would then generate additional matching budgetary outlays. These Bills are important because they relate to the whole area of research in the Australian rural sector. I am glad to see the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, at the table during this debate because these Bills are really about our research and development per se and, therefore, are also about the future competitiveness of the Australian economy, though, of course, directed in this instance to the rural sector.

I believe that the importance of research and development for Australia's future cannot be overstated. The Economic Planning Advisory Council stressed this importance in its recent report on technology and innovation-a report which is an excellent contribution to literature and the debate on this subject. Of course, this has been done in many other places. It is one of those issues that attracts bipartisan political support in terms of its importance. We may differ from time to time on the best method of increasing research and development in Australia, but there is no question at all that we are agreed it is important that it be increased. We need to look much more than we have at the priorities that we as a nation accord to the different areas of research effort. Recent examples have been cited of millions of dollars of government funding going into research projects which I think many people would argue are not as essential as some of the other areas which are being starved of research funds. For example, there are research funds for such topics in universities at the moment as the sociology of housework. I am sure the sociology of housework is an important subject, but I doubt that it is as important as putting funds into research for the development of the rural sector of this great nation of ours, a rural sector which is vital to the lifeblood and future of our country because it still provides not far short of 50 per cent of our total export earnings. If we as a nation were to suffer a further decline in an already disastrous overseas trading position, the problems confronting Australia would be even greater than those which confront us at the moment. I will turn to those in a moment because they are very considerable indeed.

I welcome these Bills and I hope that they presage an attempt by the Government to undertake a much greater scrutiny of public funded research. I trust that the Government will heed that warning when these Bills are enacted. However, there is another issue which bears directly on the efficiency and competitiveness and in directly on the research effort of our agricultural rural sector to which I would like to draw particular attention. I refer to the Government's overall domestic policies and their impact on farmers and the industries that service them and the climate in which they must operate. We have heard a great deal lately about the impact of this Government's policies on the farmer; the high inflation rate we are experiencing, which is having a catastrophic effect on the rural sector; high interest rates; increasing levels of taxation and regulation and the toll this is having on the rural sector and on the economy as a whole.

The increase in the inflation rate in Australia, announced last week at an annual rate in excess of 9 per cent, is perhaps the most serious economic statistic that has come out of the Government in recent months. It means that inflation is now decidedly on an upturn, but even more significant is the fact that our upturn is occurring when inflation is still falling in other countries of the world. The disparity between the level of inflation in Australia today, relative to the average inflation rate of our major trading partners, and indeed the rest of the Western world through the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, on average is greater than it has been since statistics on this international comparative basis were recorded, with the exception of a minor period in 1961.

So far from the Government being able to point to a good economic record in perhaps the most important area of responsibility for government, namely, keeping control on costs and prices, this Government has a worst record, relative to our trading partners and the rest of the Western world than any other government in our history. Most people in the community, particularly those buying homes, small businessmen and farmers know full well that the record levels of real interest rates we have been experiencing in Australia in recent times add another quite crippling burden to economic activity in this country and to the problems of most people in our community in terms of maintaining their standard of living. Those sorts of things have a fundamental effect on the nation's competitiveness, on the competitiveness of the rural sector, and on the real effect, impact and value of the research funds to the rural sector, which we are debating in this legislation. The less competitive we are in terms of our overall policies, the less effective is the rural research effort we put in.

Not only the man on the land is suffering as a result of this Governments's quite unfair and discriminatory policies but also the industries that service the rural community. Recently, I visited a small factory in Swan Hill, in the Mallee area of my own State of Victoria. A small business, very proudly called Grizzly, produces a new, very highly innovative and unique disc plough. It might be expected that research and development assistance would be forthcoming for an enterprise such as this that promised improved and cost effective ploughing techniques for Australian farmers. It is a very innovative, dynamic, well thought out and researched and managed company. After protracted negotiations, a great deal of paper work, and cost in time and effort by that company the negotiations came to nought and the research and development assistance that appeared to be likely to be forthcoming did not eventuate. When additional transportation costs of $3,000 are added to the cost of these unique disc ploughs in getting them to Western Australian and Queensland farmers, one realises the enormity of the problem facing some of the industries, particularly industries based in rural areas which are servicing and supporting the rural sector as a whole. The transportation costs of $3,000 per disc which amounts to 10 per cent of the selling price of the product, imposes an enormous additional burden. The additional transport cost is high essentially because of the regulatory and other economic policies of this Government. Thus the manufacturer is severely disadvantaged and, therefore, the client user of the product-namely, the farmer-is also disadvantaged in terms of adding still further to the cost squeeze facing the man on the land.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has its sticky fingers in the pockets of the income producers.

—That is entirely right. I believe that one of the biggest indictments that can and must be made of this Government is the fact that it has taken no steps to ease the fundamental problem facing the rural sector of this country, namely, a very vicious and ever increasing cost squeeze.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Seventy-Fifth Conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being near the hour of 7 p.m., to enable the Australian Broadcasting Commission to put the news to air, under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The seventy-fifth conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union was held earlier this month in Mexico City. As the leader of the Australian delegation I shall be presenting a report on the delegation's activities and initiatives at a later date. However, a short remark is in order to express gratitude to the Australian Ambassador in Mexico City, Mr John McCarthy, and his staff for the outstanding assistance they provided during the delegation's visit to Mexico. On the two previous occasions when I led the Australian delegation, my task was made easy because of the co-operation of all members of the delegation. The same situation prevailed on the visit to Mexico. But on this occasion, my duties were made even easier because of the Australian Embassy's assistance. Members were provided with extremely competent administrative, secretarial and interpretative services. The Embassy staffed a room in the hotel in which the delegation was staying. Ms Beverley Morrisby from the Embassy worked long hours in that room assisting delegates and accompanying persons. I have no doubt that each member of the delegation was grateful for the assistance of the Ambassador and his staff. I am also sure that all members were impressed by the Embassy's ability to accommodate special requests which, in several instances, called for assistance which went well beyond the normal call of duty.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Australian delegation to the IPU visited Togo last year, it had no assistance from an Australian post. The nearest Australian representation was 200 kilometres away in Lagos. It was a baptism of fire for me as leader and, I expect, for the Secretary to the delegation, Mr Tom Wharton. Administratively, the contrast of the Togo visit with our visit to Mexico could not have been more marked. Our Australian embassies and high commissions do far, far more than assist Australian citizens who happen to be in their area of responsibility. Yet until an Australian citizen living or travelling overseas experiences some type of difficulty, particularly in a non-English speaking country, the importance of our overseas posts is largely unrecognised. In the 11 days I spent in Mexico City, the stresses of living in that country became all too apparent. There are adjustments to be made in terms of the standard and quality of living, there are the problems of poverty, an uncertain and unstable economy and visible reminders of the still recent tragic earthquake which devastated the city centre. It is remarkable that, under these conditions, the Australian Embassy maintains such high morale and an excellent standing with the Mexican Government, both of which were evident to all members of the delegation.

It would be remiss of me if I did not mention that the delegation benefited greatly from the Ambassador's advice on the current major political, economic and social issues confronting countries of the Central American region, and Mexico in particular. After the Ambassador's briefing, members of the delegation had a sound perception of the problems in that area of the world. There are dangers in mentioning specific people who assisted the delegation because it is possible that others who did assist may not be mentioned. If that happens, I apologise for the omission. In addition to Mr McCarthy and Ms Morrisby I would, however, like to mention Ms Beris Gwynne, the post's First Secretary; Mr Bruce Cowled, the Second Secretary (Consular and Administrative); and Mr David McLachlan-Karr, the post's Third Secretary. Their assistance was invaluable and was greatly appreciated.

In Mexico City there is a striking statue of which the Mexicans are particularly proud. It is called The Angel. It is in this respect that I wish to make special mention of the assistance provided by the Embassy's three drivers-Andres, German, and Salamon. Those who have experienced the Mexican's frenetic style of traffic would understand that I am not overstating the case when I say that the Embassy's drivers were our guardian angels. On behalf of the Australian delegation I commend the Ambassador and his staff for their co-operation during our visit. The high regard the delegation holds for Mexico and its people is in no small part due to the Embassy's outstanding level of assistance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.04 p.m.
