QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 13 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In what ways does Government policy on Aboriginal broadcasting in Central Australia affect the nature and economics of providing the Remote Commercial Television Service (RCTS) and remote public television services in South Australia.
(2) In what ways have Government policy announcements over the past 2 years demonstrated that Aboriginal broadcasting and new satellite services policies have been co-ordinated.

(3) Is the South Australian Government providing a 75 per cent subsidy for Self Help Satellite reception facilities in communities serviced by the Outback Areas Community Development Trust, and that the South Australian government has indicated it expects the Commonwealth to offer equivalent subsidies for Aboriginal communities such as Ernabella.
(4) Will this level of subsidy, or anything like it, be forthcoming from the Commonwealth.
(5) Was the Department of Aboriginal Affairs consulted over the choice of `mandatory communities' for the delivery of Remote Commercial Television Services.
(6) Is the Department satisfied that the selection made adequately reflects the needs and concerns of the significant Aboriginal population living in RCTS service areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Government policy on Aboriginal broadcasting in remote Australia is based on the recommendations of the Task Force on Aboriginal and Islander Broadcasting and Communications.
In relation to Remote Commercial Television Services the Task Force recommended that:
licensing provisions for remote area commercial services should recognise the special interests of the remote Aboriginal population
in particular there should be provision for Aboriginal access and for definition of programming and advertising standards which recognise Aboriginal cultural interests
localism policies should be reinforced to ensure greater sensitivity of commercial broadcasters to their Aboriginal audiences.

In respect of television generally, the Task Force recommended that Aboriginal communities wanting to do so should have the capacity to switch off incoming programs and opt for local insertion, subject to the necessary legislative provisions.

These recommendations have been endorsed by the Government as a basis for policy development. In respect of RCTS hearings, the recommendations have been brought to the attention of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which has indicated that special conditions or windows may be applied to RCTS licences to ensure that provision is made for Aboriginal programs. This will not substantially affect the nature and economics of providing Remote Commercial Television Services, but will have an influence on programming decisions.

(2) The Task Force on Aboriginal and Islander Broadcasting was commissioned by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Minister for Communications to look at the issue of Aboriginal broadcasting and communications in the light of developments in satellite services. The Task Force published its findings in August 1984.
The Government's response to the Task Force Report was announced by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on 27 November 1985.
The Commonwealth Government has continued to provide funds to support Aboriginal broadcasting initiatives and to provide policy coordination through the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
An Implementation Task Group has been formed by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Department of Communications to give effect to the Government's policy on Aboriginal broadcasting.

Continuing consultations are held with organisations such as the Public Broadcasting Foundation, the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia, the ABC's Aboriginal Programs Sub-Committee and Aboriginal broadcasting organisations on developments in Aboriginal broadcasting.

Officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs have appeared before the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's Remote Commercial Television Service Licence hearings on two occasions, and the Department has financially supported Aboriginal organisations to represent Aboriginal interests before the Tribunal.

(3) The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was informed of the South Australian Government's commitment to subsidise self help satellite reception facilities in outback areas in the context of discussions on the application by Imparja Television Pty Ltd for the central zone Remote Commercial Television Service licence.

(4) Discussions are continuing between the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Department of Communications on the provision of satellite television reception facilities for remote Aboriginal communities. Twelve of the largest of these communities will receive ABC television reception under the Remote or Underserved Communities Scheme being implemented by the Department of Communications.
It has not yet been decided what assistance will be provided by the Commonwealth Government to extend television reception to other remote Aboriginal communities.
(5) The list of 37 communities at which retransmission facilities are to be established by the RCTS licensees was developed by the Department of Communications according to the following criteria:
the community lies within the likely RCTS Service Area;
the community has a population of at least 1,000; and
the community has a National (ie ABC) transmitting site available for sharing.

I am informed that these criteria recognised the economic fragility of the RCTS service, and sought to minimise the financial burden placed on RCTS licensees while nevertheless extending the service to the largest practicable number of people. Additional selection criteria would have resulted in unreasonably heavy expenditure on the part of RCTS licensees and may have jeopardised the establishment of an RCTS service.

(6) Most of the towns listed to receive RCTS retransmission facilities have sizable Aboriginal populations who will receive a commercial television service through the facilities provided. The needs of the remote Aboriginal population were addressed by the Task Force on Aboriginal Broadcasting and Communications. The Task Force recommended measures to introduce television to Aboriginal communities on a planned basis. Most Aboriginal communities are too small to be included among those to receive facilities from the RCTS licensee. The existing RUCS program does not extend to these smaller communities. Discussions are continuing between the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Department of Communications on the provision of television to remote Aboriginal communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 September 1985 (Hansard, page 530), Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle asked me, as Minister representing the Attorney-General, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct a question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General which follows the questions raised earlier by Senator Reynolds and Senator Chaney. I ask Senator Gareth Evans whether he is aware of the statement of the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, that the Family Law Act should be amended to require the Family Court to ignore social security benefits in determining maintenance. If he is aware of that statement, does he not agree that the point of it is that the Government has in prospect the setting of maintenance, rather than the collection of maintenance, which was the matter being discussed in the other answers this morning? If the Government proposes the amendment of the Family Law Act and the setting of maintenance by the Court, will the Government allow its members a free vote on any provision in the Family Law Act, as was the case when that provision was inserted in the Murphy Bill?
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 12 September 1985 my colleague the Minister for Social Security indicated in an address to the Australian Council of Social Services his view that the provisions of the Family Law Act 1975 allowing a court, in awarding maintenance, to consider the availability of social security benefits, were in need of review. This issue does, as the honourable senator points out, relate specifically to the setting of the amount of maintenance to be paid rather than to the collection of maintenance. I should point out, however, that the effectiveness of collection does have an impact on the size of the order that courts will be prepared to award.

As the Senate was informed on 20 February 1986 (Senate Hansard, p. 723) in debate on a related issue the Government considers that there is a need to clarify the wording of the Family Law Act to ensure the proper interpretation of the relevant provision of the Act, and proposes to do this when the Act is next substantively amended.
The question of a free vote is one which will need to be determined in the appropriate way when the amendment is presented.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 12 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many statutory authorities currently exist under the auspices of the Minister's Department.
(2) What are the names of these authorities.
(3) What appeal mechanisms, if any, exist for the general public to lodge a complaint against these authorities.

(4) If it is proved that any member of staff of any of these authorities is guilty of incompetence, what action, if any, could be taken by a member of the public to sue the authority for compensation; if it is not possible to sue the authority, why is that the case.

(5) How many cases concerning these authorities are currently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and what is the delay at present between the listing of a case and its hearing before the tribunal.
(6) If any statutory authority under the Minister's Department cannot be sued, will the Minister consider amending the relevant legislation to make this possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Aboriginal Development Commission; Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies; Aboriginal Land Commissioners; Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account Advisory Committee; Northern Land Council; Central Land Council; Tiwi Land Council; Alyawarra Aboriginal Land Trust; Angarapa Aboriginal Land Trust; Arnhem Land Aboriginal Land Trust; Amoonguna Aboriginal Land Trust; Beswick Aboriginal Land Trust; Central Desert Aboriginal Land Trust; Daguragu Aboriginal Land Trust; Daly River/Port Keats Aboriginal Land Trust; Delissaville/Wagait/Larrakia Aboriginal Land Trust; Haasts Bluff Aboriginal Land Trust; Hooker Creek Aboriginal Land Trust; Iwupataka Aboriginal Land Trust; Jabiluka Aboriginal Land Trust; Kakadu Aboriginal Land Trust; Katiti Aboriginal Land Trust; Karlantijpa South Aboriginal Land Trust; Karlantijpa North Aboriginal Land Trust; Lake Mackay Aboriginal Land Trust; Ltalaltuma Aboriginal Land Trust; Marra Aboriginal Land Trust; Narwinbi Aboriginal Land Trust; Ntaria Aboriginal Land Trust; Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust; Rodna Aboriginal Land Trust; Roulpmaulpma Aboriginal Land Trust; Santa Teresa Aboriginal Land Trust; Tiwi Aboriginal Land Trust; Uluru-Katatjuta Aboriginal Land Trust; Uruna Aboriginal Land Trust; Waanyi/Garawa Aboriginal Land Trust; Warrabri Aboriginal Land Trust; Wirliyajarrayi Aboriginal Land Trust; Wurralibi Aboriginal Land Trust; Yingawunarri/Mudbura Aboriginal Land Trust; Yuendumu Aboriginal Land Trust; Yunkanjini Aboriginal Land Trust.

(3) The general public may use the review procedures available under what is commonly called Administrative Law package save that the Aboriginal Land Councils and Land Trusts are exempt agencies for the purposes of schedule 2 of the Freedom of Information Act 1982.

(4) All the authorities listed above except for the Aboriginal Land Commissioners and the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account Advisory Committee are bodies corporate and may be sued in their corporate names.

The Attorney-General's Department has advised that, unless an authority is statutorily protected, it is liable for the torts of its servants committed in the course of their duty. Where employees, acting in the course of their duty are incompetent and, as a consequence, loss is suffered by a member of the public, it will commonly be found that the act or omission which was seen as incompetent was also tortious. For example, incompetent driving would probably be tortious. In the absence of a denial of liability the negligent giving of erroneous advice is tortious where the advice is given by a person having a duty of care to one who suffers foreseeable damage as a result of reasonably relying on that advice. Many other forms of incompetence would also be tortious, but each case would need to be considered on its own facts. None of the authorities listed in answer to part (1) of this question is statutorily protected against general liability in tort.
(5) Three concerning the Aboriginal Development Commission. The delay between listing and hearing is approximately three months.

(6) The Aboriginal Land Commissioners are given the same protection and immunity as Justices of the High Court in the exercise of their functions as is appropriate to the quasi-judicial nature of their function under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. The Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account Advisory Committee is an unincorporated body which exists solely to advise the Minister in connection with making payments out of the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 October 1985 (Hansard, page 1322 and 1323), Senator Townley asked Senator Ryan, as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it true that jobless New Zealand immigrants cost Australia some $64m per annum in unemployment benefit payments; is it true that the unemployment rate for New Zealand immigrants in Australia is almost twice as high as the rate for the rest of the community; when will the Government recognise that Australia can no longer afford to accept New Zealand's unemployed and apply to New Zealanders the same immigration restrictions as apply to citizens of other countries and how much is being received by Australians in New Zealand by way of unemployment benefits?

On 12 February 1986 (Hansard, page 178), Senator Townley asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs if, in view of the large number of people coming to Australia from New Zealand, many of whom immediately receive unemployment benefits, the Government intends to continue with its open door policy with New Zealand. If it does, he asked if statistics could be made available on the number of New Zealanders who have come to Australia over the past five years, the number who have received unemployment benefits and the cost to the Australian taxpayer of those benefits.
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senators' questions:

Since 1920 there has been an Arrangement between the Governments of Australia and New Zealand to facilitate the movement of both Australian and New Zealand citizens to and from each other's country. The Arrangement reflects the close historical, cultural and trade links between the two countries.

The Arrangement is supported by all major political parties. Shortly after coming into office the Hawke Government reviewed the Arrangement. Taking everything into consideration, including the recently signed closer Economic Relations Agreement, it was decided it was in the interests of both countries to maintain the Arrangement. At the same time the Government decided to keep the Arrangement under review.
At June 1984 the number of New Zealand-born residents of Australia was 183,000.

The movement of New Zealand citizens across the Tasman under the Arrangement over the past five financial years is set out below. The statistics are derived from the stated intentions on passenger cards that permanent or long term arrival or departure is proposed.
PERMANENT OR LONG TERM MOVEMENT TO OR FROM AUSTRALIA OF NEW ZEALAND CITIZENS UNDER THE TRANS TASMAN ARRANGEMENT
Arrivals
Departures
Net Gain

Source: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Minister for Social Security has advised that the latest figure on the number of unemployment beneficiaries in Australia who were born in New Zealand was 11,035 at November 1985 and that the estimated annual liability for these benefits was $60m. The Minister for Social Security has further advised that the cost of payments to Australian-born unemployment beneficiaries in New Zealand is not available. In December 1985 the unemployment rate of New Zealanders was 8.9 per cent, compared to 7.7 per cent Australian-born and 8.5 per cent overseas-born. (Source-Australian Bureau of Statistics Bulletin, ``The Labour Force, Australia'', December 1985)
